PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by Western Australian Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Giles (from 16 citizens), Powell (from 26 citizens) and Vallentine (from 380 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:-
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament; the humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
That Kingsford-Smith Airport is becoming increasingly congested and existing facilities are inadequate to handle the number of aircraft or their passengers.

The Federal Government's plans to divert aircraft from Mascot to Bankstown and/or increase landing charges for peak periods will do little to relieve congestion and will place enormous financial and other burdens on commuter airlines and their passengers.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to take heed of airline and travel industry warnings and-
1. give immediate approval for the construction of a third runway at Mascot
2. upgrade existing radar and other traffic control facilities to enable Australia's high safety record to be maintained.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat,-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National AIDS Program: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are offended and outraged by the direction of the AIDS Programme in Tasmania, in that it actively promotes Homosexual Acts and in particular anal intercourse, and that taxpayers money is being used to fund literature which directly promotes homosexual behaviour as a normal and desirable human activity.

Your petitioners therefore urgently and strongly request that the Federal Government and the Minister for Health review the National AIDS Programme and withdraw funding for this literature, and from any other aspects of the AIDS Campaign which encourages or condones anal intercourse.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Toy Libraries
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully request,
(1) that the existing laws, which exclude toy libraries from exemption from Sales Tax be removed i.e. toy libraries pay sales tax.

(2) They believe that toy libraries are non-profit and educational, and that they are of particular benefit to families who because of financial, social and geographical constraints most need a toy library.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Senate will take measures to alter the existing laws of Sales Tax to include toy libraries within the exemptions.

PETITION.TITLE: South and Port Melbourne Unemployment Group
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to close the South and Port Melbourne Unemployment Group. We want S.P.U.G. to remain open and serve the people in our community as it has done for the past ten years.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: NUCLEAR POWERED AND NUCLEAR ARMED SUBMARINES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the sinking of the Soviet `Mike' class nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed submarine off Norway on 7 April 1989;

(b) further notes that this submarine and many of its unfortunate crew now join up to 5 other Soviet submarines at the bottom of the sea along with 2 United States submarines which sank in the Atlantic in 1963 and 1968;

(c) questions the predictable Soviet assertion that there is no danger of radiation leakages from the nuclear reactor and nuclear weapons on board, just as all the nuclear weapon states have made doubtful assurances in the event of accidents involving their nuclear warships or underground nuclear weapon tests over the years;

(d) condemns the escalation of the nuclear arms race at sea which can only result in an increase of accidents involving nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed warships and submarines, ultimately involving further pollution of the oceans as a legacy for generations yet unborn; and

(e) calls on the Government to reject the recent assertion of the British Prime Minister (Mrs Thatcher) that nuclear weapons should be a permanent feature of our world order and to intensify Australia's commitment towards talks on regional security and naval arms control and disarmament so that these kinds of accidents can never happen again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Reynolds is still recovering from a car accident and will be absent from the chamber for Question Time this week. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Reynolds in her capacity as Minister for Local Government or Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs should be directed to Senator Ray. Those questions which would be directed to her in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women should be directed to me.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I preface my question by reminding the Minister that during the past 12 months the cost of business finance, in the form of bank bill rates and bank housing loan rates has risen by 6 1/2 per cent and 2 1/2 per cent, respectively, and that the Government has induced these interest rate rises in an attempt to deal with the serious economic and particularly, balance of payments situations which its policies have created. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that, with the economy still overstretched and the balance of payments crisis continuing, the provision of tax cuts not matched by reductions in government spending, plus significant wage increases, will almost certainly mean a further rise in interest rates, for both businesses and householders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In so far as the contents of the April statement to be made on 12 April are concerned, Senator Stone should await that statement before he draws any conclusions about the quantum of tax cuts or wages, which will be dealt with in that statement. It is very dangerous to make projections on the basis of what we at this stage do not know.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree with Senator Stone's comment on the basis of the national accounts figures published last week that the economy still appears to be growing strongly, although it is very difficult to say on the basis of those figures what has happened since the period to which those figures apply. I suspect that there are conflicting signals about that. But there is no doubt that the Government is committed to tax cuts, which will be announced this week, and the nature of a trade-off, so-called, with the unions regarding wages will be announced at the same time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Do I understand from the latter part of the Minister's reply that he does now agree with the premise in my question, which he seemed to be denying at the beginning, that Wednesday's statement by the Treasurer will refer to tax cuts and proposed wage increases in 1989-90? Secondly, do I understand him to be saying that, although he concedes that the economy is still considerably overstretched, the provision of those tax cuts and wage increases will not lead to a further round of interest rate increases of the kinds that have been occurring for the past 12 months?

—I am not in the business of predicting interest rates and I would not draw that conclusion. In the past we have all drawn conclusions, including Senator Stone, about what is likely to happen in the economy in the next six to 12 months. I shall not embark on that course.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as Minister representing the Prime Minister on the status of women. The introduction of the higher education contribution scheme has been opposed by some because they argue that it might be a reason for women not entering or continuing higher education. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the higher education contribution scheme has resulted in a reduction in the number of female enrolments in higher education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The information which Senator Crowley requests is freely available to the public, but some people do not seem to have obtained it. Therefore, I welcome the question in order that Opposition senators, for example, who fall into that category will be able to be better informed. Early estimates obtained from all universities and colleges on student numbers in 1989 show that enrolments by women students in higher education are at record levels. Women constitute 232,000 or 51.5 per cent of higher education enrolments, an increase of almost 17,000 on 1988. Overall higher education enrolments, male and female, have increased by in excess of 30,000-a 7 per cent increase on the 1988 figures-bringing the total student population to 451,500. These figures represent, the highest level of enrolments by women in the history of this country. It is fair to say that they refute criticisms that the higher education contribution scheme would deter women's participation in post-secondary education. Research released last week by the Australian National University predicts that the higher education contribution scheme will have no overall impact on enrolments and in fact that female participation in higher education will continue to grow more highly than that of males.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government specifically addressed the needs of women in formulating that scheme. The higher education contribution scheme is related to personal rather than family income levels, giving women the opportunity to make free choices about their own educational future. As the Government announced, the scheme contributions will be used to create additional higher education places, many of which on the basis of current trends will be filled by women. At the end of the current triennium this Government, since coming to power, will have created an extra 110,000 higher education places, lifting women's participation from 46 per cent in 1983 to today's record level of 51.5 per cent. In respect of some of the criticism which has come from Opposition sources, I might say that the Opposition cannot get its higher education policy to add up. It has a $300m hole in it which would have to be filled by reduced institutional budgets or by reducing the up front fee to at least $2,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. It appears to me that the Minister has gone from the information giving exercise that he outlined he was about to undertake to debating the question. I ask you to call him to order and have him complete his answer.
—I believe the Minister has finished his answer.

—Does the Minister for Resources know of the international energy analyst, PetroConsultants, and does he agree that it is one of the most authoritative international energy analysts? Is it a fact that PetroConsultants has described the Government's energy policy as seriously flawed, and says that there is an urgent need for policy changes `to avoid excessive and irreversible crude import dependency'? Does the Minister agree that this assessment directly condemns the Government's policy, which does not give priority to encouraging Australian oil search, on the basis that oil can be bought on the world market and the cost of purchase is offset by increased trade in other commodities? Will the Minister review the policy which, if not changed, will condemn Australia to a high and potentially unaffordable dependence on imported crude oil before the end of this century?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is yes; the answer to the second question is yes. The third question is not as simple as Senator Chaney proposes in his comments. The consultants he referred to are a respected authority but the latest figures show that Australia's current dependence on domestically generated crude oil is about 85 per cent. According to the figures, by the end of the century we will move to about a 35 per cent dependency. The argument as to whether our regime of taxing is a sufficient incentive to oil producers and for exploration purposes is a matter of some contention between the Government and some of those associations representing oil companies, as well as individual oil companies. Our view is strongly that the regime is comparable to that in countries of a like nature and indeed is a regime that is competitive on the world scale. It should provide an incentive for oil exploration and production.

ANSWER.PARA: Two other matters of significance have to be considered along with the policies of the Government. The first is the price of oil, which as we all know was heading to $10 a barrel just a few months ago. Falling prices are a major disincentive for companies conducting oil research. Fortunately the price is now in the $20 range for top benchmark crude, west Texas intermediate, and is expected to remain in that range for a while. Maybe it will soften in the middle of the year when the northern summer breaks, but oil prices are expected in the medium term to be at about the level they are at now. That will be a comprehensive increase on the lower prices being experienced when companies were framing their exploration agendas last year and should ensure that there is an increase in exploration. The second major factor is Australia's prospectivity and how it compares with other areas. This relates to the likelihood of finding oil. We think the prospectivity for Australia is good. I announced last Monday the release of acreage for bidding-those biddings are to close in August this year-which will open up areas for further exploration on the continental margins of Australia. All of that has to be seen as consistent with the picture presented by the consultants. I should also say that traditionally consultants operate for the industry and not for the Government, and a commonality of view between what they say and what the industry espouses is not surprising.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer but I ask: Is it a fact that the Government's policy, taking into account the considerable additional cost of oil imports which is likely, given the Minister's own figures in the answer he has just given, is based on the assumption that that cost can be offset by other energy exports? Does the Minister, having considered the views put forward by Petro Consultants, have any concern about the fundamental validity of that assumption?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are always concerned about and examining whether judgments we make are, in the light of experience, sound and proper judgments. I think the basic validity of the assumption, as a general assumption, is proper and well based. It is not something from which we would wish to divert; it is certainly not anything with which we would quibble. We take the view that it is not sensible to divert economic resources to one particular form of energy, in this case oil, and thus ignore the contribution that other sources of energy make to the general economy-that is, to set up a dysfunction, if you like, in terms of particular supports.

ANSWER.PARA: We know that maybe shortly after July this year we will commence shipments of liquefied natural gas off the North West Shelf and that will contribute greatly to our balance of payments. We are a major coal exporter. Indeed, in energy terms, we are a net exporter of energy because of our coal production, and that contributes into the future of our energy trade balance. So, because we are down in one area of the balance but up in others does not mean that we should divert resources from what we do better to areas where we are suffering a reduction. Overall, we will come out of it pretty much in balance or a bit ahead of balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the coalition's foreign affairs policy which was launched last Friday. Does the Federal Government propose to adopt any of this policy and, if not, would the Minister please advise the Senate why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always operated from the premise that it is important for Australia's foreign policy to be conducted on as bipartisan a basis as possible. I have actively scoured the Opposition's foreign policy, as released last Friday, for indications of a similar perspective being shared. I am certainly prepared to acknowledge that there are a number of areas of the Opposition's policy with which we would have no basic disagreement and which could certainly form the basis of a fully bipartisan policy approach. Let me instance in that respect the priority it gives to our relations with countries of the South West Pacific and the Western Pacific rim and, indeed, the specific language of the Opposition's policy on New Caledonia which, despite the editorial in this morning's Australian, is not language with which we have any disagreement at all. Nor do we disagree about, in broad terms, the direction and focus of our aid program, support for the ANZUS alliance, support for an active Australian role in international efforts to achieve arms control and disarmament, recognition of the role and significance of the Commonwealth of Nations, acknowledgment of the increasing importance of international environmental issues and, indeed, the Opposition's general approach to the Middle East.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I do have to say that in many respects adoption by the Government of the Opposition policy would either cause major problems for the country or would involve us in neglecting what are manifestly major national interests. First of all, there are some really conspicuous omissions. There is no mention, for example, of the Republic of Korea, notwithstanding its huge and growing economic importance to us. There is no reference at all to the development of relations with Vietnam and Laos. Again, there are some distortions of focus which are so great as to, in effect, amount to omissions. For example, the proposal for a Pacific Basin community refers only to strengthening our ties with the market economies of the region, ignoring the vast importance already to Australia, obviously, of the People's Republic of China, quite apart from the potential importance of Indo-Chinese countries like Vietnam.

Again, the treatment of our relations with the United States of America, which is alleged to be in many ways the centrepiece of the Opposition's foreign policy, is quite one dimensional in the sense that it deals only with the defence alliance relationship, ignoring the wide ranging trade, economic and other political dimensions of that relationship. Again, the treatment of East-West relations as a whole deals only with arms control, ignoring the other crucial issues which have long been on the superpowers' negotiating agenda, including regional conflicts, human rights and bilateral economic and political relations. Again, and very crucially, I think there is the complete absence of any treatment of trade policy, even at its interface with foreign policy. There is a complete failure to acknowledge the significance of the integration of the former Foreign Affairs and Trade departments, an integration which we certainly would not wish to reverse. It is surprising that the Opposition policy does not seem to acknowledge the significance of that.

Moving from sins of omission to those of commission, there are a number of specifics in the policy which are simply impossible to accept. They make no sense at all from an Australian national interest perspective, and they are simply misconceived or just plain wrong. For a start, the proposals to renegotiate the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty are wholly unrealistic as well as being wholly undesirable. They are at odds with the strong and growing support for that treaty in the region and they are at odds with the acknowledgment by the United States of America that it is not inconsistent with United States practices and activities in the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why has it not ratified it?

—And to pick up that point, it is at odds with the declared willingness of the United States, as indicated to me directly by Secretary of State Baker a few weeks ago, to review its decision so far not to sign the protocols to the treaty. Then again, the proposal specifically to allow the stationing of nuclear weapons on Australian soil-I repeat, to specifically allow the stationing of nuclear weapons on Australian territory-is quite extraordinary. It is obviously completely at odds with the views of the overwhelming majority of Australians in this respect, and it is unequivocally opposed by us in any foreseeable circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: Again, the enthusiasm of the Opposition policy, recommended to us and to the nation, for the strategic defence initiative program and its deterrent utility is at odds with the review of that which is now being conducted in the United States. That is a program which the Australian Government simply cannot support in its present form.

On chemical weapons, the advocacy of the enlargement of the 1925 Geneva protocol completely misses the point that all international attention is currently focused, as it should be, not upon the Geneva protocol but on implementing a universal new chemical weapons convention to outlaw these weapons entirely and to destroy existing stockpiles. On South Africa, the condemnation of apartheid is totally hollow--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the length of the answer. The question was within Standing Orders, I concede, and that is why I did not take a point of order on the question. But the Minister obviously, by responding to such a question, can make a complete farce of Question Time by devoting a disproportionate amount of time to a policy discussion of this kind. I simply ask you to draw the Minister's attention to the amount of time that he has consumed with his answer in order to enable a reasonable number of questions to be asked at Question Time. I think the Minister would agree that there is unlimited scope for a Minister to speak for an hour on the subject, if he wishes, and I am sure that this Minister could speak for two hours if we gave him an extension of time. I think that would be a quite unreasonable use of this Question Time.
—It is a very long answer but the subject is a serious one and therefore I allowed a reasonable amount of time.

—I certainly agree with Senator Chaney that the Opposition policy is not one such as to justify a disproportionate amount of time being spent on it. I will accordingly bring my answer rapidly to a conclusion. There are only two more specific matters that I wanted to refer to. The first is South Africa and the second is Papua New Guinea-Indonesia. I think the Opposition would be interested in what I have to say about its recommendations to us on both of those.

ANSWER.PARA: As to South Africa, I say this: the condemnation of apartheid, which appears in the policy, is totally hollow when it is accompanied, as this policy document is, by a refusal to apply any of the measures that might bring the South African Government to the negotiating table, and also rings particularly hollow when measured against the tirade of distaste which is directed against black African governments elsewhere on the continent.

Finally, I want to mention specifically a policy proposal which might, on the face of it, look as though it has got some attractions and that is in our immediate region, the proposal for a trilateral arrangement--

TALK.START.PARA: —Boring!

—It is a very boring policy, I agree with you, Senator Walters, boring as all hell. In our immediate region the proposal for a trilateral arrangement between Australia, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea is quite at odds with the policy of successive governments, the Opposition's as well as ours, that Papua New Guinea-Indonesia border relations must remain the responsibility of those two governments. To involve Australia in trilateral discussions could encourage conflicting, unrealistic expectations of us, and it makes far more sense to focus, as we do, on maintaining close bilateral relations with our two neighbours.

ANSWER.PARA: For those reasons and for many more, which I would be delighted to regale the Opposition with had we all a bit more time, the Opposition policy unsurprisingly is not a blueprint that we could possibly accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories seen reports that police on the central coast of New South Wales have warned clubs that they will be raided on Anzac Day if they allow two-up to be played on their premises? Does the Minister agree that the playing of two-up on Anzac Day is part of Australia's national heritage? In view of the facts that a substantial part of the proceeds of these games goes to charity, that a substantial amount of government funding comes from lotteries, lotto, the Totalisator Agency Board and other forms of gambling, and that the police will have to fight their way past all the poker machines to get to the two-up games, will the Minister consider proclaiming the playing of two-up on Anzac Day as part of Australia's heritage under section 6 (2) (e) of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act in order to ensure its preservation?
—I do not know which area of the Minister's portfolio this falls under. Maybe it is `sport'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —This question probably falls under a number of my responsibilities. It is a recreation, which is covered under the Department of Sport. The question also refers to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, so I probably get a role in a few ways. I am aware of the reports; I have seen them. The main part of the question asked whether I agree that the playing of two-up on Anzac Day is part of Australia's national heritage. I think I can say unquestionably yes. I suspect this is the only time that I could proclaim my belief in Australia's heritage and have the support of the National Party of Australia. It would be difficult to imagine even Senator Boswell opposing such a proposition.

ANSWER.PARA: In reference to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, the difficulty I have with that is that it would require the acquisition of actual property. As far as I am aware, the place where these games are often played is usually in the toilets of these clubs. It would be very difficult for the Commonwealth to propose to start to acquire any of them. However, there is one way we could go about this. There is a cultural list for World Heritage. It would be possible to look generally at the clubs of the New South Wales central coast, because they are obviously havens for culture in our society. Those culture vultures who attend them on Anzac Day are entitled to culture. Having said that, I disagree with one part of Senator McLean's question. He said that a substantial part of the proceeds of these games go to charity. I can recall my father coming home a couple of times after Anzac Day with his pockets fairly stuffed full of money. I doubt very much if much of those proceeds made it to charity, beyond that of his bookmaker. I suspect that might have been the case in a number of games. Nonetheless, one does have to fight one's way past poker machines to get to the games. It does strike me as ludicrous. I would hope that the central coast police are a bit more sensible than the article suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question of the Minister. Can I assume that you have said yes, Minister?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to recent media reports concerning the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) negotiations indicating, as for example in the Australian Financial Review this morning, a stunning coup for the Cairns Group? Will the Minister advise the Senate whether these reports are true, particularly as they relate to the implications for Australian agriculture?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to report to the Senate that after exhaustive negotiations in Geneva over the weekend, the log jam in the GATT trade negotiations that developed in Montreal last December has now been resolved. From Australia's point of view that is a result of massive significance. It means that constructive negotiation of fair world trade rules will continue, which is essential for a trading nation of Australia's size. It goes against the views of some pessimists that saw the international trading system as breaking down and forming into bilateral trade deals between the majors.

ANSWER.PARA: I think one ought to pay tribute at the outset to the work of the Australian Ministers and officials who have worked tirelessly to produce an outstandingly successful result of Australia, particularly my colleague Michael Duffy, the Minister for Trade Negotiations, who has acted as chairman throughout this exercise of the 14-country coalition, the Cairns Group, to which Senator McMullan refers, and also his predecessor, Mr John Dawkins, as Minister for Trade who actually established the Cairns Group.

On the topic of agriculture, which has been, as everyone knows, the centrepiece of the log jam and which in many ways is the crucial element in the whole current round, what has happened is that the GATT talks have in essence accepted all the major elements of the original Cairns Group proposal. Those elements are, firstly, a commitment to long term reform in agricultural trade rules, opening up world markets and reducing unfair production and export subsidies as exist in the European Economic Community and the United States. That process of long term reform will be started in 1991, which is the year following the conclusion of the GATT talks. Secondly, until that reform package starts, there will be an immediate freeze or cap on existing hand-outs to farmers, including those in the United States and the European Economic Community. Access to markets, including Japan, is to be maintained at least at current levels. Finally, we have even secured a commitment that countries will reduce the support and protection levels in agriculture in 1990; that is to say, prior to the implementation of the long term reform process.

The significance of all this can hardly be underestimated for Australia. Ultimately, Australian farmers and, indeed, the community will be billions of dollars better off because, as one of the world's most efficient agricultural producers, we can be assured that in a fairer and more open market for agricultural products our farmers without any doubt will be able to secure continually improved export sales. Further, the development of fairer and more predictable rules in agricultural trade will help reduce the boom-bust cycle in that trade which has previously been exacerbated by the pricing and production policies of the major countries. The fact that the Cairns Group has worked together so well over the difficult period since Montreal has established once and for all, if anybody were in any doubt, that that group is here to stay. It will continue to be a central force in the agricultural negotiations, through which we now have to convert the principles agreed at Geneva into practical application.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is it a fact that the Premier of Tasmania, Hon. Robin Gray, asked the Federal Government on 13 February to cooperate with his Government to establish joint guidelines in relation to the proposed establishment of a pulp mill at Wesley Vale in Tasmania? Does the Minister now admit that his response to that request in refusing to cooperate with the Tasmanian Government was a contributing factor in the ultimate failure of the project because, in the absence of this information, the Tasmanian Government was unable to set requirements to meet Federal demands?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot recall 13 February being an operative date in these discussions. I will have to check that. As far as I can recall, the Premier of Tasmania insisted through the months of negotiations that the Tasmanian Government was the appropriate body to handle environmental guidelines. The difficulty faced by the Government in looking at those guidelines, and in evaluating my response, of course, as Senator Walters put it, was that the Tasmanian Government showed at the end of the day that it had no political will and no environmental sense. It set down a series of guidelines. I think they would have been fairly close to the mark.
—Noranda said that you did not tell the truth.

—I will get on to that in just a second. I am very glad that Senator Archer has referred to Noranda and to telling the truth. I am delighted, Senator Archer, and I will refer to that. If we look at the contribution made by Tasmania we will see that first of all it sets down a series of guidelines which were in some respects tough and in other respects not as tough as I would have liked them. Nonetheless, it was a reasonable place at which to begin. The difficulty for the Tasmanian Government was that, as soon as it was confronted by a big, arrogant and powerful multinational which said that it did not like that and would not wear it, it backed off. Premier Gray said for months that these guidelines would not be changed and repeated that the day before he changed them. But what happened was that he backed off. He did not back off in little way; he backed right off. The guidelines were torn up and they started to process them again.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Treasurer, Paul Keating, said when we met with the company only a few months ago, `Look, you saw the Tasmanian Government coming four miles off through a pea soup fog. You knew you could run over them, but you can't run over us'. That is exactly what happened. All we did was inform the company of what was a pretty obvious fact, and that was that the claim that the technology which was to be used in this mill was in some way the best in the world was nonsense. In the first meeting we had with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and Paul Keating, we were able to get the company to admit that it could go further than the Tasmanian guidelines. That took no time at all.

I also want to point out that when one refers to Noranda-and Senator Archer's claim about lies, Mr President-it is not the case that the Commonwealth Government got involved in this at the last minute. On 11 July last year the Commonwealth met with the company and told it what we expected. On 7 December last year the Commonwealth and the Tasmanian Government, in partnership, sent a joint letter to Noranda and North Broken Hill Peko Ltd. In that letter we listed 85 points where the environmental impact statement (EIS) was either inadequate or where points had not been addressed at all. What did Noranda choose to do about that? It chose to ignore it. Noranda was always accustomed to getting its own way. What happened here was that it met a government determined to see that, if the mill were to proceed, it would proceed only under environmental guidelines that protected Bass Strait. That was always the Commonwealth's basic position, and it remains so.

So far as the future is concerned, this afternoon at 4 o'clock Senator Button, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and I are having a meeting to look at the process by which the Commonwealth can resolve the difficulties over pulp mills because we have a number of proposals coming up in the next few years. We will deal with that this afternoon.

As to what we said to the company about what the guidelines should be, let me give a couple of examples. We told the company straight away that the idea that it could only go up to 40 per cent chlorine substitution was nonsense. We proved to them straight away that in Sweden hardwood mills exist with 90 per cent chlorine substitution. That, of course, is the crucial element in producing the organochlorins that were to be dumped in Bass Strait. It was not hard to show where these guidelines were rotten. They were rotten right through. I am proud of the fact that the Government knocked them back and any company that thinks it can ignore the Government in the future I hope will have learned a proper lesson.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. As the Government, as the Minister has said, told Noranda what was required as early as last June, can the Minister now give us detailed guidelines of what is required by the Federal Government for such a mill to be set up?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that the answer was there, but, to repeat what the Prime Minister said a couple of days ago, it would be ridiculous to expect to give total guidelines for every mill. It would be pretty obvious, even to a moron, that when we examine pulp mill proposals the different product that goes in affects the effluent that comes out. The method of disposal will also vary from site to site. It is possible therefore to draw up guidelines, in the broad. It is not possible to make guidelines for every mill under every circumstance straight away. We would not attempt to do that. We will, however, address the process, and that is why I will meet with the other relevant Ministers this afternoon. We wish to attract industry. Unlike the Opposition, however, we will not do so at any price.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook. In view of the catastrophic effects of the Alaskan oil spill disaster-and I particularly draw the Minister's attention to an article by Mary Anne Gwinn in Saturday's Canberra Times which describes the horrific effects on many of the native birds in the area-has the Government done anything to ensure that Australia's procedures to deal with such a disaster are the best possible? Can the Minister explain what kind of planning is in place to deal with oil spills in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March an Exxon shipping company supertanker, the Exxon Valdez, ran aground while loading at the southern terminal of the trans-Alaskan pipeline. Up to 50 million litres or 300,000 barrels of oil is reported to have been spilled. Press articles have reported criticism for the initial response to efforts being made to clean up the spill. The Alaskan Department of Environmental Conservation has been reported as saying that `the initial response was inadequate and did not match the planned outline response measures to be taken in a spill'. I understand that aerial chemical spraying has failed to disperse the oil slick. They are waiting for calmer weather conditions to prevail. I am aware of the article in the Canberra Times and other reports referred to by Senator Devereux relating to damage to the marine environment and to sea life in general. It is not a simple matter of oil in the water; it is also a major environmental hazard.

ANSWER.PARA: We have two national plans to combat any event of this nature in Australia. We have the national plan to combat pollution of sea by oil, which is a plan held by and operated by the Department of Transport and Communications. It has a cooperative Federal-State component. It is a contingency plan for where there might be major oil spills off the Australian coast. Under the national plan, State and Commonwealth committees work to a series of administrative guidelines that are worked out in advance in territorial waters. At various points around the Australian coast they stockpile dispersants and equipment so that, in the event of a spill, they are near at hand and can be accessed readily. The committees have a strategy, first, to contain and, secondly, to coordinate and clean up, and provide technical and logistical support where necessary. The second plan is the marine oil spill action plan, which is an industry based plan. It initiates action for any spillage, not just major spillages. It, of course, interacts with the Federal plan.

There is a third consideration in all of this in that, where oil exploration and drilling and production are going on on the continental shelf, proposals for authorisation to drill or to produce are put to me under the Commonwealth Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act. All such proposals have to be accompanied by environmental assessments of the work that is being done and guarantee of non-major disturbance. Those plans are approved as site specific plans in the particular location where the drilling or the production might be going to occur.

In view of this massive disaster-I think everyone would agree that that is a correct description of it-an interdepartmental committee for combating oil spills has been inaugurated. It is chaired by the Department of Transport and Communications. It will be reviewing the events that caused the Alaskan spill to get out of hand. Any lessons for us from that will be applied off the Australian coast. That is consistent with the strategy that this Government has adopted where major events of this nature occur. Honourable senators will remember that last year, after the Piper Alpha explosion in the North Sea, I reported to the Senate that we had set up a committee to review the proceedings of evidence as adduced before the inquiry into the Piper Alpha disaster. The industry, along with the States, has participated on that committee. Indeed, industry has foreshadowed some changes to its procedures because of that. That is a very heartening sign. It is consistent with what we are doing here to prevent the replication of a devastation such as the Alaskan one occurring in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce would know that the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) draft report on international trade in services states that service industry deficiencies must be tackled as `a matter of urgency' if international competitiveness of Australian industry is to be achieved. Does the Minister agree? If so, what urgent action is the Government taking to progress its much talked about but little achieved agenda for micro-economic reform?

—I have seen reports of the IAC draft report. At this stage I have not studied the report in detail. I certainly agree with Senator Lewis's summary of that IAC report. It is very difficult to generalise about service industries. For example, tourism is a service industry that has been extraordinarily successful. I am sure the Minister, Senator Richardson, and I would agree that not everything that could be done in respect of tourism, particularly as to long-term infrastructure, was in place. These are on-going matters. That is true in respect of a whole range of issues in the service industry sector.
—Including Mascot airport.

—Including Mascot airport, I agree. Senator Lewis puts forward a good example. Well done; a gold elephant for that one. There are a whole range of service industries which are very important, such as health services and insurance, which require addressing across different portfolios in the Government. They have been the subject of conferences with the trade in services group of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and have been considered in a variety of contexts. I cannot add anything to that at this stage. Of course the Government realises the urgency of these matters, and has done for some time; but one will not achieve results overnight with developing trade in services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has acknowledged that the Government has realised the urgency of these matters for some time. The question I was asking the Minister was as to what the Government intended to do about them. I draw the Minister's specific attention to one paragraph regarding cabotage arrangements affecting coastal shipping and domestic aviation, in which it says, on page 12:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government's program for micro-economic reform will fall well short of achieving its full potential while barriers and impediments to efficient performance in these domestic service industries continue to impose a debilitating burden on the rest of the economy.
It goes on in relation to transport and communications to say:

Recent government initiatives, when implemented, should make some progress towards improving competitiveness in the transport and communications industries, but these initiatives are too narrowly focused on these industries themselves.
Is the Government ever going to get around to attending to these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it extraordinary that Senator Lewis puts a supplementary question in that form. He would know, if he reads the newspapers at all, that the issue of coastal shipping, the issue of the waterfront and so on are high priorities on the Government's agenda. If he will contain his soul in patience--
—Six years and you have not done anything,

—Senator Boswell interjects to say that it has taken us six years to do something. Need I remind Senator Boswell again that in the last 39 years his coalition was in government for 30 years and in that whole time it did nothing about any of these issues. That is why they are in the public domain at present-because of lazy government over 30 years. Now those issues are being addressed by this Government. Those opposite made no decisions on those issues for 30 years.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of noise from the Opposition because what I am saying is very unpalatable. As I said in the Senate the other day, the first time those opposite had to front up to an issue and to come in here and vote on the issue of deregulation of the domestic wheat market, Opposition senators went to water in the face of their National Party colleagues. They came up with a shonky, second rate compromise, because they went to water on that issue. That points to the fact that the Opposition, which did nothing for 30 years, still has not learnt. Opposition members have still the same level of guts and intellectual integrity that they had when in government-absolutely none. The first time they have an issue they have to confront, such as wheat deregulation, they run away from it. Senator Boswell came into the Senate the other day-and I sometimes characterise the Opposition as the 1960s show-and defended regulations of the sugar market which were made in 1915. Senator Boswell is a 1915 show, not a 1960s show. Every time an issue comes before the Opposition it runs away from it, just as it did in government. So it ill becomes Senator Lewis to come up with this stroppy stuff, asking when we are going to do something. These issues are all on the Government's agenda.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the present Opposition do about the airlines? We made a decision about it; those opposite did nothing. No amount of noise will substitute for policy and guts; honourable members opposite can keep on making their noises because they will not fool anybody by noise.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Further to my question of 5 April, I draw the Minister's attention to his reply and ask him, in respect of material taken by Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd out of Coolangubra, what is the subtle difference between Harris- Daishowa quarantining this material in its yard and stockpiling-which the Minister denies is occurring? If Harris-Daishowa has not extracted the material for export and stockpiled in anticipation of export permission-which export is prohibited by section 6c of the export licence-what does the Minister think Harris-Daishowa extracted the material for? Does the Minister believe that the material will deteriorate over time, with exposure to weather conditions, so that by the time any agreement is made between the Commonwealth and State governments it will be fit only for pulpwood? Is the Minister aware that compartment 1323 of Coolangubra State Forest, to which my original question referred, is off the Kansonah access road, off Wog Way, and not down the Bondi Link area, as the Minister's reply indicates? Will the Minister admit he has made an error in his reply? Finally, does the Minister realise that the logs lying on Apogee Road were the result of New South Wales Forestry Commission roading and not the result of wind damage, as is stated, and that this is a clear violation of section 5c of the licence? A local resident whose property is located near Apogee Road told me, some one hour ago, that logging commenced yesterday morning at 7 a.m.
—Order! That is a statement, not a question.
—I am asking the Minister for a comment on this in view of the fact that negotiations are currently proceeding between the State and Commonwealth governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a series of questions; let me try to pick my way through all of them and answer them, if I can. The first is a question of semantics-what is the difference between `quarantine' and `stockpile'. I think the word `stockpile' comes from a statement made by the head forester in the Eden area in a television or radio interview he gave and of which transcripts have been furnished to my office. That statement has been relied upon for a number of comments made publicly, subsequently, by environ- mental spokespersons. I have insisted that the right description of what has happened is quarantining. I take it that one stockpiles in the interests of some time in the future using the thing stockpiled, but quarantine suggests-I draw this inference from my administration of the Quarantine Act-that one may hold the thing for inspection but may not admit it, or one may according to whether or not it is later found to be acceptable. I do not believe there is any mystery about that because in previous answers I have said the material is being held and it may or may not be used, and in fact I have even said it may never be used.

ANSWER.PARA: Section 6c is a section that I have inserted in the woodchip licence conditions. I inserted it for the first time for this specific interim set of conditions when I issued the woodchip export licence on 29 December last year. It did not appear before. It appears specifically because I want to have the power-not that I do not have it, but I want that power to be explicit-to control the use of material from areas on the interim list of the World Heritage Commission which I have statutory obligations to do something about. The purpose of section 6c is not to deny ever cutting in a World Heritage area or an interim listed area; it is to provide that if we decide to cut in those areas we must have regard to the sensitivities of the region because it is one found by the World Heritage Commission to have outstanding values. Cutting would be carried out only in certain circumstances and then with specific regard to the protection of those values.

The honourable senator further asked: why did Harris-Daishowa extract-and the word `extract' is pregnant in this context because it has been contorted to mean other things-the particular wood? To the best of my knowledge, Harris-Daishowa did not extract in the classic sense in which that term may be used. The cut was authorised by the New South Wales Forestry Commission. The Minister responsible for that Commission is the Minister for Natural Resources in New South Wales, Ian Causley. This is not a matter over which I have any jurisdiction or control. If it involves export, I would have; if it does not involve export, I do not have. It is something I would prefer did not happen, but he has the constitutional authority. He tells me that this action was taken so as to maintain the supply of sawlogs to Bombala sawmill; otherwise people would be put out of work in that area.

As far as the honourable senator's other questions are concerned, it so happens that I have a supplementary answer to make to the question that was asked by her last week. If the honourable senator checks, she will find that the `pinks', the Daily Hansard and the Weekly Hansard, are all the same; they are all in accord on this. I said something to the effect-and I am relying on memory now-that I could not confirm or I was not sure of the exact circumstances but it may be or I think it is this, and then I proceeded to answer. My supplementary answer, which I will put down in about seven minutes time, the Senate willing, is that I can answer the specific questions to which the honourable senator referred. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for immediate action by the Government to introduce reforms which will ensure that the Australian waterfront becomes efficient and productive instead of being a national burden and impediment to internationally competitive economic activities.

We on this side of the chamber believe very much in meritocracy but on this occasion I have to be grateful for the numbers. It is indeed a privilege to speak to an urgency motion in these terms because honourable senators, and indeed, the Australian community, will be aware that we are now almost two-thirds of the way through a so-called historic third term of the Hawke Government. This was to be the term that put the finishing touches on productivity and efficiency in the workplace: in other words, the era of micro-economic reform. Never mind that the Government has had six years for the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and his colleagues to address the issues, whatever that means. I would have thought it would be `return to sender' by now. Quite clearly, even at the time the current Inter-State Commission report was commissioned there would have been ample opportunity for the Government to have addressed the issues. Indeed, it did what it always does: it employed that time-honoured political strategy of keeping the ball in the air.

The Government has now had a further two years in which to have these matters exhaustively considered, and we now are faced with the crunch. This is the acid test. Never mind that inordinate cost burdens have been imposed on employers, manufacturers and producers by giant sheltered workshops in telecommunications, rail and shipping. Never mind that the Government realises the absolute impossibility of conditions on the waterfront, where all the major parties are aware of the need for change. In fact, let me remind the Senate of what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had to say in October of last year, as reported in the Australian of 14 November:

I can think of no reasonable argument why employers and unions in our manufacturing and export sectors must adjust to international trading companies while stevedoring and shipping remain shielded . . . We are determined not to shirk the challenges.
At the same time the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said, `It is important that Australia not be prevented from further processing of raw materials by the high cost of coastal shipping'.

That was the rhetoric, but of course the reality was that when it came to the crunch and the Cabinet had to consider the issue it baulked at the first hurdle. We had the disgraceful spectacle of people such as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) wandering into this chamber and announcing in very strong terms that there would be no change to the employment conditions as a result of that report, that there would be no competition in terms of employment for coastal shipping. Indeed, Senator Ray was pursuing the matter in the way that he always approaches these things. In other words, if there is an opportunity to be honest and reasonable at no political cost, then he is quite prepared to be in it, but when it comes to something critical like a third runway that might impact on the Government's re- election chances, every time he goes for the politically expedient. As a result, we have had no response to the Industries Assistance Commission report.

What have we had now in relation to the Inter-State Commission report? I do not think anyone could disagree with the diagnosis that is made in that report. It is quite clear that for many years the Waterside Workers Federation, perhaps one of the most intractable and selfish unions in this country, has regarded itself as beyond the law. Certainly it has taken advantage of every opportunity to abuse its monopoly power. In every respect it has put its self-interest ahead of the national interest. As a result we have had all those matters so eloquently identified in the rorts task force, described by Senator Parer as 64 ways to sink an industry. Indeed, that is absolutely right. This industry is sinking fast. We have people working, if that is what it can be called, for many fewer hours than is the average in this country, earning much more money than their skills warrant. We have a problem compounded by ineffective management, we have inordinately high levels of industrial disputation, and we have an industry that is cocooned from the real world. As a result, with no competition there is no incentive for efficiency, no productivity resulting, and, accordingly, we have an industry that is a national disgrace.

The Inter-State Commission, in my view, made the right diagnosis, and with one crucial-and I think ultimately flawed-exception came up with the right prognosis. But, and it is a very big but, as a result of that flaw, instead of a radical change of lifestyle for the patient the real recommendation is that it should undergo cosmetic surgery. All of us have known for many years that the waterfront has been the sick man of Australian industry. It has been protected in all sorts of outrageous ways. There are solutions that do involve biting the bullet, but essentially they involve injecting some manner of competition into the industry.

Perhaps the most critical question that the Inter-State Commission had to address was whether it would do away with the manner of employment-those time honoured arrangements that had resulted in pooling and levy systems that were quite inimical to the public interest, that resulted in people working almost when they felt like it, working perhaps for half the time for which they were paid. Indeed, the Inter-State Commission did come up with the right solution. It recommended a move to enterprise based employment. We regard that as critically important because that means that decisions will be made at a local level by employees, not by unions on their behalf. Accordingly, there will be much more incentive for a realistic and constructive relationship to be developed between employer and employee. We will see workers who are motivated, workers who have incentive, and workers who believe in producing a fair day's work for a fair day's pay. We simply do not have those things at the present time, as a result of a system that is driven by union domination, which is not ultimately in the interests of the work force.

Although the work force has been reduced from something like 26,000 to about 7,000 as a result of the permanent employment arrangements introduced some 10 or 12 years ago, there are still something of the order of 7,240 Waterside Workers Federation members. Some 53.51 per cent of those workers are over 50 and one-third are over 55. Less than one-tenth of the work force is under 35. In Sydney there have been no new recruits to the industry since 1974. There are many waterside workers who have forgotten what real work is all about. This report recommends that there be an immediate movement towards significant reductions in numbers of the order of 3,000 over three years but with a recruitment campaign that would involve taking on younger members, injecting new blood of the order of 1,000 over that period-what we regard as a sensible balance that will bring about at least some reduction in the disgraceful overmanning and featherbedding that has dominated the industry for so long. That is a critical recommendation. If we can find a way to enterprise based employment, then we will be well on the way to bolstering productivity levels from the disgracefully low point at the present time.

The critical flaw in this plan is the critical flaw that bedevils this Government's whole approach to real issues. It stalls for time. If we look at industries like telecommunications, which are absolutely exploding around the world, we find that most of the major industrialised countries are introducing competition; they are privatising their telecommunications and postal sectors. This country is locked firmly into the monopoly mould. We have given the rest of the world five years start already and this is yet another example of why the Government, I am sure, will baulk at the prospect of real change. This report recommends that there should be negotiations between all of the parties before any real movement towards enterprise based employment occurs. What that means is that the Waterside Workers Federation will have a veto over reform in this critical area. As long as that is the case, the national interest can never prevail. I regard that as a very sad state of affairs because in many ways the report does come up with some very enlightened recommendations. Certainly if adopted in full it would result in something like a 27 per cent improvement in the levels of overmanning. If productivity arrangements were introduced, there would be perhaps a 40 per cent increase.

There is a long way to go, but I think the report provides a prescription which most Australians could agree with. The recommendation for the employment of casual labour at peak periods is similarly a very important matter. The danger in all of this is that there will be no substantive progress, that this will simply serve as yet another opportunity for the matter to be put off until after the next Federal election. Never mind that it is less than two years since the last election. What this Government is all about at the moment is keeping that ball in the air, ensuring that it does not have to get offside with any of the major players. One would have thought that, with all the enlightenment that Mr Kelty is supposed to have brought to the industrial relations arena, he would have been in heated agreement with the rest of industry, with all of those commentators, and indeed, I have no doubt, in their heart of hearts, with all the Ministers in the Government. Perhaps even the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) almost qualifies these days, after his baptism of fire in the communications area.

Indeed, it is tragic to report that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) response has been almost entirely negative. The reason for that is that it is much more concerned about any loss of union membership when it is striving for single industry-based unions. In other words, its cooperatist approach, its blueprint for change, its grand strategy might be threatened by actually having diversity in competition in this vital area, especially if enterprise based workers took the view that they did not need to be strangled by a union and if, indeed, they were prepared to work hard, develop a healthy and constructive approach with their employers and started working overtime and at weekends without, as happens now-as Senator Parer has so graphically demonstrated-all of these rorts. Most of the time is spent in negotiating rather than working, in deciding how much will be paid in advance. Then there is the darg system under which people go home after doing a certain rostered amount of work. If that is a form of productivity I do not know what the term means.

It is quite clear that enormous progress needs to be made. Yet the ACTU, when it had the opportunity, simply deserted notions of efficiency and productivity. That tells us a fair bit about what we can expect about awards restructuring in due course. The likelihood is that we will see wage increases first; we will see some token gestures in the direction of award restructuring and productivity gains but, at the end of the day, our productivity levels will continue to languish at the bottom of the international league table.

It is a tragic state of affairs that this country should be held to ransom by a very selfish union; one that is not in any way interested in the national well-being; one that has dominated an industry riddled with monopoly practices; one that has transformed blackmail into an art form and that ultimately is being aided and abetted by the trade union movement. That is the challenge for this Government. To date we have been met with a deafening silence. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, pathetically talks about addressing the issue and somehow promises that we can expect some progress. We did not get any comfort at all from Senator Button's response. The need for immediate action remains. Those reforms are vital. If we are to have an efficient and productive waterfront, then these recommendations will need to be adopted but not as part of some union negotiating deal. They will be adopted because gradualism has failed; because the way ahead is clear.

There is nothing magical about these recommendations. They are blindingly obvious to all people other than the members and supporters of this Government, which seems to be much more interested in delaying progress towards real change. Indeed, it simply pacifies those on whom it seems to count for electoral assistance. That is the last thing that this country wants. I am sure that the Australian community cannot look forward to any real progress in this area unless there is a change of government. I hope that today we will, at the very least, have a recognition of the validity of the recommendations of that report without any linkage towards this usual negotiating tactic. If we do, then at least there might be a glimmer of hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The achievement of a more productive and reliable waterfront is a major priority within the Hawke Labor Government's micro-economic agenda. In fact, it has been an aspiration throughout our term of office. Waterfront reform, which is necessary, will complement and reinforce reforms being pursued right across other areas of the economy. We see it as essential to enhancing the international competitiveness of Australia's agricultural, mining and manufacturing industries. We will be giving immediate consideration, within the terms of this motion with which we have no particular quarrel, to the recommendations contained in the report of the Inter-State Commission (ISC). The ISC's report is, of course, the culmination of over two years work, including very extensive public hearings and investigations into all aspects of the waterfront industry. It makes a very comprehensive series of recommendations having, obviously, far reaching implications. They deserve, and they will receive, detailed and active effective consideration by the Government. Rather than using up limited time to talk in detail about the recommendations of the ISC report, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a five-page summary of the detailed content of the report which I have shown to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The summary read as follows-
INTER-STATE COMMISSION WATERFRONT INVESTIGATION REPORT: SUMMARY OF PROPOSED THREE YEAR INDUSTRY REFORM PLAN
Implementation
Three person independent implementation authority to oversight the plan and supervise the release of government contributions
-full time chairperson and two part time members
-small secretariat

An ``in principle'' agreement between the Federal Government, ACTU, stevedoring employers and unions for initiating and progressing the stevedoring and international container depots elements of reform plan.
Under the agreement release of Government financial contributions to be contingent upon satisfactory progress with all aspects of the industry plan by the other parties.
Stevedoring Industry
Change from present industry based employment arrangements to enterprise based employment arrangements within 3 years.
Introduction of improved workplace practices following individual workplace assessments. Federal Government to provide up to $500,000 on dollar for dollar basis with industry to fund assessments.

Introduction of new job structures based on skills acquisition and demonstrated competency incorporated in an integrated career path. Federal Government assistance of $100,000 for skills reviews in selected workplaces.

Development of new training program to meet the competency requirements of new job classifications. Federal Government contribution of $2 million for industry training facilities and $6 million towards cost of on-the-job and off the job training.
Special recruitment program to rejuvenate the stevedoring industry with 1000 new recruits under the age of 30 being brought into the industry over three years.
Removal of ``gangway watchmen'' classification from the industry involving redundancy of some 200 gangway watchmen.

Special retirement and redundancy package to enable 3,000 employees to leave the industry over three years. Federal Government grants of $145 million to meet half the redundancy cost with stevedoring companies meeting other half.
Use of supplementary workforces to meet peak labour requirements and contracting out of maintenance work.
Termination of existing cross subsidisation of stevedoring labour in small ports.
Development of integrated labour forces in small ports with coverage by port authority unions or introduction of commercial stevedoring labour pools in small ports where this is more efficient.
Renegotiation within six months of key awards and industrial agreements to give effect to restructuring proposals.
Continuation of joint ventures but with greater regard to their obligations under the Trade Practices Act.
International Container Depots
The elimination of existing industrial constraints on international container depot-operations and introduction of single union coverage at individual workplaces.
Redevelopment of container depot productivity schemes to make them more relevant to individual workplaces.
Bulk Terminals
Introduction of enterprise based labour arrangements with WWF agreeing to withdraw its coverage of bulk loading operations.
New South Wales Government examine ISC consultancy report on coal terminals with view to action to improve coal terminal performance.
Industrial Relations

Industry examine whether guidelines for handling safety disputes can be improved and Federal Government Departments examine whether present industry safety code can be developed for enactment as legislation.
Implementation authority arrange for study of safety and risk management.
Enterprise managers and employees should examine scope offered by certified agreements for introduction of workplace based agreements.
Employers and employees should commit themselves to adhere to agreed disciplinary and dispute settlement procedures.
Insertion in awards of stand-down provisions that can be put into effect within 24 hours.
Port Authorities
State and Territory governments should review current allocation of port functions with a view to a more appropriate balance between Departmental and port authority responsibilities.

Port authorities should be statutory authorities rather than private companies but their structure should be changed to give them greater autonomy with governmental strategic oversight being through corporate plans and performance targets.
Port authority legislation should be reviewed to provide clear port charters and port authorities should be required to publish corporate plans.
Port authority board members should be appointed on the basis of individual expertise.
Each port authority should have a standing port advisory body comprising representatives of the main groups with an interest in port operations.
The Association of Australian Port and Marine Authorities (AAPMA) should propose to the Australian Transport Advisory Council guidelines for the valuation of port assets.
State and Territory governments should establish economic rates of return on port assets and review them annually.
Port authority annual reports should contain sufficient detail to provide a clear indication of performance.

Port authorities should grant leases and licences for the shortest term consistent with stable operation of individual facilities and should keep under review the possibility of providing facilities to enable entry of other operators.
Port authorities should scrutinise the accounts of monopoly port service providers to ensure prices charged are justified.

The AAPMA should further develop standard guidelines for port pricing and port authorities should take immediate action to reduce reliance on wharfage charges. Prices should be set to provide an economic rate of return on market value of assets used.

State and Territory governments should consider the impact of the ISC plan on port authority staffing levels and consider the need for special retirement/redundancy programs to facilitate restructuring.
Importers and Exporters
The Implementation Authority should monitor and assist the new shipper bodies.
Trade Practices
Federal Government should ensure the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) has adequate resources to develop expertise in transport areas and waterfront in particular.
Effective liaison arrangements should be established between Implementation Authority and Trade Practices Commission to facilitate implementation of waterfront changes.
TPC should consider merit of third party intervention under Industrial Relations Act when there are possible trade practices implications.
The TPC should give consideration to action under the Trade Practices Act if satisfactory progress not made in area of industry levies and container depots.
The business activities of port authorities should be subject to the Trade Practices Act or equivalent State/Territory legislation.
Land Transport Access
State and Territory Governments should ensure full economic and social appraisals of urban access links to ports are carried out.
The Federal Government should conduct a review of funding priorities for road connections to major ports.
Port authorities and user organisations should continue to address land transport operational issues.
Improved management structures should be developed for interstate rail services to facilitate improvements to inter system co-ordination and marketing of rail services.
National Communications Network
The Implementation Authority should monitor the introduction and application of EDI techniques in the shore based sector.
Performance Indicators and Statistics
