The Implementation Authority should have responsibility for co-ordinating the provision of nationally required statistics and indicators in collaboration with the waterfront industry.
Ship Services
Port authorities should review their guidelines on towage requirements.
The TPC should consider whether there is a need to review its existing authorisation of tug operator agreements.
An industry plan for Australian shipping should make provision for changes to work practices to enable reduced tug crewing levels.
AAPMA should review pilotage exemption requirements/restrictions with objective of developing more uniform national standards that give due weight to both navigational and economic requirements.
State and Territory Governments should consider the merits of establishing pilots' co-operatives.
Federal Government should review the basis on which light dues are currently charged.
Ancillary Matters
The Federal Government should review current cargo documentation procedures with a view to streamlining and standardising them.
Port authorities should be subject to sales tax on stevedoring equipment if they are in competition with stevedoring companies.
The Implementation Authority should examine the scope for introducing procedures for releasing goods on minimum customs documentation.
Stevedoring equipment should be exempted from the single-voyage permit requirements of the Navigation Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) will be bringing a submission on this report to Cabinet in May-not in the never-never, not after the election is over, but in May this year-and the Government's decisions will be announced as soon as possible thereafter. Prior to his submission to Cabinet, the Minister will be consulting with key industry participants on the ISC's recommendations and, indeed, in accordance with those recommendations. We expect initial discussions with stevedoring employers and unions to be held very shortly. Many of the ISC's recommendations, particularly those related to the management and operation of port authorities, are the direct responsibility of the State and Northern Territory Governments. The Minister has already written to responsible State and Territory Ministers asking that they give priority consideration to those recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the union movement is concerned, which attracted the rhetorical indignation of Senator Alston, while the union movement has, in the person who is head of the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF) and, indirectly, through the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), indicated some reservations about certain aspects of the report, it has confirmed acceptance of the need for waterfront reform. It has also confirmed its willingness to participate in the Government's consultative process, which I have just outlined. It has not deserted notions of productivity and efficiency, as Senator Alston claims. There is a great deal of consciousness about the need to move in this particular area, just as there is in the Government itself. We are committed to achieving considerable and effective reform on the Australian waterfront and we will see through the changes necessary to improve efficiency and reliability in this vital area of the economy.

A lot of the criticism in Senator Alston's opening tirade-I have no doubt that this is a theme to be repeated over the next 2 1/2 hours-was of the Government for its alleged action in this area over the six years that we have been in government. I do not accept for a moment that anything the Government has done over this period could be construed even remotely as inaction or paying inattention or demonstrating an unwillingness to come to grips with this issue. What the course of action which I will now retail in loving detail does demonstrate is that the Government, throughout this process, has been acutely conscious of the difficulty of achieving extensive structural reform in this area. Because of the clash of interests involved, the extraordinary complexity of the problem, the enormous numbers of different players, parties and different levels of government involved, we are very conscious indeed of the counter-productivity of seeking to ram reform down the throats of people who basically not only want to reject it but also are in a position to disrupt that process.

It is tremendously important that as much consensus as possible be achieved before the final crunch point is reached. That is the process that we have been going through. It is a process which began back in July 1984, a few months after we were elected, when the Federal Government sponsored the shore based shipping cost seminar involving waterfront industry participants and their clients. It was an exercise designed to review the performance of the waterfront industry. Following that seminar, and in response to problems identified at it, in September 1984 the Government established the industry taskforce on shore based shipping costs under the chairmanship of Mr Ian Webber, Managing Director of Mayne Nickless Ltd. That task force examined all aspects of the waterfront industry, with membership including representatives from union and employer organisations, port authorities, shipping and user interests. It presented interim reports to the Government in December 1984 and December 1985. In June 1986 it presented its final report recommending a series of fundamental changes to be progressed in all sectors of the waterfront industry. In July, in response to that and to the increasing attention focused on the performance of the stevedoring sector, the stevedoring employers and the major unions established the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee as part of a stevedoring awards settlement exercise to examine all aspects of improving stevedoring productivity.

In December 1986 the Government announced its waterfront strategy in response to issues raised by the task force which had reported a few months earlier. The strategy included an investigative reference to the Inter-State Commission to examine all aspects of waterfront industry on a much wider canvas than that which had notionally been covered by the task force and to develop, with the participation of many more players than had been involved in the task force, a fully integrated plan to improve the efficiency and reliability of the waterfront. That strategy also involved-and in fact it was quite central to it-integrating the activity of four different industry groups, identifying and where possible addressing problems as they went in their separate areas of responsibility. It was not just a matter of preparing a report. It was a matter of a dynamic process here being set in train to pick up and shake each of the areas that had been identified in outline terms in the task force and to do something about getting change along the way, and that has happened.

Those four groups were the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee, to which I have already referred, which examined employment-related issues in the stevedoring sector; secondly, the Industry Committee, reviewing impediments arising from commercial practices, inadequate documentation and communication systems; thirdly, the Importer/Exporter Panel, representing the concerns of waterfront client industries and monitoring progress of the strategy from their perspective; and finally, the Marine and Ports Group and the Railway Group of the Australian Transport Advisory Council, aimed at progressing initiatives to address rail and port authority issues in consultation with the State and Territory governments That was all set in train in 1986.

By September of 1987 the Inter-State Commission presented its interim report advising of progress being made by the various industry groups established pursuant to that strategy. In October-November 1987 the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee concluded the first stage of its work program reviewing management and work practices at the local level, with the settlement of agreements between stevedoring employers and major unions under the second tier of the March 1987 national wage case decision. In February 1988 the Structural Adjustment Committee of the Cabinet met with all the major participants in the waterfront strategy to review its progress.

Through March to July 1988 the Inter-State Commission conducted its first round of public hearings in all capital cities, receiving some 80 submissions from interested parties. In August 1988 the ISC released its preliminary report establishing the basic final agenda for development of the integrated waterfront reform plan. From November 1988 to February of this year the ISC conducted its second round of public hearings, receiving some 60 additional submissions. In December 1988, in the middle of that period, the Structural Adjustment Committee of Cabinet again met with the major participants in the waterfront strategy process to review progress. Finally, in April 1989 the ISC published its final report, which is before us today, providing recommendations aimed at addressing all aspects of the waterfront industry comprehensively with a focus on fundamental structural change in the stevedoring sector.

I might add that while all this was happening at the governmental level, a lot was happening on the union front in terms of the unions demonstrating their willingness to generate themselves those improvements in efficiency and productivity which everyone is now fussing about. Early in 1987 agreement was reached between a container depot operator in Melbourne and the Waterside Workers Federation on the introduction of a performance-based productivity scheme. That concept was later extended to other WWF container depots. Later in 1987 the Federation announced the establishment of its first joint venture stevedoring operation in Stanley, Tasmania, in an endeavour to improve stevedoring performance in smaller regional ports by the involvement of the operational work force. This has since been followed by similar joint ventures being established in Mackay and Gladstone in Queensland, Newcastle in New South Wales, Geelong in Victoria, Darwin in the Northern Territory and Geraldton in Western Australia. The momentum is being generated, the commitment is there, the action is occurring, and it is all now coming to a head. If it has taken a long time, it is because these issues are relentlessly complex and have to be addressed in a systematic and sensible way, not just rushed at with a great rhetorical bellow like a bull at a gate, in the way that Senator Alston would urge us to follow.

I repeat that the Government has put restructuring of the waterfront at the centre of its current micro-economic reform agenda and we will see reforms through. We have already established a track record in regard to the crude oil industry deregulation, aviation industry deregulation and telecommunications liberalisation. We have delivered and we are delivering. That is to be compared, and compared dramatically and graphically, as Senator Button made clear in Question Time today, with the performance of the Opposition parties during the years that they were in government-and they were in government for 30 of the past 39 years. They have had endless opportunities over that period to reform not only the waterfront, but the coastal shipping industry about which they are also uptight-a reform that we are now addressing in a comprehensive and thorough way. They had ample opportunity not only not to start the two-airline policy, but to bring it to a close much sooner than they did. They had to leave that to us. They had to leave it to us to get a move rational and coherent deregulation of the crude oil industry and to do what we have just succeeded in doing in the context of telecommunications. The Opposition did none of those things during all those years it was in government. Therein lies the rub, the basis on which its credibility must be assessed.

What is the Opposition's policy in regard to the waterfront? It has no constructive policies that we can discern to restructure and revitalise the waterfront. Its approach is just a repetition of divisive and shallow ideology of the kind that we have so often heard. Many of the present underlying problems in the waterfront stretch back to the introduction of containerisation in the late 1960s. Many of the industrial relations attitudes stretch back further than that. The Opposition was in government when containerisation was introduced and it should take responsibility accordingly for many of the difficulties which have become apparent on the waterfront. There were never any serious attempts to address the deep-seated problems of the waterfront until this Government came to power. The Opposition's achievement when in government was to hand the industry over to employers and unions to fix it. It abolished the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority in 1977 and handed over most of its functions to the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour, which now controls employment arrangements in conjunction with the Waterside Workers Federation. It put no strategy in place to ensure that improvements were achieved. What is the Opposition's policy now? The Opposition's Future Directions policy says:
The chaotic situation which still prevails has occurred because of the mass of restrictive trade practices which have vested unions with excessive power.
Its solution is:
Implementation of essential services legislation and our industrial relations policy will achieve greater productivity.

The introduction of essential services legislation in relation to the waterfront is a policy designed manifestly for confrontation and is only likely to result in further disruption to waterfront and shipping services. What we want in this area as elsewhere is less rhetoric, less huff and puff, but some genuine, careful, thoughtful, constructive, thought out, negotiated, consulted action. That is the base that we have been establishing in all our endeavours over the past five or six years which I have retailed in detail. It is the basis on which we will now proceed to implement major reform and to see that reform through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support this urgency motion. In our view, it is indeed a matter of urgency that the Government introduce massive reform on the waterfront along the lines outlined in the Inter-State Commission waterfront investigation report. We would anticipate that these reforms and the rapid changes that they will necessitate will be difficult for and make very heavy demands upon all parties involved. Although we support the motion and the reforms, we do not believe that a wharfie or union bash is the way to begin the process. We say that we should all try to be objective about the realities-attitudinal, industrial and political-of the situation on the waterfront. We all concur in and accept the critical significance of this industry in Australia's present industrial and future industrial development and industrial relations, but we must approach reform cautiously. It is an industry with a bad image. We believe that its bad image has been exaggerated and substantially misrepresented over the past decade or so, and I shall cite some evidence to that effect in a moment. So, in essence, the Democrats' position is certainly that reform is needed urgently, but it must be approached in a thoughtful, deliberate and consultative way, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has just this moment quite correctly emphasised.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Inter-State Commission proposes what we acknowledge as being essentially a very rational strategy. It is worth citing the essential elements of the strategy of reform, which appear in the introductory summary of the report. The report suggests that the intention of the strategy is the elimination of waterfront related transport impediments. `Impediments' is a significant word. This industry is so critical that disruptions within it constitute a major impediment to what happens right across the industrial scene in Australia-particularly the primary and secondary industrial scenes. The report aims at the achievement of a reliable and cost-effective transport system for exporters and importers. Very few things would be more in the national interest than a reliable and cost-effective transport system for exporters and importers.

The report cites seven main elements of an effective strategy. It begins by saying that management is the essential element of this successful strategy. It says that an effective management and well-motivated work force-that of course acknowledges the criticality of good relations between management and labour-is required. The second element in the strategy is a strengthening of the influence of exporters and importers. Thirdly, we need to increase the industry's transparency and accountability-in other words, let us establish what the realities are, let us see what is there rather than speculate. I will mention some of the anomalies in a moment. Fourthly, the report says we must improve industrial relations and dispute settlement procedures; fifthly, ensure a market oriented provision of infrastructure and service; sixthly, remove anti-competitive practices; and, seventhly, establish a body to coordinate and manage the strategy. That strikes us as being an inherently rational start point for making dramatic improvements in a critical industry, and we commend the Opposition for suggesting to the national that this is a matter of urgency.

I would like to discuss, only briefly, four points. First of all, the industry has a bad image. Not only does it have a bad image at home but it also has a bad image internationally. That affects the attitude of our potential traders as to convenience or inconvenience, the possibility or impossibility and the economics of trading with Australia. So the image of this industry is extremely critical. By no means do we deny that the industry has a bad image, but it is probably exaggerated. The pre-1980-82 image of the waterfront was extremely bad. There was a peak in industrial disputation between 1980 and 1982 but since 1983-that is, since the accord-there has been a quite dramatic improvement in the level of industrial disputation on the waterfront. The post-accord period has been a period of positive improvement. In 1985, 312,000 hours were lost on the waterfront. In 1986 there was a 60 per cent improvement, with the numbers of hours lost decreasing to 127,000 hours-still a lot of time. In 1987 there was a 30 per cent improvement, down to 88,700 hours. Things have improved quite dramatically, and as the Minister cited there is a movement towards a positive attitude on the waterfront in recent times. I believe it is important for us to acknowledge those realities.

The report quite correctly cites structural problems and labour inflexibility as being the inherent limitation on the waterfront. There are not only limitations for workers but also limitations for management. The report also cites the fact that most of the management problems are of a clerical nature and that there is vast diversity and repetition in the handling of the paperwork that is associated with the industry. There has been an interest in sustaining that diversity because it has allowed opportunities for delay, hold-up and disruption. It is within that clerical dimension that a lot of the problems lie. If there could be a major move towards standard- isation and towards computerisation of these procedures a good many of the management problems would be resolved. A lot of the communication breakdowns are associated with this diversity or inconsistency and repetition within the clerical dimension of management.

There are major design problems. Our wharves are appallingly designed and it is very difficult to achieve technological advancement because of the inherent historical design limitations which impose a restriction upon major management changes. Worker attitudes within the industry have become inbred. It is an industry where workers are, by comparison with the remainder of the work force, relatively elderly. It is an industry where the bulk of the work force has been in place for decades rather than a few years. There is an entrenchment of attitudes, including the present disposition of resistance to change. Those attitudes reflect historical circumstances and will not be changed overnight. The Commission recommends that there be a flush-out, if you like, of portions of the work force-which is an acknowledgment of the fact that it imposes very serious limitations for change. The proposed generous redundancy plan is an attempt to acknowledge the fact that there is a need to see a lot of new faces and perhaps have a substantial reduction in the number of people actually in the workplace. At the moment the workers are relatively well off and therefore not disposed to leaving the workplace without a fight. There is no doubt that they have, through industrial action and other methods, been successful in creating a very favourable set of circumstances for themselves. Naturally they are reluctant to see these significantly disrupted, as they obviously would be by significant change in the workplace.

The most important thing for us to acknowledge in this debate is that the whole question of the waterfront is tied in with the broader question of the transport industry, which in turn is tied in with some very profound questions that the Australian community has to come to grips with, for example, in relation to the greenhouse effect and energy, and these proposals for change are very opportune. The Australian Democrats would argue that sea transportation must emerge as the primary form of transportation between our major centres of settlement in Australia in the next three to five decades, and that that process of dramatic change must begin now. It is a fact that most Australians live on the seaboard and within close proximity to ports. It is a fact that there is the potential for most of Australia's commodity requirements to be transported by sea. It is a fact that there is a bias towards road transport in Australia, which is expensive, dangerous and polluting. So it is quite appropriate that, at a time when we are beginning to examine the whole question of the greenhouse effect and alternative sources of energy consumption and transportation, there also be an examination of the wharves in relation to the shipping industry.

We must acknowledge the need for review within the transport industry generally, and the wharves are critical to that. The Inter-State Commission has delivered to us a very long-sighted, positive and responsible national strategy. The Democrats suggest that this is a timely opportunity to approach these industrial challenges. We would urge the Opposition particularly not to enter this critical debate with a wharfie bashing or union bashing mentality. We believe that it would be quite inappropriate to do so. In supporting the urgency motion, we simply make a plea to all parties involved to agree with the Inter-State Commission that we are addressing a critical challenge at a critical time. We need to acknowledge its urgency and the demands it places upon all parties involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address my remarks to four separate aspects of Senator Alston's motion. First of all, on Wednesday evening of this week we are contemplating a statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) which will purport to address the economic problems of this country. It will do so, as we all know, by way of providing for a major tax cut to be operative from 1 July this year and by way of agreement with the trade unions-an agreement, no doubt, that will be rubber stamped by the Industrial Relations Commission-for a very significant rise in wage and salary rates in the course of 1989-90. I want to say something about that. I also want to say something about the pressing need, under the circumstances in which Australia finds itself today, for reform of the micro-economy-the individual elements that go to make up the whole of the economy. I want to say something specifically about the waterfront, which has been the particular topic of investigation by the Inter-State Commission for some considerable time now and on which it has just reported. If I have time, I would like to say something very briefly about the human relations aspects of some of these matters, which are often too quickly passed over by those discussing them in purely economic terms.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the overall economic background, at Question Time today Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, agreed with my comment that we have today an economy which is overstretched and which is undergoing a continuing crisis in its balance of payments whereby Australia is getting further and further into debt to foreigners and selling off more and more of the Australian farm. What Senator Button did not say-and it is fair to say that I did not suggest to him in my question that he should-is that a solution to these economic problems is to be found in measures which will render the Australian economy more competitive. We need to address the fact that our productivity performance today is woeful-one could use any number of stronger terms.

It is extraordinary that in these circumstances we have the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia proposing to make a statement on Wednesday evening of this week purporting to address the problems of our economy which will contain nothing, so far as we are presently informed, that relates to the woeful productivity performance of this economy. Rather, the Treasurer appears to be under the impression that we can fix up our productivity problems by, on the one hand, the Treasury handing out a bag of money and, on the other hand, the Industrial Relations Commission, as it is now called, forcing employers to hand out more bags of money by way of higher wages and salaries. Of course, everybody in this country knows that we cannot fix up our problems in this way. The only way we can address those problems is by improving our productivity performance, by lifting our economic game, our productive game. It is a travesty of economic policy that the Treasurer of this country will get up in this Parliament on Wednesday night of this week and ignore those topics.

We need to lift our game by addressing the problems of our major domestic service industries as well as other industries. There is a need for what the economists call micro-economic reform. This Government has taken a great deal of credit-and I think it has been deserved credit-for the reforms it made by way of deregulating the financial sector of the economy. But there it has stopped. It has been frozen into immobility ever since December 1983. Meanwhile, the labour market, which is the greatest single market in this country, has gone totally unreformed, totally untackled by this Government. It is as rigid today as it was five years ago. The waterfront, which is the subject of the Inter-State Commission report to which I referred earlier, is a total shambles. Coastal shipping is an absolute disgrace. In effect, it is a monopoly in the hands of the Australian Seamen's Union. There are land transport inefficiencies, particularly in our State railway systems, whose financial deficits alone amount to something like $3 billion a year. I think in the case of New South Wales alone it is something like $1 billion a year. There are also inefficiencies in communications generally.

In addition, a whole raft of government enterprises-so-called business enterprises; in most cases it is almost a joke to describe them in that way-are still meandering along in their comfortable governmental clothes. As we all know, and even the Government itself has dimly begun to recognise this-although, as Senator Lewis said this afternoon, recognising is not the same thing as doing anything about it-the only solution to that problem is to privatise those government so-called business enterprises. It is only by these measures that we shall tackle the question of raising productivity.

As it happens-and this is very opportune-we have before us today a draft report of the Industries Assistance Commission on international trade in services. This report has a great many very interesting things to say about matters which are totally apposite to the points I have just been making. Let me quote a few paragraphs from that report, to which Senator Lewis also referred earlier this afternoon. For example, the report states:
Because of the crucial importance of these embodied services-
that is to say, services embodied in our exports-
any inefficiencies in their production can seriously undermine the capacity of Australian industries to compete internationally.
The report goes on to detail a list of examples. It states:
In 1988 the Commission-
that is the Industries Assistance Commission-

estimated that a reduction in coastal shipping freight rates to levels in line with those applying internationally would reduce direct costs by some $180 to $460 million in most years, with beneficial flow-on effects that would increase GDP by between $250 million and $550 million.
The report makes a second point:

In an information paper prepared for the inquiry into Government (Non-tax) Charges, the Commission estimated that direct savings from productivity improvements in government rail authorities could amount to $1 billion per year-
I think that is a modest estimate-
and that if these savings were passed on to rail-freight users, GDP could increase by about $1.8 billion annually.
The Commission also quotes a report by the Business Council of Australia and states:

The Business Council of Australia in a recent study suggests that if best international practices were adopted for shipping and related shore transport, the cost of transporting Australian exports and imports would fall by more than $2 billion annually. When these savings were added to a further $1.3 billion the Council estimated to be available from productivity improvements in the operation of railways, the economy-wide effects were increases of more than $6 billion per annum in GDP and 17,000 persons employed.
That is, above those who can now be employed. So it goes on. I have not the time to quote at more length, but it concludes by saying:

However, the implied benefits of removing (these impediments) are so great as to suggest that these heavily regulated and protected service industries are imposing a debilitating burden on the rest of the Australian economy. It is difficult to envisage how increased international competitiveness of Australian industry, which is a fundamental objective of the Government's agenda for micro-economic reform, can be achieved if these service industry deficiencies are not tackled as a matter of urgency.

Let me go on to say something more specifically about the waterfront. We have the report of the Inter-State Commission on its investigation into this matter. The Commission has made estimates, which are that the benefits from tackling the inefficiencies and the monopoly of the control of labour on the waterfront by trade unions would benefit the Australian economy to the extent of $620m per annum. Indeed, what the Commission actually says, in leading up to that view, is that it is convinced that there is `a need for further substantial change to the waterfront industry'. It says that many of the other estimates being provided to it as to the benefits from doing so `were much higher than the Commission's own minimum estimate of $620m per year'. It goes on:

The evidence to the Commission on many matters, such as inefficient work practices, unsatisfactory industrial relations, ineffective supervision and management, high costs and widespread unreliability all indicate that fundamental rather than incremental change is required.

The most obvious example of that, of course, is the overmanning in the industry. The Commission estimates that the work force in the industry can be reduced by about 30 per cent; that is to say, roughly 30 per cent of the work force in the industry is presently either effectively unemployed or inefficiently employed. Other estimates range much higher than that and go as high as 40 per cent.

As Senator Alston has said, the Commission has proposed a plan of campaign, a plan of attack if you like, upon that totally unsatisfactory and unacceptable situation. What has the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia said in response? The General Secretary of that Federation has said-I was engaged in a television debate with him on the subject; so I heard him say it-`This is a recipe for chaos'. He said that, as far as the Waterside Workers Federation is concerned, it is totally unacceptable. What is more, he went on to say, `I have the full authority of Mr Bill Kelty of the ACTU for saying so'. This is the body which we are told has been so reasonably assisting the Government of this country to conduct our affairs for the past six years.

The Commission has a number of salutary things to say about the monopoly powers of trade unions, but the time available to me will not permit me to quote them. However, let me quote just one particular example of the extraordinary situation we have on the waterfront. There is a category of workers on the waterfront known as gangway watchmen. I should say, in fairness to Mr Bull and the Waterside Workers Federation, that these are not members of his union. They are members of, I think, the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia (FMWUA). The Commission says quite flatly at page 212 of its report:
. . . there is no case for the employment of gangway watchmen . . .

It goes on to mention that there are in all 493 of these watchmen on the so-called `A' Register of Waterside Workers and, in addition, `69 watchmen were employed'-I am quoting from page 213-`on the `B' Register as casual employees'. There have already been proposals to reduce the number of these people for whom there is no need at all. The Association of Employers of Waterside Labour has proposed redundancy lump sum payments equivalent to nine months average earnings for each person, which would amount to approximately $32,000 in the case of watchmen in Sydney. In its response to that offer, the FMWUA proposed-I am quoting again from page 213 of the report:

That its members should receive twelve months' average earnings, four weeks' pay in lieu of notice, and four weeks' average earnings for each year of service. In the case of a Sydney watchman with ten years' service, this amounts to a lump sum of approximately $78,000.

Not bad if one can get it. But, of course, that does not come out of thin air; it has to be loaded on to every consumer in this country and, not least, the exporters upon whose effectiveness this country will depend for its survival.

I simply want to say that what we have here is a classic example of a trade union and its representatives confusing their interests and the interests of that union not only with the interests of Australia, which of course is obvious, but also with the interests of other people who might want to get employment in other jobs which could be created in Australia if this waterfront were not weighing down our cost levels to such an extent that export industries are put out of business in the process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with an urgency motion moved by the Opposition in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for immediate action by the Government to introduce reforms which will ensure that the Australian waterfront becomes efficient and productive instead of being a national burden and impediment to internationally competitive economic activities.

Senator Evans, for the Government, has made it very clear that the achievement of a more productive and reliable waterfront is a major priority within the Government's micro-economic agenda. It complements and reinforces reforms being pursued in other areas of the economy and is essential in enhancing the international competitiveness of Australia's agricultural, mining and manufacturing industries. So, the Government does agree that this is a priority. I will show that the consistent approach of the Government is to achieve change.

We have heard what we would expect from this Opposition. Senator Alston led off in a vicious attack on the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. He has been ably supported by Senator Stone, who has attacked the seamen and others. The Opposition's approach is always to attack the unions first, and to give what I would suggest is a rather superficial analysis of the industry. One of the matters I want to raise, as others might not raise it, is that the council of the Waterside Workers Federation is meeting today. It received the report before lunch and its members are reading it.

What we have here is an urgency motion from the Opposition. It believes that everything is so important. The members of that council are indeed reading and analysing that report, as people in the industry are and as everybody else should be. The report is a package. Many of the proposals would be acceptable to the Waterside Workers Federation. An example is where the union has put proposals forward. It disagrees with a number of the proposals and, as is the tendency in industrial relations matters, it states its position very strongly, as Senator Stone has said. But I believe that the Waterside Workers Federation will-it has indicated that it will-negotiate with the other parties to achieve an effective reform of the industry. When we make these statements, as the Opposition has, I think it is worth while analysing the sort of criticism that the Waterside Workers Federation has referred to. It is concerned about the bulk handling proposals, with which it disagrees. It is concerned about something that Senator Alston mentioned, namely, enterprise employment. It is concerned because the Liberal and National parties are always out to smash the unions, to undermine the economic power to trade unionists through their unions and so reduce the salaries that unionists might get. The concerns of enterprise unions are based on a bitter, bloody history in Australia, particularly in Sydney, which is where I come from, where everything that could be done to people was done in the hungry mile of Sussex Street. It is against this difficult background that we have to achieve change. We have examples of overseas experience--

TALK.START.PARA: —We cannot go on living in the past.

—Senator Alston, as a lawyer in his previous life, had the audacity to talk about the monopoly power of the waterside workers. Here we have professionals, Senator Stone, who can determine their own salaries, who can determine the pyramid structure of employment, who can exclude people and who can do every imaginable thing-but that is all right; they are professionals.

SPEECH.PARA: When people like the waterside workers try to retain employment, to improve conditions of employment or to increase salaries, Senator Stone says, `This will bring the country to its knees'. That is the double standard inherent in what the Opposition is saying. When the waterside workers are critical of the proposals for enterprise employment it is not an impossible situation to deal with. The Australian National Line, in Sydney and elsewhere, is a type of enterprise employment. When that is examined-and it has not been rejected out of hand by the waterside workers-it will be possible, given good faith, to get into a situation where some sort of a compromise proposal can be reached which protects the interests of the workers involved and which allows for the industry to be remodelled and streamlined. We cannot expect people who have had a history of strong solidarity to easily agree to some of their colleagues being completely eliminated in the process. That is a bitter and difficult process and, of course, it is one of the reasons the Australian Council of Trade Unions said that the Commission's recommendations on industrial relations aspects are not acceptable to the union movement in their present form. However, the unions have confirmed their acceptance of the need for waterfront reform and their willingness to participate constructively in the Government's forthcoming consultation process.

That is where Senator Stone shows his ignorance. Clearly there is an opening ambit claim. The council of the union is meeting this week. The Minister will go to that council meeting to discuss the matters with the Waterside Workers Federation. This is in keeping with the Government acting immediately to discuss the reforms and to achieve those reforms. Of course, employers will have concerns from within the waterfront. I think some of Senator Stone's National Party supporters throughout Australia might be concerned too and, legitimately, some community interests will be concerned with the centralisation of wheat. It is intended that wheat will be routed to the central city ports, instead of to places 100 miles along the coast, as it is now, where transport is close at hand. This concerns National Party people. I will be very interested to see how Senator Stone deals with that. He will probably deal with that matter in the usual way the National Party deals with these problems; on the one hand it is in favour of change, but on the other hand if the changes affect people in the country it screams the loudest.

It is proper to have a community discussion on the matter and I agree that the matter is urgent and that we should all participate in the debate, but I do not agree with the carping criticism in the terms of the matter of urgency that was put today. The Opposition's emotional and confrontationist approach will not help find a solution. Grandstanding has no place when we are looking to achieving complete change. When we talk about change, when we talk about the micro-analysis of industry, this Government has a good record, particularly in the steel industry, in heavy engineering, in shipbuilding, and in the textile and clothing industry. The people in those industries have had the opportunity to participate in changes. Change is only effective when people can take part in that change. Giving orders, passing motions, which is the Opposition's way, has not been effective. It has not been effective from the time of the Menzies Government through to the Fraser Government. Those governments failed to change anything because they could only make statements and speeches on the problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trade union bosses like giving orders. They do nothing else.

—Senator Stone talks about productivity. Does he not realise that we only get an increase in productivity when people give freely, when people believe that they are able to participate, when they can see that they are being treated fairly. Standing over people on our waterfront is no different from standing over people anywhere else. It is the only way known by people like Senator Stone, who are part of the elite in this society, on how to handle these matters, but they have not changed anything. This is confirmed in the Future Directions policy document of the Liberal Party. That policy says:

SPEECH.PARA: The chaotic situation which still prevails has occurred because of the mass of restrictive trade practices which have vested unions with excessive power.
This is the usual thing the Opposition refers to. The Liberal Party says its solution is:
implementation of essential services legislation and our industrial relations policy will achieve greater productivity.

The history of the waterside workers in particular in Australia is characteristic of the Australian labour movement. We want people to make effective changes that will transform the waterfront. They are the sorts of changes that we want to achieve. We want to take the industry away from its bad history. I do not deny that it has a bad history. It is a history that we want changed. Senator Gareth Evans gave the Opposition, by chapter and verse, an account of the detailed discussions that have occurred since 1984 in trying to get agreement and improvement. He referred to an improvement in August 1987 when the Waterside Workers Federation established the first of its joint venture stevedoring operations in Stanley, Tasmania, in an endeavour to improve stevedoring performance in smaller regional ports by the involvement of the occupational work force. This has since been followed by similar ventures being established in Mackay and Gladstone in Queensland, in Newcastle in New South Wales, in Geelong in Victoria, in Darwin in the Northern Territory, and in Geraldton in Western Australia. The employers and the Waterside Workers Federation will have discussions with the Government. The Government will lead those discussions. It is acting as a catalyst to try to achieve changes. It is a priority of the Government's economic reform agenda and the Government will be giving urgent consideration to the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission. It has been two years in preparation. There has been an interim report. There has been a great deal of preparation. We now have the opportunity to enable people to examine the report. We are coming to the important phase.

Unfortunately, the Opposition's reaction is to go back to the past, to attack the unions. If anything, this debate today will make it more difficult for the unions to come to the conference table with the Government and the employers and to be able to give some ground, as they have already done and will in the future.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members continually interject, but they have not seen a real live unionist in recent times. They live in a completely artificial atmosphere and continually denigrate people. They have to learn that if there is to be change on the waterfront people will man the cranes and do the work. That will only occur after they are convinced that it is in their interests to modernise and change the industry. This Government has given this matter a priority. The Minister will meet with the people concerned in the near future. I am confident that as a result of that we will have a much more streamlined waterfront industry than we have had in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating an urgency motion proposed by my colleague Senator Alston which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for immediate action by the Government to introduce reforms which will ensure that the Australian waterfront becomes efficient and productive instead of being a national burden and impediment to internationally competitive economic activities.

Nothing could be more urgent in Australia today than this motion. Before starting with the subject matter I think it is best to point out the state of our economy. We are enjoying the best terms of trade that we have seen for 10 years. Yet month in, month out, our balance of payments-our current account deficit-is in the order of $1 billion to $1.5 billion a month. Our net foreign debt is $100 billion and growing. Senator Childs talked about the need to be productive. We all agree with that. However, he went on to say that the only way to achieve that is by cooperation, consultation and-as Senator Gareth Evans said-consensus. Consultation and consensus on the waterfront has not worked. It is as simple as that. The only criticism I have is of the implementation of the Inter-State Commission's report. I will come to that later.

What are the problems on the waterfront? They are not that individuals who would like to work harder will not. I am not under any circumstances criticising the majority of people who work on the waterfront. I am criticising the system, the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia (WWF) and the restrictive work practices. I would like to give a few examples in the short time available to me. We all realise that people on the waterfront are paid a lot more than the average wage.

TALK.START.PARA: —About 30 per cent more, on average.

—As a minimum it is about $800 for a 28-hour working week. I would be prepared to accept that if those workers were permitted by the system, by the Waterside Workers Federation, to be reliable. The major problem in this country lies in the lack of reliability and the effect it has on our exports, our import replacements and, hence, our current account deficit. I will give a few examples of that. In addition to what are very generous wages, the WWF employees receive a whole range of extravagant allowances including a site allowance, a telephone allowance, a laundry allowance, an obnoxious cargo allowance, a bad stow allowance-for unloading badly stowed cargo-a dirt allowance, a rain allowance and a cold allowance, to name just a few. They do get a telephone allowance but when they fail to turn up for work on an almost daily basis work does not continue unless a replacement is found, which is made difficult by the fact that the workers do not telephone to advise that they will be unavailable, even though they are paid the allowance. In my home city of Brisbane that allowance is $7 a week. Another example is the eighth day off, where a wharf labourer works seven days in a row and gets a day off which is added to his annual leave. There is the infamous nick system that I have referred to often in the past. It is alive and well throughout Australia. This is where two or more men are rostered on to do the same job or some invented job and the spare wharfies can nick-off while on full pay. These are some other examples of overmanning which allows wharfies to nick off.

SPEECH.PARA: At Brisbane's conventional port-not the container or bulk ports-at least two extra workers are employed for each vessel. These spare men do no job and are not allowed to be employed even if a job arises during the shift. They are not permitted to work. Others must be employed to do any new jobs that arise during a shift. These are just a couple of problems. There is a system called two up, two down. On Brisbane's container and coal loading wharves a down driver must be employed on the ground for each up driver operating a crane. As cranes and other equipment are driven for the full shift by the same driver the down driver has no job to do. At one container terminal 480 shifts were allocated to surplus down drivers last year. That is the problem. We have spare front-end loader drivers who must be employed when gypsum cargo is loaded on to road transport in Brisbane ports. When three loaders are being used an extra five drivers must be employed in addition to the actual drivers. Needless to say, these spare drivers have no job to do. This is what we are paying for. This is why we are unproductive. This is why we cannot compete on overseas markets.

There is a group called general purpose men. Two general purpose men-GPs, as they are called; they have all the lingo down on the wharf-are allocated on board the vessel regardless of whether they are needed. We have people called amenities men. When a gang of 15 or more A-registered waterfront workers are employed an amenities man must also be hired to tidy up amenity rooms after breaks and safeguard waterfront workers' personal belongings. The amenities men have no real cleaning to do as the job of cleaning the amenity rooms is done by the port authorities. This is a most incredible situation that occurs in this country.

Another issue I wish to talk about relates to first aid men. This is not a safety issue. One of the most blatant examples of featherbedding is the first aid men on the waterfront. A fully qualified waterside worker must be employed in each stevedoring gang to man the first aid station. If he does not show up no work commences. If someone has a heart attack or cuts an artery there is nothing that person can do except call for an ambulance. In 1988 it was calculated that these first aid men cost-I am giving the example of my own city and the port of Brisbane-$1.5m for the year and tied up 17 qualified waterside workers who could have been doing other work. The stevedores decided that a much more efficient practice would be to contract with the ambulance brigade which would provide ambulances all the time with paramedics. They would have saved $700,000 a year if this had been done. It was rejected by the Waterside Workers Federation which said that one of the major problems on the wharf was the lack of wharf labourers available to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are these the people Senator Childs was referring to as such reasonable fellows?

—These are the people, as Senator Childs said, whom we can get somewhere with by consultation. It cannot be done. The editorial in the Age newspaper today referred to the Inter-State Commission. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing, as the report observes, is more certain than that the waterfront industry will not reform itself.

It cannot do that. I could go on and on. There are people called the glutmen. In Brisbane two glutmen must be employed to pick up any gluts-pieces of timber used to support cargo in transit-which may fall off timber packs. The incidence of gluts falling off is rare and does not require two workers to do the job. It was estimated that 400 man shifts are lost each year as a result of that simple overmanning. Waterside workers work for seven weeks and are rostered a week off. This is what they call a one in seven roster. This is in addition to holiday pay. It is included in the calculation of holiday pay allowances.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is part of the 38-hour week.

—I wish Senator Burns were right. He is not right and he knows that he is not entirely right. That is the theory behind it. It does not work in practice. I put it to the Government that not only do they get a week off but they also get a 25 per cent loading on the week when they are not working. Also, the extra hour's work that has just been referred to on top of their seven-hour shifts entitles them to a 20-minute coffee break, thus reducing the extra hour to 40 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer briefly to the report of the Inter-State Commission. Frankly, I think it is an excellent report, although I do have one reservation with regard to its implementation. The one reservation I have is in connection with the plan, which is on page 142 of the report. The plan itself is excellent and must be implemented. This will be the acid test for this Government. The report says:
. . . the Commission proposes that the first step be an in-principle agreement between government, the employer association, the ACTU and key unions.

As Senator Stone mentioned, we have already seen the reaction of the key unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which are not going to have a bar of it. Under the implementations suggested by the Commission, which assumes that it is dealing with reasonable men-and I doubt whether they are-either of those groups has the power of veto. This is the major challenge for the Government. The Government must not use that as an excuse not to implement something which it has talked about for six or seven years. It is worth commenting, in passing, on remarks made by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, the other day when he came in here and tried to have a bit of fun at Senator Boswell's expense. Senator Button said:

What is wrong with this country is that for years and years we had governments which were not prepared to face up to the problems of real deregulation. They were not prepared to face up to the problems of reducing protection to soft and flabby industries.

That is fair enough, but why did he stop there? He did not mention the monopolies that have been created in the labour market in this instance-the Achilles' heel of Australia-the point of exit of our export goods, the point of import of the capital goods that are needed for import replacement for exports. Going back to the Inter-State Commission report, it states in the general conclusions:
The evidence to the Commission on many matters such as inefficient work practices-
which I have just covered briefly-
unsatisfactory industrial relations, ineffective supervision and management, high costs and widespread unreliability all indicate that fundamental rather than incremental change is required.
Yet we heard the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, earlier quoting a litany of studies and investigations with no sense of urgency whatsoever. Further on the report says:
Australian industrial law and practice has had the general effect of conferring on unions monopoly or near-monopoly power . . .
This is never heard from the other side; we hear about it in respect of other issues. Dealing with the important considerations that flow from that, the report continues:
First, there is a strong case for representation of users and the community in the negotiations that lead to industrial arrangements. Second, a union-
the Waterside Workers Federation-

to which society has conceded a large degree of monopoly power should be committed to exercising that power responsibly. Third, abuses of monopoly union power should be dealt with in a manner similar to abuses of corporate power.

We have been saying that for year and years on this side of the Parliament. We are looking simply for the unions to fit within the same level playing field as applies to everybody else in the community. It is not a matter of union bashing. I would fight just as strongly for the right of someone to participate in a trade union as for his right not to participate. What must happen-and these are the major recommendations-is that we get rid of restrictive work practices, get away from the industry-based pooling system, get on to an enterprise-based employment system where people who work for a company can build up their expertise and have some loyalty to that company so that each day their pride grows that they are improving their productivity and are adding to the ability of this country to compete and not destroying our competitiveness and productivity in overseas markets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the tabling at the end of last week of the conclusions of the Inter-State Commission (ISC) recommendations on its waterfront investigation, the Hawke Labor Government has finally run out of even the flimsiest of excuses for failing to take immediate action to change the disastrous and intolerable structures and work practices on our waterfront. That is why the Opposition has moved today, as a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for immediate action by the Government to introduce reforms which will ensure that the Australian waterfront becomes efficient and productive instead of being a national burden and impediment to internationally competitive economic activities.

The Australian waterfront has been costing the Australian people hundreds of millions of dollars a year more than it should. Numerous inquiries and reports in recent years have provided abundant evidence of this and, indeed, pointed the way to the specific changes required. But this Government, the toady of the union movement, has refused to act. It has always sought one more inquiry, one more report, as a camouflage for its lack of guts. It now has the Inter-State Commission report. There can be no more excuses. There can be no more delay. The buck rests fairly and squarely with this Government. It can have April or May economic statements and August Budgets until the cows come home, but if it fails to reduce the costs on our waterfront the Australian economy will remain in tatters and every Australian will continue to suffer declining living standards.

The findings and recommendations of the report of the Inter-State Commission are welcome. They reinforce the evidence of earlier inquiries. The proposals for change are moderate and, indeed, generous to waterside workers, whose rorts and work practices have for decades ripped dollars out of the pockets of their fellow Australians. Why is the Government so obsessed with discussions and negotiations and so incompetent and gutless in actually dealing with the waterfront fiasco? The report lays down in detail a plan of action. There is no need for further discussion. Indeed, if there is a fault in the report, it is its moderation in seeking the execution of its plan over a three-year period. Action is so urgent that it should be completed within a year. After all, every year that goes by retaining significant elements of the present structure costs Australians at least $620m and probably more than $1 billion. Given that need, if a three-year program is to be implemented, then it must start now. The time for talk is over.

We have already heard a cacophony of responses to the Commission's findings and especially to some of its recommendations. The most notable and, unfortunately, the most predictable was the response from Mr Tas Bull, General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, who slammed the report when it was released last Thursday, rejecting its proposals outright. His little mate Bill Kelty, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), has come out in support of Mr Bull and his union's position. Both are simply serving vested self-interest, not of the waterside workers but of trade union structure and power. Under the proposals, both can see the premier waterfront union losing membership to other organisations in a rationalisation of labour when the ACTU is seeking to create all-powerful super unions to entrench its power in the corporate state which this Government is establishing.

Senator Childs claimed a few moments ago that honourable senators on this side of the chamber had not seen a live unionist. Since that report was published last Thursday, I have spoken about the report with a senior official of the Waterside Workers Federation. One can certainly understand the union leadership adopting a negative position on the report-it is against their vested interests-but it is the Government's responsibility to act in the interests of the wider community. It must act without delay. However, improved industrial relations and productivity on the waterfront require a marked change in attitude, an end to the `us and them' mentality between employers and employees.

Some of the Commission's recommendations address these attitudinal issues directly-such as replacing labour pooling with an enterprise employment structure. The union should not oppose them. Let us hope that saner heads prevail at the meeting this week of the National Council of the Waterside Workers Federation, which is considering this report. Let us hope that Mr Bull's initial reaction is replaced by a greater recognition of the national interest.

The Commission's findings, which recommend considerable and specific changes to work practices and necessarily reduced employment to sort out overmanning, finally, after years of hearings, get to the heart of the matter, to the heart of the disease on our waterfront. Evidence to the Commission of inefficient work practices, unsatisfactory industrial relations, ineffective supervision and management-and we need to note there is a managerial responsibility as well as union responsibility with regard to some of the problems on the waterfront-high costs and widespread unreliability, all indicate that fundamental rather than marginal changes are required.

It is about time too. For far too long we have had a plethora of investigations, inquiries, commissions, studies, reports and reviews, none of which have so far resulted in the implementation of the key restructuring of the waterfront and its associated participants which this nation requires. This has chronically affected Australia's efficiency and standing in international commodity markets and has denied us many export income opportunities. Here in Australia the stevedoring industry has not been subject to direct regulation in the last 10 years other than through the general provisions of the trade practices legislation. In recent years there has been increasing shipper and community concern about the level of shore-based shipping services and costs. With the considerable changes that have occurred on the Australian waterfront since the Second World War, such as the move toward containerisation, the refocus of trade patterns fostering growth with Japan rather than Europe, industrial and environmental issues and a developing society and economy, it was evident that waterfront labour needs would by necessity reflect a change in demand.

In the 30 years since the late 1950s there has been a 79.8 per cent drop in the number of A-register watersiders, despite an increase in bulk and non-bulk tonnages over that time. The proportion of the volume of cargo stevedored by Waterside Workers Federation members shrank from 63.8 per cent in the early 1950s to 21.8 per cent in the early 1980s as a result of much of our mineral and some other bulk commodity exports being handled by members of other unions such as the Australian Workers Union or through private ports. This very occurrence is a sad reflection on the productivity of Waterside Workers Federation members.

In recent years primary labour concerns have been the surplus brought about by the increasing development of containerisation and the rigidity of the permanent employment scheme. The flow-on effects, concession on wages and conditions, together with a 35-hour week, which was introduced in the stevedoring industry before any other section of the economy, made labour-intensive operations costly and hastened the introduction of container shipping operations. The recent experience of industry scrutiny under government structure reform committees suggests that innovation is not a feature of the industry. The existing waterfront scene has long been set, and it has inherent dangers.

As I said a few moments ago, the Waterside Workers Federation members are now handling less than a quarter of all cargo moved in and out of the country. Restrictive work practices, low productivity, overmanning and inefficient management produce an industry where cost overruns are in excess of $1 billion per year. Just imagine what the cost overruns would be if more than a quarter of all cargo was handled by the Waterside Workers Federation. In the light of such cost overruns, the Commission figure of a $620m per year benefit to the Australian community if the Australian waterfront becomes more productive seems very conservative. In fact, other participants in the Inter-State Commission's inquiry have offered much higher figures. The figure of $620m was the lowest estimate to emerge from the inquiry. The fact that Australian productivity levels tend to be lower than those of comparable countries is recognised even within the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

One factor worthy of further scrutiny is the high average age disability profile of our waterfront work force. Labour force statistics highlight the reasons why the industry exhibits low productivity. Some 53.5 per cent of A-register waterside workers are over the age of 50 and one-third of the work force is over 55 years of age. In my own State of South Australia almost half the Adelaide waterside work force exceeds the age of 55 years. In Sydney there has not been a single new recruit for some 15 years, since 1974, while in Adelaide it is some 22 years since there was a new recruit to the waterfront. Of course, the age structure has its flow-on in terms of disabilities as well. The debilitating effect on the industry of this profile is obvious when the combined effects of age and disability are seen against a trend demanding improved skills, training and labour flexibility. The only way these issues can be addressed is through early retirement and the recruitment of younger, properly trained employees, as recommended in the report.

All ports around Australia are subject to an exhaustive list of restrictive work practices. My own research has identified further rorts in my home State of South Australia in addition to those I outlined when last debating this issue in the Senate last year. In Adelaide, for instance, workers transferring between ports were refusing to commence work until their agreed travelling time had expired. As a result, other labour was forced to stand by at the commencement of a shift. Transfer labour now commences work upon arrival at the berth and receives payment from the stevedores from that time. However, they also require payment of the full travelling time. As a result, they are being paid double for the interim period.

Fixed minimum manning scales apply for almost every aspect of stevedoring operations. Minimum scales must be allocated if work is to occur. They are not flexible and cannot vary, except upwards, to reflect real operational requirements. As a result, manning throughout the industry is constantly in excess of what employers require. On certain types of ships' gear, such as swinging type derricks, where the equipment has one seat with three control levers and is designed for a single operator, the waterside workers demand two drivers, insisting this is necessary to utilise the three controls, despite the fact that the equipment is designed for one-man operation. Where forklifts transport unitised cargoes, two men on the wharf are employed as a minimum to assist the forklift. Their role is simple to stand by and replace any component of the unitised cargo which might fall off. Why is it necessary to employ at least two men in case something falls off the forklift when they perform no other function? In some cases hired-in equipment such as mobile cranes and front-end loaders are supplied with an attendant driver. In such circumstances it is the current practice that Waterside Workers Federation members be allocated to that type of equipment whether they are capable or proficient to drive that equipment or not.

Irrespective of who finally operates the particular item of equipment, there is a duplication in overall manning, doubling up the real driving requirements. This is an increasing restriction which is resulting in carriers not using stevedoring equipment due to its high cost. As a result, stevedoring companies are losing hiring charges which they would otherwise be able to gain from the utilisation of their equipment by road transport carriers. Heavy lift cranes are only driven by specialised crew which are supplied with the crane. However, the Waterside Workers Federation demands payment for waterside workers drivers as if they worked the vessel. In Adelaide, a specialised submersible vessel worked with no involvement of the Waterside Workers Federation. However, the Federation demanded payment for drivers.

Spelling is a common activity, with few exceptions, in Port Adelaide. The allocated hold complement on all vessels and commodities in the port adopt this practice where, at any given time, only half of the labour is actively working and the other half give themselves a spell. At Port Pirie, on bulk discharge operations, when a front-end loader is operating in the hold; a whistle man is employed in the hold in addition to a hatchman. On a signal from the hatchman, he activates a remote control warning device in the front-end loader to warn the driver that the grab is returning. The device, however, can be activated by the hatchman, thus obviating the necessity for a whistle man to be employed. However, no adjustments have been made since the introduction of the remote control device.

The rorts and cost impediments to our waterfront go on and on. That is why it is important that the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission's report be implemented. Its reforms are not radical except, it seems, for those in the Australian waterfront. Reform on the waterfront is crucial if serious impediments to the growth of Australia's export competing industries are not to occur. These industries that create wealth for all Australians have suffered for far too long at the hands of the waterfront. We can no longer afford the rorts and low productivity of our waterfront. If this Government does not act, then undoubtedly a future coalition government will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —It would appear that the word `productivity' has really been given a bit of overtime today. I do not believe in productivity for productivity's sake because the product of all the rubbish stated here this afternoon by the Opposition would not produce any benefit for anybody. The attitude of the current Government in its policy set down for the future in relation to labour market reforms and industrial relations agenda entitled `Labour Market Reform-the Industrial Relations Agenda' states that the elements of the Government's strategy for economic reform include:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a legislative framework which ensures the effective operation of the industrial relations system and promotes industrial harmony;
a wage system which facilitates micro-economic reform;
education and training arrangements to ensure the development of a more skilled work force . . .

Senator Chapman talked about one water-side worker or more who could not operate certain bits of machinery. This policy will take care of that problem. The current position has come about because of the lack of training provided by employers. The policy continues:
. . . the restructuring of awards to provide incentives for skill formation, and to help develop more flexible forms of work organisation;
the expansion of practices of information sharing and participation in decision making.

There is no way that one will succeed in reforming the waterfront or any other organisation unless what is required is understood by the work force and management. Therefore, they would be inclined to cooperate in the national interests. A change in attitude is required on the part of management, supervisors, workers and trade unions.
The policy goes on to say:

An adversarial approach will not bring about the fundamental changes in workplace and management attitudes required for long term improvement in productivity and competitiveness or for continuing acceptance of new technology and other changes.
That is, union bashing will not succeed one little bit. The policy continues:
The Government will continue to use the Accord process as the foundation for ongoing structural adjustment and labour market reform.
The Accord is a process for addressing changing economic and industrial circumstances; it is not a prescriptive charter.

This is in contrast to overseas experiences where prices and incomes policies have failed because they have not been able to make this transition. The result will be a more flexible labour market and a better quality of life for employees.

That is our position. Let us examine some of the rubbish that has been stated this afternoon by those opposite. Senator Stone talked about people lifting their game and the question of productivity. Senator Alston talked about production and efficiency. He said that waterside workers had more money than they deserved. I have in front of me a document put out by the Waterside Workers Federation, which is directed at its members. It explains their position. It says that a waterside worker's basic rate is $429 per week, which is far below the average national wage. It is certainly far below what Senator Alston would be getting if he were operating as a practitioner in law. I do not know that I would give him a job. However, he may be fairly competent. He talked about no productivity being a disgrace. If we look at the documentation we find that the number of waterside workers has been reduced from about 25,000 in 1970 to 6,000 currently. In the last 20 years productivity has increased more than five times. I do not think that is a disgrace. It may well be argued that productivity could be more, but one cannot argue that and ignore the fact that management practices and attitudes have a lot to do with it.

Senator Stone talked about the need to look at coastal shipping and rail. He ignored certain elements of costs involved in that area. Only last week I mentioned that road transport has an unfair advantage because of the tremendous road costs borne by the taxpayer, whereas the rail industry has to provide its own maintenance, its own permanent way. There is no doubt about that. It is an unfair criticism of the railway system. I believe the railways can be efficient. Originally they were saddled with two different gauges, in New South Wales and Victoria, and later a third, Queensland, with a 3 foot 6 inch gauge. If that is a prescription for efficiency, I will have to re-think my position. I do not think that would be the case.

What more do those opposite want in regard to shipping? The seamen have accepted lesser conditions in many instances. Manning has been drastically reduced on coastal shipping. Do those opposite want our seamen to work like those who work on ships from ports that are used as tax havens and tax rorts? Do those opposite want our seamen to sail rust buckets, for about $20 a week, in which their lives are at stake when it is possible that they go down at sea with no trace? No, they do not want to do that. This is the correct process. It is not helped by abuse from those people opposite. Ship owners say that there has been a big change in industrial relations and that they are fairly happy with the way that the Seamen's Union of Australia is dealing with a real problem that certainly needs to be looked at.

Senator Chapman talked about the lack of guts and the fact that we should work together. In terms of floating the dollar, de-regulating banking-we will de-regulate wheat and sugar-this Government has shown a lot more guts than the Liberal-National Party. Those opposite wanted to do it but they never had the guts. They should not talk about guts because they do not have any. People can see what has happened.

Senator Alston talked about feather-bedding and the darg system. He should know that the darg system was introduced by employers; not by the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. It was introduced years ago to get higher productivity. He talked about featherbedding-people looking after their own interests. I can assure him that if I were a waterside worker and my ability to provide food and lodgings for my family and an education for my children meant that I had to withstand certain changes in my industry and the only thing going for them was that they were in the national interest, and the national interest did not care about me, I would make a stand too. We talk about the national interest but we do not talk about what we will do for those people who will lose their jobs and how we will distribute and re-allocate all the savings amongst the work force and the general community. In many cases, higher productivity has put more profits into the hands of the employers. It has not helped the community at all.
