It was interesting to hear Senator Alston talk about featherbedding. I have known many people working in the field of law. Many of them are very fine people. Some I have not particularly liked. But I noticed the other day that legal practitioners were outraged when someone suggested that in New South Wales solicitors and barristers were really not needed in many cases involving up to $5,000. It was said that this was outrageous: how could one take away the right of people to have lawyers represent them in the courts? I do not knock that. They have a right to argue that but Senator Alston had better think about it. He should not be a hypocrite by suggesting one approach when it comes to the waterside workers and another approach when it comes to legal practitioners.

There was talk about the national interest and the national debt that was increasing. I have some figures in front of me which show that in the three months to November 1988 car imports amounted to $500.8m, as against $173.2m in the same period last year. The latest new motor vehicle registration figures show that the largest increase in numbers of cars imported has occurred for luxury vehicles. I assure honourable senators that the wharfies are not buying the luxury vehicles; I suggest that the employers are-the very people that Senator Alston and all those opposite represent. And they worry about the national debt! Those opposite should ask their people to stop buying Mercedes-Benzes and Rolls-Royces. We, on this side of the chamber, will keep buying Fords and Holdens that are made in Australia.

Those opposite talk about enterprise unions. Enterprise unions are only a way to deny workers access to a union which can give them the expertise which employer organisations give to employers. Employers who have millions of dollars in resources can employ skilled and trained people in industrial relations and negotiations, but those opposite want shop stewards with no access to any of those things to try to match them. It is no match at all. I have no problem with the idea of having a proper organisation within the enterprise, but it must be linked up with and be part of a trade union on an industry basis so that people can have a fair go and no-one is taken advantage of.

Even before this report was brought down, we had a media release by Tas Bull, the National Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation. One Opposition senator said today that Tas Bull and the Australian Council of Trade Unions rejected this report. I took that to mean that it needs a lot of working over and that there are many things it contains that the union does not accept, but I find it difficult to accept that the report contains suggestions made by the unions. If that is the case, it would be a little silly to think that the unions are rejecting such proposals. I believe that the unions are saying that the report needs a lot of working over. Tas Bull says in the press release:

To ensure that debate on waterfront restructuring is full and broad-ranging, the Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia (WWF) is putting together comprehensive briefing papers about what needs to happen on the waterfront and why. A working version of these papers was released to the media today.
The National Farmers Federation and some other industry groups have been lobbying hard to influence the outcome of the Investigation.
There is nothing wrong with that at all. Tas Bull also says:

The National Farmers Federation, the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour and others would like to force changes which serve their own interests. They are seeking to scapegoat the unions for all the industry's inefficiencies, in some cases including their own.
Self-serving solutions are not the answer.

He goes on to talk about a desperate need for rejuvenation. He talks about some of the successes which have come about as a result of joint ventures, Mackay being one and others have been mentioned. He was kind enough to include a letter from one of his satisfied customers. There do not seem to be any of those on the other side of the House. One of the customers wrote:

You often read criticisms of waterside workers . . . so it is therefore particularly gratifying that I am able to write to you to applaud you and your men associated with the Port of Geelong stevedoring company for the excellent effort in loading the `Professor Popov'. Everything from the lack of damage, to the loading rates was more than you could reasonably expect . . . I can only say once again how particularly pleased we were for the efforts that everybody put into it. Mike Murray, Managing Director, International Food Processing.

The unions also put in a graph which showed that 50 per cent of waterside workers were over 50 years of age, 32 per cent over 55. It dealt with the fact that there had not been any new waterside workers brought into the industry since back in the 1970s and that that needed to be done. The unions did not wait for the report before making suggestions as to what was needed. The union agrees with those sorts of things. But the question the unions asked themselves was, `Why should we allow these changes to take place totally against the interests of our members and be expected to carry the burden for the whole community and to provide higher profits for the employer?'. The Waterside Workers Federation's document says:

The WWF has been working with various government bodies over the past two years to reform the waterfront. Further, we have taken initiatives to introduce joint stevedoring ventures and productivity schemes. It is the Federation which is pressing for change.

The Federation said that the unions are not mucking about but are pressing for change and want it to happen. The document issued by the Federation went on to mention the seven ports around Australia which operate joint ventures. The Federation also mentioned a fresh approach to fruit exports. It said that after it had made changes the fruit all arrived in perfect condition and that there was no deterioration at all-normally, the deterioration figure is 15 per cent. What happened was that the wharfies visited Shepparton fruit growers and as a follow-up the farmers came to the wharves, because both felt that they could profit by working together. They hit on a simple formula-more coordination over delivery and loading, more trade and more jobs. The outcome has been a boost to Australian fruit exporters, according to the Executive Director of the Northern Victorian Fruit Growers Association. He said:

If the fruit keeps arriving in Europe in as good a condition as this lot we'll be very, very pleased . . . Now thanks to the cooperation of the shippers and the union we're getting a good slice of the overseas market.

That is an example of where the waterside workers took the initiative. Quite calmly, they went and talked to the farmers and the farmers indicated that perhaps they had not done all the things they needed to do. One cannot put rotten fruit on the wharves and then blame the wharfies if it is crook. The farmers realised that the fruit needed to be in good condition. They provided it in that condition, and they benefit, as does the community. It is a case in which there is mutual benefit. But that is not what the report suggests. Everything that it suggests certainly will not be mutually beneficial. The document continues:

While there continues to be real problems on the waterfront it is clear that substantial progress has already been achieved. This progress could not have been achieved without the cooperation of the waterfront unions, including the Waterside Workers' Federation and their recognition of the need to maximise competitiveness in order to improve job security and increase employment opportunities for union members.

Those are the sorts of attitudes that people have. It is an attitude which was shared by Ralph Willis, the Minister for Industrial Relations, in 1988. I do not want to go on any further, but my last plea is that we should go forward together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate because of my concern about the inefficient waterfront industry in Australia, and especially on the eastern coast, which greatly affects the rural industries throughout the country, especially the wheat marketing industry. At present this Government is trying to restructure marketing in the wheat industry-a system which has operated successfully for 42 years. At the same time the Government is trying to impose on the industry proposals which the Government will not apply to itself. Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, would like wheat farmers in this country to take on measures that will reduce their income, and yet the Minister and his colleagues will do nothing about the waterfront. There is no mention of cost cutting measures that are imposed on farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon the Senate heard a tirade from Senator Button during Question Time about the coalition in Opposition failing to come to an agreement on the deregulation of the domestic market, and he referred to the Liberal Party falling into National Party thinking. Let me tell Senator Button that we are very capable of coming to our own decision on wheat marketing without any interference or suggestions from him. What is more, the Liberal Party represents as many wheat growers as do the Nationals, and together we will work the problem out.

The difference between the waterfront industry, about which this Government will do nothing as long as it can get away with it, and the wheat industry is that the wheat industry has no rorts. There are none of the rorts that one finds on the wharves-rorts which have been mentioned by several speakers in this debate. Our wheat industry is the most efficient wheat industry in the world. If honourable senators want confirmation of that fact, they should read the Hansard report of today's proceedings. Who said that the Australian wheat industry is the most efficient in the world? It was said by Senator Gareth Evans during Question Time, in answer to a Dorothy Dixer from his own front bench. Honourable senators can read that for themselves when that report appears. The big differences between the two industries is that there are no rorts in the wheat industry, and certainly one finds those rorts operating on the waterfront. The McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport found that savings of $10 to $12 per tonne could be achieved if some of its reforms were implemented. That also included some freight.

I have seen some of the rorts operating in Fremantle. I have watched self-loading ships and have seen men scattered everywhere-men who fill in their time when in fact they are not needed. The report of the Inter-State Commission on waterfront investigation has found that the waterfront of Australia is the most imperfect marketing system that one could ever find. There is inefficiency of management, lack of general efficiency and poor work force training. Senator Burns set out the reasons why there is a lack of training, but he thought that it was the employers who were not carrying out the training task. In all sorts of jobs, be they professional, technical or labouring, one expects some on the job training; but the employers cannot be expected to take that on board when, for example, a fellow applies for a job to drive a crane or a truck. One expects that he has some knowledge of that before he arrives. This Government has always said that the Australian work force in other areas should be trained before we take trained personnel from overseas, but I am afraid that in Australia there are too many people who do not want to be trained.

We see introspective industrial attitudes, as my colleagues have pointed out. There is poor information for users and poor links in transport. I have seen many times, as have many honourable senators in the chamber right now, road transports down at the wharves waiting to load or unload containers. In the morning 30 or 40 trucks will be lined up and those same figures of 30 or 40 trucks will still be lined up even towards knock-off time in the afternoon. It is beyond all comprehension why the wharves cannot put in place a booking system so the transport operators can get an approximate time at which they may be loaded or unloaded. It has been asked for, but that request has been refused time and time again. These unions want to waste the time of these 30 truck operators, who have to wait at the gate until a quarter to four or a quarter past four, or whatever early time the waterfront workers knock off in the afternoon, just hoping that they may get loaded or unloaded. When the gates shut they have to drive away and come back and get in the queue the next morning. It is thoroughly inefficient.

There is an imbalance in the use of facilities. For weeks on end facilities may be underused. Then when a couple of ships are in at the same time the waterfront is snowed under. But those involved do not try in any way whatsoever to meet the demand. That keeps others waiting, and it is all because of the abuse of a monopoly power. I can give a good example of a small company that exported some cottonseed out of the port of Brisbane. This company contracted to supply 1,500 tonnes of cottonseed to a client in Saudi Arabia. Although this seemed to be a fairly straightforward exporting initiative, the company experienced a number of problems. First, delays in unloading the ship prior to the commencement of loading resulted in the company becoming liable for expenses of $4,000 for labour placed on standby, awaiting the opportunity to load. Secondly, the actual loading rate was well below that initially indicated by the stevedoring company, so that 11 shifts of labour were used instead of the four shifts originally estimated. In addition, the company had to provide about $4,500 worth of plywood to resolve a safety dispute involving the loading operation. Thirdly, the much slower than expected loading rate made the company liable for ship demurrage charges of $21,600. The total cost of the loading operation at the wharf, including stevedoring, plywood and demurrage, came to $92,800, or $62 a tonne. The initial estimate by the stevedoring company was $23 a tonne. So that figure was multiplied several times. That is what we get with an abuse of monopoly power.

The Commission's report did recommend that in order to become efficient the waterfront work force around Australia should shed 3,000 workers over the next three years. The report advises that in the meantime 1,000 people under the age of 30 years should be recruited. This will mean an effective drop in the work force from approximately 7,000 men, and perhaps women, to 5,000. The new people will then be trained in the skills required. We certainly need to have multi-skilled people so they can move, for example, from a crane to a front-end loader. There is also an advantage in having younger people because they can be trained more readily. We have all heard the old saying that you cannot teach an old dog new tricks, and that is especially the case if the old dog does not want to learn them. We have had many examples of that this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no old dogs in the Senate.

—Some are getting that way-including myself. The point is that not only will we have people more willing to learn, but also they will be more adaptable. In the main, they will also be fitter. As the report said, the average age of workers in our ports around Australia is over 50, and a lot are over 55; many of them should not be working because of medical conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: The report did mention-this is most important in industries involved in bulk grain handling terminals; industries with which I am involved-that bulk terminals should operate as one unit and labour should be employed by that unit. I refer in particular to the bulk wheat terminals around Australia, which could work far more efficiently. When the new port was built just below Fremantle in the early 1970s it operated quite successfully until the Waterside Workers Federation decided to take over representation there. We have had no end of trouble since. If the terminals could handle their own labour and that labour were represented by a less militant union, I would say the wheat industry would be far better off. We have a far better chance of the smaller ports around Western Australia being in a much better situation, but unfortunately those ports are short in draught capabilities and only smaller vessels can be accommodated. The bigger ships can be loaded with a certain amount of cargo but then they have to go to Kwinana to finish the loading.

This report points out that unfortunately it will cost $158m over the next three years to implement the recommendations. I believe that $158m is not an amount that employers, and probably the Government of Australia, should have to pick up, because of the way things have gone over the years and the rorts and systems that have brought about the present situation. The report also tells us that there could be a saving of approximately $620m a year once those measures have been put into place. Much as I dislike the public purse picking up the cost, I believe that in this case it should be picked up so that we may eventually get over these problems and save $620m a year.

I mentioned earlier that Senator Button had said during Question Time that the Opposition was not willing to deregulate the domestic wheat market but wanted to deregulate the waterfront. The coalition came to the position that we would, under certain circumstances, support deregulation of the domestic market if the Government were willing to put into place certain measures under which the waterfront and other areas would be fixed up. This afternoon the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a statement to try to appease our side, but I do not know whether really it will introduce measures that exempt the Australian Wheat Board from State regulations that impede the efficient storage, handling, transport and marketing of grain being traded interstate or overseas. He knows as well as I do that trucks will not be able physically to move all of that wheat even if we deregulate road transport. The wheat mostly has to be moved by rail. The Government also has to look at keeping wheat on rail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe in wheat marketing deregulation or not?
—I am certainly one of those who fought for the status quo. However, I suppose I can say that I was rolled in respect of the democratic decision that was taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following urgency motion:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for immediate action by the Government to introduce reforms which will ensure that the Australian waterfront becomes efficient and productive instead of being a national burden and impediment to internationally competitive economic activities.

I think the importance of this subject cannot be overstated. We are a great trading nation. But, frankly, at the moment we are not doing very well. Our current account deficit is more than $14,000m a year and is going up by between $1,000m and $1,500m each month. We desperately need to improve our exports. As an integral part of improving the competitiveness of our exports, we must improve the performance of our ports. It is essential to our survival that we do so.

Not only that, our ports are also very important in terms of interstate traffic. We are a very scattered industrial community. If our industries are to be efficient, we need to be able to move products cheaply, quickly and reliably between our scattered centres. But we cannot do that at the moment. The costs are appalling. It is cheaper to ship a given quantity of freight from Tasmania to Europe than it is from Tasmania to Melbourne. We cannot be internationally competitive if this is the way our ports as well as our very inefficient coastal shipping carry on.

It is not only a question of costs; it is also a question of reliability. Our exporters will lose orders if they are unreliable in respect of delivery. In some parts of Asia the only news that seems to come through about Australia is contained in the lists of the current strikes in Australia that are affecting the country concerned. We have a very unenviable reputation as a reliable deliverer of goods of any sort. We are very unfavourably regarded as a suitable supplier by many countries whose manufacturing industries depend for their efficiency on keeping their stockpiles low.

We have, regrettably, the reputation for having the worst and the least reliable ports in the developed world. Some countries insist that extra insurance be taken out before their ships come to Australia. They even advise their ship owners not to trade with Australia because of the very poor standard of our ports. This matter, in the interests of the whole Australian community and the efficiency of the Australian economy, must be tackled. It has been estimated, I think accurately, that for every dollar we improve the efficiency of our ports, through every dollar that we can save through increased efficiency, the national product would go up by $2. It is not a matter of looking for jobs for the boys on the wharves. If we can increase the efficiency of our ports, our whole industrial efficiency and our gross national product will rise $2 for every $1 we save.

It has also been estimated that 20 per cent of the $11 1/2 billion we spend on transporting and handling exports and imports could be saved by just bringing our standards up to those of our international competitors. This, of course, comes back again to the question of reliability. The potential savings from increased reliability are very great. Unreliability comes not only from sheer bloody-mindedness. Political strikes are also a big factor, as are demarcation disputes. The non-involvement of our work force on the wharves is a particular factor in the success or failure of the enterprise they are involved in. Lack of competition and lack of involvement are fatal to efficiency.

Even now we have the absurd situation of containers being sent by road along the Hume Highway from Melbourne to Sydney. This is an absurd way to move a container. The reason for this is the high cost of coastal shipping and the very high costs and very low level of reliability of our port handling facilities. People prefer to send containers by road, which is reasonably competitive and efficient, rather than being involved in our coastal shipping and port handling facilities. Nevertheless, this is a very inefficient and unsuitable way of transporting containers. If only we had efficient coastal shipping; if only we had efficient ports.

The Inter-State Commission report lists many of the rorts and inefficiencies which have been mentioned many times in this debate. I certainly do not intend to go through them in detail. I will just mention a couple of examples of the problems we have. The average throughput per employee in an American grain handling terminal is 100,000 tonnes. In Sydney, using the same equipment, the throughput per employee is 17,000 tonnes; in Newcastle it is 21,000. This compares with 100,000 tonnes using the same equipment in America. We just cannot afford to let this sort of thing continue.

I will give the Senate another example of the sort of productivity that we are not getting. Container cranes are almost identical around the world. For 100 containers handled on Australian wharves at a given time, New Zealand handles 138, the United Kingdom 141, northern Europe an average of 214, North America 250 and Japan 312. Using the same equipment, the Japanese load and unload containers three times as fast as we do. Australia cannot possibly remain competitive under such a situation.

As I said, I do not want to list all of the many rorts and inefficiencies that are listed by the Inter-State Commission. I want to give the Senate just one more example. The enforced use of gangway watchmen and hatchmen has nothing to do with safety. If the work of a watchman is required, it is a matter for the ships crews, which in the case of our coastal shipping are already heavily overmanned as it is. There is no necessity for them. At present, they are provided by regulation or union demand at very considerable cost. As I said, there is no need for them. They are just as useless as Melbourne suburban railway guards, who have not had a job to fulfil for 25 years but who have continued as a result of historical accident. There are 948 unnecessary gangway watchmen and hatchmen around Australia. These men, who have no job to do at all, are being paid for ultimately by the Australian community.

A month ago a much publicised summit on the waterfront was called by the Government. That summit did not achieve anything. In fact, the result was a drop in productivity, which has not yet come back to what it was before the summit. There have also been extra delays since the summit at an average of two days extra per ship. The so-called summit-the much heralded summit-just did not achieve anything. Of course, the Government's solution to problems is to talk about them or `address' them, as it says, and not do anything.

At Question Time today the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, made a remark about the Liberal-National Party coalition not doing anything about the wharves. Two things can be said about that. I accept that the wharves have been in an unsatisfactory state for many years. This is not a sudden occurrence of the last few years. But we now have a crisis in our balance of payments. The pressure to do something, which was always there, is now urgent and it is time for the government of the day, of whatever political colour, to take action to deal with the crises as they arise. As a matter of fact, there were two inquiries during the term of the Fraser Government. I would be the first to say, as I said at the time, that they did not go far enough or deeply enough into the real problems on the wharves. In response to what Senator Button has said, the recommendations of these two inquiries were promptly implemented. What did the Australian Labor Party do about them? It opposed them step by step, all the way. But if this Government is now prepared to take action to sort out the mess on the wharves, real and effective action, I can assure the honourable senator that we will be supporting it. We want to see something done in the national interest about the crisis on our wharves.

The Inter-State Commission has recommended a number of fairly radical proposals to try to solve this long-running and disastrous problem. For instance, it recommends the introduction of casual labour. Well, that is common right throughout the rest of industry. If a firm has varying loads, if it has full employment, it has standard people to cover the standard load, and employs casual labour to deal with the extras. What is so extraordinary about that? The attitude of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia is, as far as can be established, `No way!'. The second recommendation of importance is an end to the so-called general employment system, that is, the pool. Instead, waterside workers should work for the particular enterprise they are being employed by. This again is elementary throughout the rest of Australian industry and it does at least give some chance of developing a feeling among the people working for an enterprise that their future and their standards are bound up with the efficiency of that enterprise. That is the direction in which we must move. What is the attitude of the Waterside Workers Federation? In no way will that be agreed to. What is the attitude of the Government? We do not know yet, but I am certain that it will not do much about it.

The next recommendation is that the employment arrangements of the waterfront industry can be restructured to allow more competition. The only way to break down the exploitation of monopolies is either by legislation, if it can be introduced and enforced, or by introducing competition. Competition is by far the most effective way of doing it. I think we must look for ways in which we can introduce proper competition on the waterfront so that the efficient terminals get more business and the inefficient ones get less. Ultimately that is the only way in which we are going to improve efficiency on the waterfront.

The Commission also recommends the ending of the waterside workers' monopoly and, in particular, that the people who work on bulk handling facilities should be employees working for the bulk handling terminals and, as far as I can gather from the recommendations, members of a separate union. That is entirely sensible. That is the way in which we must go. We cannot continue with our bulk handling terminals working at one-fifth of the level per employee of American ones. The Commission also recommends a gradual reduction in the average age of the stevedoring work force. It is presently over 50 years of age. I do not accept, as Senator Button seems to be implying, that people over the age of 50 cannot be usefully employed. Nevertheless, for hard manual labour it is perhaps much too high as an average age. The idea of a retirement or redundancy package to encourage people over the age of 50, who are frequently not fully fit, to leave the industry and to recruit young employees is one I am sure we should all support. My worry is that the Government will put this, as it has put virtually all the other micro-economic reforms, in the too hard basket.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! What are you talking about?

—I have not yet seen any signs of any serious micro-economic reforms. The Government has made a few macro-economic ones with which I agree, but this is the sort of area, dealing with productivity, which I think we must tackle and which this Government has neglected. It has been looking in all the wrong directions. But of all the areas of micro-economic reform, where improved productivity is important, our waterfront is the most important. It is crucial to our competitiveness, and on our competitiveness this country will rise or decline. The world does not owe us a living. We must earn it, and we must start earning it by having an efficient waterfront.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are in effect debating a report from the Inter-State Commission entitled Waterfront Investigation, Conclusions and Recommendations. Whether or not we agree with the conclusions and recommendations, at least the report should be used as a basis for discussion and proper analysis of what might be done on the waterfront. Having listened to the debate, unfortunately it seems to me that the Opposition has not used this debate as a basis for developing a strategy to answer the problems on the wharves. It has used it to present a litany of the evils of the waterside workers. The problems, according to the Opposition, will be solved if we can somehow put leg irons around the waterside workers and use the whip to scourge them so as to stop their so-called rorts. To return to the convict days of old, all the problems were cast upon the people in chains, the people actually doing the work. There was nothing wrong with the New South Wales Corps, the system or anything else; the only people who could be blamed were those who were doing the work. That, of course, was not the approach taken by this report.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point of the seven main elements which this strategy describes is that we, as a nation, should achieve effective management and a well motivated work force. The Opposition's approach to obtaining a well motivated work force is to go down to the wharves and say to anybody who is not under 30, `You have to leave because you are too old', or to say, `For years you have been engaged in several rorts. You have never been able to work well; you have never done as much work as people overseas, whether in Japan or the United Kingdom. In fact, you are pretty unsatisfactory human beings'. That is the approach the Opposition takes. It will say that to the waterside workers and then add, `Having told you these things, we now expect you to be well motivated. You really will not mind being called the scum of the earth, the lowest of the low, people who earn more money than they ought to. You ought to accept what we well-motivated people from the National Party and the Liberal Party in the Senate have to say as we really know how you ought to work. We are telling you how to do it. Now we want you to go away and become well motivated'.

The situation on the waterfront has developed over many years. Although there are faults on the waterfront, and it must be accepted that there are many, they did not appear during the period that this Government has been in office but at a time when the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia pursued an economic and trading policy whereby we sold commodities overseas and imported manufactured goods. That is still the situation. That is a legacy from the past which is still with us today. The situation on the waterfront is a great illustration of that because Australia brings in many more container loads of manufactured goods than it sends out. In fact there has been a build-up of containers. That is not a problem that has been created by the waterside workers. It has been created by the way industry has been developed in Australia over many years. Not only has industry developed that way, but the attitude that has developed in that industrial scene has been reflected amongst those at the waterfront. Senator Hamer asked: What has this Government done? I will tell him what this Government has done. Before I do so I will read from page 124 of the first volume of the report. It states:
During its investigation the Commission was encouraged by the way in which the main parties in the waterfront industry appear to accept the need for fundamental change.

That is what the Commission found. All the main parties, including the employers and the employees, accepted the need for fundamental change. That is not a statement consistent with the sort of libel that has been placed upon the waterside workers by the Opposition up until now. It continues:
This is not to say that all parties agree on all of the components of the necessary changes.
The report goes on-this is the part I want to emphasise-to say:
But a climate does now exist in which it is practicable to move forward and revitalise the waterfront industry.

That statement could not have been made when the Opposition was in government; it could never have been made at the time this Government came into power in March 1983, but it can be made now. That is the answer not only to the waterfront, but also to industry and to the development of commodity production and to secondary production in this country. The clue is that there has to be a new climate, a new culture, a new attitude developed amongst managers and workers. That is happening, and it has happened under this Government. There is much optimism in that statement about the course this Government has pursued through an accord with the unions, through a proper approach to unions, through a proper approach to management, through a proper approach to those who take part in production-that is the companies and the people who manage and plan-and through a proper approach to those who work under them. This proper cooperation will lead, and has led, to vast increases in productivity.

Let me give an illustration. Most illustrations that have been given today have been anecdotal. There has been a swapping of stories. The Opposition gives stories about how dreadful it is. The people on this side give stories about how good it really is. I will illustrate how the waterside workers have accepted a quite big drop in wages over the years for an increase in the tonnage handled per man. I am not saying that this illustration proves that things are anywhere near perfect, but it illustrates that if a proper approach is taken a climate can be formed where the reform can take place. The illustration is that in the early 1970s, the waterside workers were paid according to a formula which in effect was 93.75 per cent of the gross national average wage for the adult male unit. That was adjusted every three months in accordance with the average male wage paid over that time. During the Whitlam period, wage indexation was introduced and the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia went along with that, but then there was a wage freeze and we had the development of the accord. The fact is that if the 93.75 per cent formula had applied to the general hands on the waterside throughout that period-that is from when it was introduced in the early 1970s until now-the general hands would now be getting $90 more than what they get. There has been, therefore, according to that illustration, an acceptance of the need for a moderation of the increase in wages and an understanding that there had to be an increase in tonnage. That is an illustration of the fact that if the problems on the wharf are approached in a cooperative way, in a way which does not denigrate one side, in a way which respects the approach taken by all sides, there is hope of getting out of this problem.

To go on to another point, much has been made about the monopoly union power on the wharf. Let us look at that. The first thing to remember, as has been said already, is that the waterfront is run, in theory at least, by a number of stevedoring companies, all of which are privately owned. This is an industry that has developed as a private industry over the years. It is an industry which has employed labour on the basis that it will no doubt help each stevedoring company in competition with the others. Much has been made in the report about the monopoly powers of the Waterside Workers Federation. In the same breath there has been much criticism of demarcation disputes on the wharves. They are inconsistent statements. If we are going to have unions in competition on the wharf, we are certainly going to get down to a series of demarcation disputes which, I happen to think, are the most destructive of all strikes. The employer cannot do much about these disputes. If we are going to run a centralised wage-fixing system, if we are going to run an industrial relations system as we have since 1904 and before Australia became a Federation, we have to have unions covering particular groups of employees. That is the way the system is run and by and large it has run well. As has been pointed out in this report, there has been a diminution in industrial disputes on the wharves since the Waterside Workers Federation obtained greater coverage early this decade. Many of the illustrations put forward by the Opposition to show that things are working badly are, in fact, signs that things are working a lot better than they did in the 1950s, the 1960s and the 1970s, or when it was in government. That is the real comparison to make. How do things stand now compared to how things were at the end of the previous Government's term in office? I notice that Senator Michael Baume will speak next. If we compare the situation now with what it was at the time when the Opposition was in government, we will see that the situation is much better, that the tonnage per man is greater, that the wages are more moderate, that strikes are down and that demarcation disputes are much more modified. The exciting thing about all this is that there is hope, as this report says, that things will improve rapidly. When we look for improvement we are not to look, simply as has been done by the Opposition, at changes in the attitude of unions, at changes in the work that they do and at the productivity. The whole industry must be looked at. In that context, the union's contribution must be looked for and demanded just as the contribution from the employers must be looked at and demanded. It is a complex problem. Finally, I will quote from page 123 of the first volume of the report as it illustrates that very point. It says:

The evidence to the Commission on many matters such as inefficient work practices, unsatisfactory industrial relations, ineffective supervision and management, higher costs and widespread unreliability all indicate that fundamental rather than incremental change is required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always interested to follow Senator Cooney, not necessarily because he occasionally makes some remarkable Freudian slips which reflect reality, such as his comment, `as we come to the end of the Hawke Government', but because Senator Cooney has almost a natural honesty, which means that when he has an impossible case to argue his argument demonstrates that it is an impossible case. Everything Senator Cooney said on behalf of the Australian Labor Party points to the need for this Government to take action to correct the disastrous situation on the waterfront.

SPEECH.PARA: It is totally wrong for Senator Cooney to say that the only people the Opposition seems to be criticising are the workers themselves and that we are putting the blame on the workers for everything. I stress to Senator Cooney that the Waterside Workers Federation has been under solid attack from this side of the chamber for one very simple reason: its total, outright and disgraceful rejection of the Inter-State Commission report, its irresponsible damning of this report, its instructions to the Government not to act on this report in any effective way. When a union behaves as irresponsibly as that and is half-heartedly defended by Senator Cooney, then it does not deserve to face anything less than severe criticism in this chamber. Let us look at the sorts of problems the union has got itself into in this matter. This report made an examination of industrial disputes in the period from 1 December 1988 to 1 February of this year. This was just a brief two-month period to examine whether all the reports of irresponsible behaviour on the wharves were accurate. This was the conclusion in the report:

Most disputes were, if not spurious in intent, at least questionable and they illustrate a degree of failure in dispute-settlement procedures as well as seeming indifference to the consequences of their actions on the part of labour involved.

That is absolutely damning of the unions involved, which are responding to this report by saying that nothing should be done along the lines of the recommendations. They are instructing this Government to maintain a situation in which these unions can behave irresponsibly and get excessive money in some instances for not producing the goods. Some of these industrial disputes are incredible, and I recommend that people read pages 393 to 409 of the report. One of the disputes referred to on these pages related to holding up a ship because it dared to have South African cargo on it. The report reveals that the suggestion that such protest action may harm the wrong parties was given weight by the comment of the ship's agents, who stated:
. . . a greater part of the ship's alleged South African cargo was in fact Mozambican tobacco, railed south and shipped from South Africa because of the poor state of Mozambique's main port.

Apart from anything else-the serious question of who is running our foreign policy, Tas Bull and the Waterside Workers Federation or Mr Hawke and Senator Evans-the fact is that this silly and irresponsible action by the Waterside Workers Federation and other waterside unions that have at times joined in this kind of black ban in effect hurt the people who are least capable of withstanding that hurt-the Mozambicans. The stevedoring cost of that dispute was $20,000, excluding quarantine costs. The demurrage on the ship involved, sitting idly doing nothing, was in addition. The fact is that this was no industrial matter at all. This was a political issue. Of course, many things hide behind health issues. There is another instance on which the report states:

This case is typical of many of the safety disputes that occur on the Australian waterfront regularly, and is indicative of the extremism exercised by sections of the WWF in an endeavour to avoid having to work.
It is the type of attitudinal behaviour which creates the unreliability for which the Australian waterfront is infamous.

Strangely, it is the union that is responsible for this kind of behaviour which is attacking this report. This Government has to have the intestinal fortitude to stand up to it. There was another case-case study No. 5-where there had been an agreement to have a specified level of productivity. If the men did their work satisfactorily and got enough goods unloaded they could then go. As a result, when the men who had done their work went all the other gangs said, `Well, if they can go so can we'. But they had not entered into such an agreement and had not done such work. This is just ludicrous and is explained in many cases in the report. I repeat the conclusion from the report:

Most disputes were, if not spurious in intent, at least questionable, and they illustrate a degree of failure in dispute-settlement procedures as well as seeming indifference to the consequences of their actions on the part of labour involved.

That is one of the reasons why we need radical reform of the waterfront. The question also seriously affects the coal loading industry, particularly on the south coast of New South Wales. It is in New South Wales that the coal loading industry is demonstrated by this report to be totally and monumentally inefficient. A study was undertaken by the Inter-State Commission which identified a number of factors influencing the performance and costs associated with the domestic transport, handling and loading of coal at the terminals investigated. Those were Port Melbourne, Balmain, Newcastle, Gladstone, Dalrymple Bay and Hay Point. Basically, they found that in New South Wales in particular it was a disaster. The report says:

The consultant identified a number of factors influencing the performance and costs associated with the domestic transport, handling and loading of coal at the terminals investigated. First, the consultant considered that many port and ancillary charges may be based upon inappropriate pricing mechanisms.
It went on to outline what they were. It continued:
Second, employment and industrial relations factors underlie many differences in the operational and financial performance of the coal terminals investigated.
It noted:
the level of manning at the New South Wales terminals, which is substantially greater than that at the Queensland facilities;

the level of manning at terminals owned and operated by the Maritime Services Board, which is significantly greater than employment levels at privately owned Newcastle facilities (even though the throughput at the public facilities is less than that at the privately operated terminals);
the current Maritime Services Board service agreements at Port Waratah and the Kooragang Coal Loader, which are operated by a pool of Maritime Services Board employees;
the large number of unions representing New South Wales coal employees, which inhibits agreement between employees and management;

the enforced use of gangway watchmen and hatchmen, which appears to have been maintained as a result of historical practice rather than as an operational or safety requirement of contemporary bulk shipping;
the absence of flexibility, efficiency and skill clauses in particular industrial awards and agreements;
industry-based rather than company-based employment at some loaders;
restrictive work practices (for example, minimum working hours and wage requirements at Balmain);
some union benefits derived from the expedient settlement of industrial disputes in the past.

Third, in some ports the regulations require use of pilots for foreign-flag vessels without recognition that many coal ships are dedicated to a particular trade and the ships masters have excellent knowledge of local port conditions.
It continued:

Finally, the high level of road and rail transport rates, unsatisfactory receival facilities at some terminals, and limitations on rail movements resulting from priority being given to passenger services significantly affect costs: land transport costs constitute approximately 30 per cent and 25 per cent respectively of New South Wales and Queensland export prices.
That is intolerably high, and many honourable senators in this chamber have been commenting on this for quite some time.
In relation to ownership and administration of loaders, the report states:

. . . the consultant suggested that in view of the poor performance of Maritime Services Board loaders, the New South Wales Government should consider `corporatising' coal terminal operations. This would provide the necessary commercial freedom to efficiently service the current and future industry.
Port charges should be reviewed and restructured to reflect costs.

So there are many matters apart from the Waterside Workers Federation itself. But the point remains that the Waterside Workers Federation has behaved appallingly in this matter, along with other waterfront unions.

Having stressed that there is scope for massive improvement in this area, I want to stress, on behalf of the people who live in the Illawarra region, that there is an urgent need for this recommendation of the consultant referred to in this report to be brought into effect. The consultant recommends that there should be an independent review of rail freight rate structures for coal haulage in New South Wales and Queensland; that current restrictions in New South Wales on the use of road vehicles should be removed; and that a number of other measures should be taken with a view to improving road infrastructure and receival facilities where it is inappropriate to use rail. The consultant also concluded that in relation to port operations and regulations the Government should continue to explore the need to upgrade existing facilities in order to ensure continuing improvements to efficiency; that particular attention should be directed at increasing the depth alongside some berths, removing the existing restrictions on night-time entry in New South Wales, and allowing tug requirements to be determined according to maritime conditions at the time of entry or departure. Those are all rational and sensible things. I hope this Government will do something about them rather than adopt the approach of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, as I recall it, referring to a previous report, who said: `There is no way that we are going to do anything about it, and don't hold your breath waiting'.

There has been a suggestion that the Opposition when in government did nothing about these things. When we were in government we introduced a lot of reforms. I accept that we did not introduce enough reforms, but one of the reasons that there were not enough is that there was a lack of-that marvellous word-consensus, without which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who is always calling for consensus, says that nothing really significant can be achieved. What sort of consensus did the Australian Labor Party give us when we were trying to reform the wharves during the time of the Fraser Government? While we were in government, the Labor Party was only interested in aiding and abetting the stranglehold of the unions over the waterfront and stevedoring. That is the way it voted and spoke consistently. Now it is in government and the iniquities of the present system on the waterfront and of the shipping industry have been so thoroughly exposed, it is at last forced to at least consider taking some action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't talk rubbish. You did nothing.

—I remind the Minister of our response in 1976 to the Northrop report when we decided to withdraw the Government from the industry. That was a major change, because at that stage the dead hand of government had been over that industry and made it even less efficient. Action was taken which resulted in 1,107 registered workers leaving the industry by the middle of 1977 to try to make it more efficient. Yet we hear this nonsense that when we were in government we did nothing. We called the second National Stevedoring Industry Conference and took action to implement its recommendations. We reduced the Government's involvement in the industry, as I have said, and normalised relationships between employers and employees, thus making them more responsible for the running of the industry's affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I stress that this is not simply a matter affecting the waterfront; it affects every Australian's standard of living. I strongly support the conclusion by the Age newspaper that Mr Hawke should add his weight to this report. The editorial opinion was:

Delays or modifications could destroy the whole plan. If the Government has to stand up to the WWF, it should be willing to do so. This is an issue on which Mr Hawke cannot afford to be defeated. Millions of dollars in export earnings and his Government's credibility depend on the outcome.

The reality is that every dollar that is wasted on the waterfront, every corrupt dollar, every pinched dollar, every dollar that the Waterside Workers Federation seems to want to maintain in this flow to it and its members, is coming out of the pockets of the Australian people.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTER-STATE COMMISSION: WATERFRONT INVESTIGATION CONCLUSIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I appreciate that this Inter-State Commission report on the waterfront has been the subject of very lengthy and very fruitful debate in the Senate today. I think that reflects the importance of the report. In the five minutes available to me I would like to make some of the points that I would have made had I had the opportunity of speaking in the debate today. The report by the Inter-State Commission is one of the most important reports tabled in this Parliament in recent years. It goes to the heart of the micro-economic reform required if Australia is to improve its productivity and its ability to compete with other countries both in export markets and in Australia itself with imports.

The rhetoric that we have heard from the Government over the last 18 months, two years or more in terms of the importance of micro-economic reform has not in any sense at all been reflected in the performance of the Government. The consideration that the Government gives this report and the treatment that it accords it will be a major test of the Government's credibility as to whether it is really serious about wanting to get this economy on the rails.

The waterfront industry and the shipping industry are two of Australia's most important industries when it comes to determining international competitiveness. This report, of course, deals only with the waterfront. In the near future there will be a report on the shipping industry which has been prepared by another inquiry headed by Mr Ivan Deveson. That too will be an inquiry of major significance. If we cannot handle our exports efficiently from the time they get to the wharf to the time they are received in their overseas destinations, we will continue to lose our competitiveness. The bottom line result would be increasing balance of payments crises, an unstable currency, higher inflation, less employment and lower living standards for us all.

This report found a great deal wrong with the waterfront industry. The litany of problems, of course, is very long. The problems were dealt with earlier today. They include ineffective management, poor work force training, introspective industrial attitudes, poor response to user needs, and attendance and the abuse of monopoly power reflected particularly in pricing and investment policies and the approach of the trade unions. The report noted that considerable changes have occurred over the last 50 years-as one would certainly hope they have-in the industry but that there is a need for further substantial changes. The Commission found that the benefits would be great. If the recommendations of this report were adopted the minimum contribution to the Australian economy was estimated at $620m a year. That is a very significant contribution indeed.

The report said that fundamental rather than incremental changes are required if the necessary results are to be achieved. The report emphasises that the role of government itself will be absolutely vital if these changes are to be implemented because the industry will not be able to reform itself. The most important change required of all is to reduce the extent of monopoly union power in the industry. That is spelled out in some detail on pages 125 to 127 of the report. It is to be regretted that both the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia Secretary, Mr Tas Bull, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions Secretary, Mr Kelty, have so prematurely rejected the report. Mr Kelty is reported to have called the findings childish. I think that is highly regrettable. He has a great responsibility to assist in pushing these reforms through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Normal power of veto.

—He has the normal power of veto, as Senator Parer says, in relation to much of the activity that is necessary in this economy. It is going to be a major test of the Government and of the trade union movement.

I rise to speak on the Joint Coal Board forty-first annual report, 1987-88. The Joint Coal Board is an anachronism in Australia. I think it is worth just drawing attention to the beginning of the report where it talks about the general powers and functions of the Board. The general powers and functions of the Joint Coal Board include the powers:
(a) to ensure that coal is produced in the State-
that is, New South Wales-
in such quantities and with such regularity as will meet requirements throughout Australia and in trade with other countries;
(b) to ensure that the coal resources of the State-
New South Wales-
are conserved, developed, worked and used to the best advantage in the public interest . . .

This was introduced at a time when the only coal in this country being mined was in New South Wales. It was introduced at a time when the major energy source in the country was in New South Wales. Of course, the Board itself is funded 50 per cent by the Government of New South Wales and 50 per cent by the Federal Government. I cannot help but question why the rest of Australia should be funding an industry which in 1946 may well have been totally enclosed in one State but has no relevance whether it be Western Australia, my own State of Queensland, Victoria or Tasmania.

The Joint Coal Board is an authority which the Federal Government has said on numerous occasions it intends to get rid of. In fact the recently elected New South Wales Government said that it would also be prepared to do that. There is an occupational health and rehabilitation service. I read in the report that the Joint Coal Board has now leased accommodation at Narellan to house a rehabilitation service. We must bear in mind we now have Medicare-most companies contribute to some sort of health fund to pick up the gap-and we have the Joint Coal Board going on its way willy-nilly spending the taxpayers' money through the Federal Government and the Government of New South Wales. This involved the examination of 273 miners in three separate districts. A prevalence of approximately 10% was recorded for all categories of disease, with quite large local variations. The much more stringent criteria for diagnosis required by the trial drug protocol (which only accepts moderate to severe disease) dropped the prevalence of those acceptable for entry to the trial to 4.3%.

I have said this year in, year out: The Joint Coal Board is an anachronism. It was established at a time when this country was quite different, over 40 years ago. The cumulative impact of those and similar losses in earlier years-and into 1988-89-is such that the Treasury is being robbed of many of its most promising officers who could have been expected to form the backbone of the senior ranks of the Department in the years ahead. There is also a risk that the very large gaps now opening up in relative salary levels for Treasury and private sector economists could begin to undermine the exceptional commitment from officers who choose to remain with Treasury. The reality is that if the Government is to have access to the best available advice on the nation's on-going economic problems-as it is entitled to-it will have to pay for it (although it does not follow that the overall costs of government must rise; a better paid but leaner, more productive Service could well lead to net savings).

It is quite interesting that a major department such as the Treasury should be, in effect, castigating the Government for its failure to create a leaner, more productive service which could lead to net savings but which would enable the skilled experts in higher positions to be adequately rewarded.

There is one benefit that the Treasury has as a result of spreading its ex-members around in the private sector, and that is that it can quite happily seek almost to mislead the private sector by suggesting to former colleagues still within Treasury that the Government knows what it is doing about the economy. It will be noticed that a very large number of forecasts made by former Treasury economists working in the private sector about how the Government's last Budget was sensible, rational and doing the right thing were demonstrated to be absolute nonsense. This ex-Treasury mafia has served its purpose, while leaving the Government bereft of adequate and coherent advice.

I am distressed that the Government seeks to diminish the expert levels of the Treasury by one move by appointing a Treasury officer, for the first time ever, to be Governor of the Reserve Bank. I regard it as a retrograde step. The Government is behaving disgracefully in so doing. The money markets are expressing proper concern by regretting that someone who is accustomed to Canberra rather than the reality of the marketplace should be moved from the Department of the Treasury to take over as Governor of the Reserve Bank.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, which is associated with the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill 1989, the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill 1989 and the Insurance Supervisory Levies Collection Bill 1989. The overall Bill, the Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill 1989, gives effect to the 1988-89 Budget announcement, last August, to levy an annual supervisory fee on general insurers, Lloyd's and life insurance. This measure is intended to recover the ongoing costs of supervision of such insurers under the Insurance Act of 1973 and the Life Insurance Act of 1945 by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Another Bill contained in this insurance legislation package, the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, contains provisions to amend the Insurance Act 1973 and the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984 to provide for the registration of insurance intermediaries dealing with unauthorised foreign insurers, and for the collection of statistics regarding premiums remitted overseas; and to amend the Life Insurance Act 1945 to give effect to a number of miscellaneous changes to improve the administration of the Act.

I should say straight off that the Opposition will be supporting these Bills because it believes that they are reasonably based and, therefore, should go through unopposed. However, a number of issues need to be raised. First, this insurance legislation in effect corrects yet another Government botch-up, another mistake. According to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) this super deluxe, high quality front bench is supposedly the best that this nation has ever seen. He has stopped making that claim now, having had to sack so many, pension so many off and send so many overseas. But this is yet another one of those administrative botch-ups that this Government has been responsible for.

This package replaces the Government's aborted Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. The original Bill sought to make virtually the same changes as do the present Bills. But the Government withdrew the Bill last November before it was debated in the Senate in order to reassess its provisions in the light of the High Court of Australia decision to reject the immigration arrivals fee in the Air Caledonie case. Hence, the current Bills have been drafted following the immigration fee debacle to ensure that they are constitutionally sound. The point to be made, therefore, is that the Government failed to get the legislation right in the first place. The capital gains tax, for example, has been subjected to monumental correction months and months after an announcement was made. In fact, in that case people had to take commercial decisions on the basis of the announcement of a law which ended up not being reflected accurately in the legislation that was ultimately passed. We have seen the same sort of nonsense in respect of the broadcasting legislation.

It seems that this is yet another example of what happens when this Government makes mistakes by trying to make short cuts in drafting its legislation and gets it wrong. This comes not simply at a cost to the people who have to act on the announcement of legislation-in this case, for example, from the time of the last Budget. It also comes at a cost to the Parliament by, quite frankly, wasting its valuable time and resources. It also demonstrates the Government's continual contempt for the Parliament by entertaining such constitutionally unsound legislation which simply cannot be sustained. One wonders whether at some stages-early in the session in particular-this Government is in fact just whacking up legislation simply to give the appearance that it has itself prepared and ready and that it is actually doing something. We find that at the end of each session we have to deal with mountains of hurriedly prepared legislation. We get the situation where legislation such as the Bills before us had to be withdrawn after the Government's first try and it has had to try again.

Of course, the Government's action also comes at a cost to taxpayers in particular because of the huge cost of constitutional challenges in the High Court and the additional paperwork, of course, that results from this kind of continual muck-up. The Government makes blunders in respect of its legislation. It is about time, after six years, that the Government got its act together and stopped making these nonsensical, absurd mistakes in regard to legislation.

It may well be that this is another example of the consequences of the Department of the Treasury's complaint in its annual report that was released today about how this Government is monumentally incompetent in establishing not only a leaner Public Service but a better paid Public Service so that it can get better quality people. I am glad to see that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is in the chamber. I encourage him to read the Department of the Treasury's annual report because, clearly, it gives its side of what must have been continual battles with him and his Department about an inappropriate and disadvantageous system that continues to apply with the result that the Treasury Department is losing so many of its senior officers. Maybe the loss of senior and competent public servants continues to bring these sorts of problems. Of course, as I said, it may well be that the Government is rushing legislation into the Parliament just to give the appearance of doing something, particularly at a time when it does not have itself in any kind of shape, it has not got its legislative program in any kind of order and it has to fill in early in the session with a whole lot of matters which could have been better thought out.

Another comment worth making on this group of Bills concerns taxation. In his second reading speech on the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) said:

The proposed levies reflect the Government's view that, generally, where a service is designed to benefit a particular group, the cost should be borne by that immediate group of beneficiaries of the service rather than by taxpayers in general.

That sounds a great principle. I think it is correct. But in this case it is really quite eccentric. There is really something very odd about a statement from a Hawke Government Minister on this one. How can the Minister hold a straight face while mouthing those words about relieving the burden on taxpayers in general when, of course, the Hawke Government is the highest taxing Government in Australia's postwar history and is responsible for the greatest number of new taxes and charges of any previous government? The Hawke Government has obtained its Budget surplus on the backs of ordinary taxpayers, mainly through bracket creep. Families in particular have been hit by the Hawke Government's ruthless attack on middle Australia. In other words, this Government has taxed the incentive out of the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the worst interest rates.

—As Senator Puplick says, and the worst interest rates. There is no doubt that today's news on that score is particularly worrying, with one bank now having outlined that as a result of deliberate governmental policy it will be increasing some of its mortgage interest rates to 17 per cent. Another bank is forecasting that 18 per cent is likely.

SPEECH.PARA: I should just mention in passing on that score that it is ludicrous for the Government to pretend, as it will on Wednesday night, that it is providing an immense benefit by giving an $18 a week tax cut and a $25 a week pay rise when, if interest rates go, as expected, to 18 per cent, this will mean an extra $70 a week in the interest and mortgage repayment bill of someone purchasing no more than an average Sydney home. This slug is already up $40 a week extra compared with June of last year. The bill will be increased by another $30 a week to $70 because of this Government's direct and deliberate economic policies, which are pushing interest rates up higher.

As I was saying, at the same time as the Government is continuing this massive attack on people through interest rates, it now promises to give back a tiny fraction of the enormous amount of money that it has taken from them. I think the Opposition has established very clearly now that people are something like $58 a week worse off than they were when this Government came to office. This is mainly because of tax. This is why living standards have plummeted under Labor. By 1 July this year, when the long awaited tax cuts are due, a person on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse would need, as I suggested, a tax cut of something like $58 a week simply to restore that family to the situation it was in before the Hawke Labor Government came to power. No Minister has effectively refuted this statement. Although there has been a bit of personal abuse about it, there has been no effective refutation of the figure. Yet the Government still has the gall to talk about relieving taxpayers by the supervisory fee that is imposed under this package of legislation. Apart from anything else, it is rather quaint to impose supervision on an industry, which the industry says is not necessary anyway, and then to charge the industry for the benefit of the supervision it is getting. But that is a separate issue.

The fact is that this Government is pinning its political survival on the tax cuts that are due to be delivered from 1 July this year. They are to be announced this Wednesday, and they will virtually disappear within 12 months, and no doubt before then, because the money Mr Keating will give back in tax cuts will be taken away again by inflation and more taxes. In fact, it has already been taken away, as I indicated, by massive increases in interest rates affecting the purchase of homes. Interest rates have priced many thousands of Australian families out of the prospect of owning their own home. The Keating $18 or $20 tax cut will not in fact mean a decrease in taxes of $20 a week, because he will claw back most of it through taxes on the wage rises that are now planned to take place during the year. In June 1990 an Australian on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children will still be at least $50 worse off than in March 1983, when this Government came to power. He gives with the one hand and the Australian Taxation Office and price rises take away with the other. Therefore, even after so-called wonderful tax cuts, living standards will still be in a shocking and depressed state, courtesy of the Hawke Government.

Getting back to the specifics of this legislation-I have just dealt with the irony of the Government claiming some kind of purity on tax in this matter-the final issue to be raised concerns the Government's inaction to date in introducing other important legislation in the insurance area. Prior to last year's May economic statement, the tax system treated life offices and friendly societies on a concessional basis. Life offices were taxed at 49c in the dollar but on a concessional tax base because of certain tax deductions under sections 46, 115 and 116 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Friendly societies were taxed at 20 per cent. Following the May statement, the deductions allowable for life offices will be severely cut back, and the rate of tax applying to the life insurance business of friendly societies is to be increased from the present 20 per cent to 30 per cent. But after nearly 12 months we are still to debate this legislation. The industry is becoming very concerned about the absence of this legislation in black and white.

This is yet another occasion, in a long list of occasions, where this Government announces a policy decision but fails to back it up with legislation, in some instances up to three years after the decision. This is not simply monumental incompetence, it is monumental arrogance. There is no doubt that this Government, the longer it stays in office, is revealing a greater and greater level of arrogant disdain for the requirements not only of the corporations in this nation-in this case the insurance companies of this nation-but of people on whom it depends for votes. I think that this kind of uncertainty on the part of the ultimate consumer, that is, the taxpayers of Australia-the fact that the private sector in so many instances does not know what the legislation is going to look like and has to rely on initial statements of some years standing, which are not necessarily backed up by the reality of the legislation as major changes take place-generates considerable additional costs, apart from the fact that enormous amounts of professional advice have to be obtained to ensure that, whatever the corporations are doing during this time of limbo, they are not put at risk in any of the activities they undertake.

I conclude by saying that the coalition parties do not oppose these Bills. We are glad that eventually the Government has got around to bringing into the Parliament, and putting into black letter law, the statements that it made in last year's Budget. I suppose it is appropriate, with the mini-Budget coming on this week, that the Government should choose this week as the way of eventually introducing some legislation relating to that Budget. But we will be watching very closely the Government's claim that this legislation will be effective in improving the administration and the regulatory supervision of the insurance industry. There is no confidence on this side of the chamber, particularly in view of the incompetent manner in which this matter has been dealt with so far by the Government, that the Government will be capable of being effective in improving the administration and regulatory supervision of the insurance industry. The Opposition wants to see the industry expand under an effective regulatory environment, but one that imposes as few regulations as necessary. In other words, the only role of government in this arena is to ensure that there is fair and honest play on as level a playing field as possible. That means we have a basic philosophic difference from so many members of the Australian Labor Party, whose main objective is to generate a maximum volume of regulation and red tape. So the Opposition's commitment to limiting the amount of regulation to the minimum amount necessary stands in general contrast to the philosophic basis on which the Labor Party has existed all these years. I repeat: the coalition parties do not oppose these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is tonight debating a package of four Bills, and in that package there lies a story, as Senator Michael Baume has already pointed out. We are dealing with the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill 1989, the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Bill 1989, the Insurance Supervisory Levies Collection Bill 1989 and the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), in his second reading speeches, pointed out the litany of problems that lay behind this package before us tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills, of course, are substantially the same as the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, which was passed in the House of Representatives in November of last year. It was, however, withdrawn before the Senate had an opportunity to debate it. The primary reason for the Government withdrawing the legislation, before giving it to the Senate for debate, was that the Government could make some changes in the light of the Air Caledonie case, which was taken to the High Court of Australia over the issue of immigration review panel fees. It was the High Court's decision in that case which led the Government to rethink the format in which it was presenting the legislation. The result of that decision was to cast some doubt on the Government's attempt to impose insurance supervisory levies on general insurers, Lloyd's and life insurers. Therefore the levies and the method of levy collection are in separate Bills in the legislation currently before us.

In the House of Representatives, and in the chamber a moment ago, the Opposition indicated its general support for the legislation. But it raised some other issues, such as the Government not giving the House of Representatives enough time for it to debate the legislation generally; the foresight of Australians in not giving the Government control of the Senate; the decline in living standards; and an appalling propensity by the Government to try to legislate by press release. To all these concerns and views the Australian Democrats say, `Hear, hear!'.
