It was with the support of the Opposition that the Democrats last year had a motion passed through this chamber that set in place some restrictions on the Government's capacity to legislate by press release. I think this will make life somewhat easier for people in complicated professions who need to know where they are on a day to day basis and who do not want the Government indicating that it will change some legislation three years before it actually gets around to presenting the legislation to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —And often in a very changed state.

—Yes, and often in a very changed state or, worse, in a state that turns out to be flawed, confusing, not easily able to be understood and so on, which leads to amendments being made either in this chamber or by the Government itself under pressure from people in the industry. The whole thing finishes up causing more confusion than it needed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Baume, when speaking a moment ago, raised the question of high interest rates. He talked about the problems being caused in the community because of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which had nothing to do with the Bill.

—Indeed, it has nothing to do with the legislation and I had intended to make that point. However, I wanted to point out that it was Senator Michael Baume and his colleagues who supported the deregulation of the financial sector which has led, inevitably, to these sorts of high interest rates and caused many problems to many people who have to deal with the financial sector that Senator Michael Baume was talking about. In fact, on the Page One program tonight the Chief Executive of Westpac Banking Corporation, Stuart Fowler, very cheerfully admitted that the banks are in the business to make profits and that if they can increase those profits by squeezing the customer dry, by putting fees on all sorts of services that they advertise they want people to take advantage of, that is precisely what they will do.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Michael Baume is quite right to be concerned about the level of interest rates in this country, but he and his colleagues have to share the responsibility for that fact, not only because they supported this Government in deregulating the financial sector and encouraging foreign banks to come in, all under the guise of increasing competition, providing better services and lowering interest rates-none of which has occurred-but also because they share with the Government a predilection to encourage foreign investors into this country for a variety of reasons. They support the sort of tax inequities that apply which allow investors to get a tax break if they want to buy into the housing sector but do not allow a similar tax break to people who want to buy a home to put over their own and their children's heads. This is somewhat different from the story in both the United Kingdom and the United States of America, where people who own homes for themselves to live in are given a tax break.

Furthermore, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is running around saying that all of this is at least partly caused by the fact that people are not putting their money into the banks any more, that they are spending as if there is no tomorrow. Yet no encouragement is given to people to support the banking sector in this way because the Government takes through the tax system the bulk of interest that people earn. So unless governments change their attitude we will have the sort of situation that Senator Michael Baume quite gratuitously raised this evening.

The legislation before us will achieve two important changes for which the Government can be praised. There are a couple of other changes, however, which could cause some concern. I hope that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will respond to those issues. The Government has made some commendable changes. It has provided for the registration of insurance intermediaries who deal with unauthorised foreign insurers. In order to carry on insurance business in Australia, authority under the Insurance Act 1973 is required. The authorisation process involves making an application, providing the relevant information, and receiving a grant of authority by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. As a result of this legislation, all insurance intermediaries who arrange insurance contracts with unauthorised foreign insurers will be required to register under the Act. They will also provide to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission copies of their agency agreements with the unauthorised foreign insurer, provide an annual return to the Commission and, importantly, obtain written acknowledgment from the insured that cover is being provided by an unauthorised foreign insurer. To recover the additional supervisory costs of this measure the legislation will also implement a fee via regulations on insurance intermediaries who deal with these unauthorised foreign insurers.

The second change which the Government has quite justifiably made is this: the legislation introduces the requirement for each life insurance company to nominate a suitably qualified appointed actuary. This will assist the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to identify the actuary for each company, and this actuary will be responsible for discharging the actuarial functions within the Life Insurance Act. I think those two moves are ones for which the Government should be given considerable credit.

There are, however, a couple of changes which cause the Australian Democrats some concern. The first lies with clauses 20 and 25, which abolish section 13 of the principal Act empowering the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to arbitrate in a dispute between a life insurance company and a policy owner in relation to a policy. It is interesting to note that the explanatory memorandum on page 10 describes clause 20 as repealing unproclaimed sections of the principal Act which are redundant. I find that a rather bizarre statement. Not only the Parliament but also the public is entitled to know why so much legislation that goes through this place is either all or in part left unproclaimed. I wonder what we do here sometimes, arguing and debating legislation, only to find years later sometimes and frequently accidentally that some sections and sometimes whole Acts were never proclaimed for a variety of `Yes Minister' reasons.

The second reading speech claims that this provision, that is section 13, has been used only once in more than 40 years of the operation of the Act. Does this mean that the one dispute was the subject of arbitration on the basis of unproclaimed legislation or is there earlier legislation which established the arbitration facility? Interestingly enough, perhaps even oddly enough, clause 25 also repeals section 13-so we have a double repeal of this section-but includes a saving provision, subclause (2), so that section 13 continues in effect for any parties to a policy who may have already entered into contracts to submit disputes to the Commissioner under section 13. Why, one is forced to ask, is the Government including a saving provision for current disputes when it is repealing a section which we are told has been used only once in over 40 years?

Is it possible that the reason there are so few disputes referred to arbitration by the Commissioner is that arbitration power encourages the insurance companies to settle in favour of the policyholder? I can understand why the insurance industry would be happier to move to self-regulation than to maintain the arbitration power of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. Self-regulation is clearly in the interests of the insurance companies. However, I believe it is good for the public to have someone outside the industry to fall back on. The potential problems of having Caesar reporting to Caesar are legendary, and it may be better for the industry to set up an independent ombudsman to deal with such problems. Perhaps that is what they have in mind. At the moment nobody is aware of that, or if anybody is they have not passed that information on to me. In general, self-regulation works against the interests of the complainant. If the industry wants these sorts of changes, it has to be prepared to show its bona fides by having an outside independent authority to deal with disputes. I would like the Government to come up with some answers to those issues. I would like the Opposition to consider opposing the repeal of section 13 unless the Government has some answers that are a little better than simply saying that it has only been used once in 40 years.

Our second concern relates to clause 42, which increases the threshold for publication in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of life insurance unclaimed moneys. It increases the threshold from $20 to $200. Again, one is forced to ask why. The second reading speech gives an explanation. It argues that publication of unclaimed moneys below $20 is time-consuming and costly; but so are a lot of things that we continue to do. I am aware of the fact that in excess of 50 per cent of all unclaimed moneys are below $200. We are wiping out in this move a large number of listings. What happens to unclaimed money? Is it reported? Is it paid to the Treasury each year and deposited into Consolidated Revenue? The answer to that question is yes. Attempts are then presumably made to find the owners of the money. I say `presumably' because attempts are certainly made, but whether they are actually made to find the owner is a moot point when one considers that attempts are made by inserting a notice in that highly popular publication, the Government Gazette, which we all, as a matter of course in this community, read with considerable interest--

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not miss it.

—Senator Boswell, there are a lot of people who wait breathlessly for the next edition of the Government Gazette to see whether they rate a mention or whether anybody they know rates a mention, or whether Truth has missed out on a story for the week. It is a touch bizarre to argue that we are increasing this limit from $20 to $200 and we are going to help everybody find out whether they are in this little game by putting the notice in the Government Gazette.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1985-86 the total amount of unclaimed moneys under the Life Insurance Act 1945 going into Consolidated Revenue has been over $1m per annum. It is a lovely little revenue raiser for the Government. It does not quite match up to the amount of revenue lost by the fact that half the major companies in this country are paying precious little tax, but it goes some small way towards taking money off ordinary people to make up for those losses to Consolidated Revenue from the bigger companies. In 1987-88 the figure was $1,283,052. That was when the threshold was $20. I wonder whether raising the threshold from $20 to $200 will increase the flow of unclaimed moneys into consolidated revenue, given that about 50 per cent of all unclaimed moneys are below $200. I would have thought the resounding answer to that question was yes. I wonder whether the money would not be put to better use to fund the ombudsman that I mentioned earlier so that there is somebody to act for insurance policy owners who are in dispute with insurance companies, rather than that being done by somebody operating from within the industry. To whom is the person within the industry going to report? If a job is given to a person by the industry, then it can be taken away from that person by the industry, presumably, unless it is a tenured position. There would be enormous pressure placed on somebody within the industry to make enough decisions that are on the side of the industry for that person not to lose the position. The idea of using the unclaimed money to fund an ombudsman to act for insurance policy owners who are in dispute with insurance companies would be an especially good idea if the arbitration function of the Commissioner is abolished.

In any event, the Democrats do not oppose the principle behind these Bills. We applaud some of the moves that the Government has made. But I repeat that I am concerned about the effect of clause 25 of the Insurance Legislation Amendment Bill. I would appreciate it if the Minister could give some assurances with regard to that clause and, in doing so, ensure a fairly speedy run through the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to hold the Senate up for long but I will respond briefly to a couple of points Senator Haines has raised. With regard to the unclaimed moneys, the $20 figure has been in the Life Insurance Act ever since 1945. I cannot state this positively off the top of my head but I think the consumer price index has increased 10-fold since 1945 so in real terms it is about what it was then. We can argue that it should be more or less. But it is entirely consistent with the Act when it was originally passed.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the other question-that is, the repeal of section 13 of the 1945 Act-it might be worth quoting it in part. It says:

. . . if the parties have agreed . . . to submit the dispute or difference to arbitration by the Commissioner, the Commissioner may act as arbitrator of the dispute or difference and his award shall be binding on both parties.

I am advised that that section has been used only once in 44 years. I am also informed that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is examining, in conjunction with other government agencies and industry bodies, possible improved arrangements for resolving disputes between insurers and policyholders. I am advised that those discussions involve not only the regulator and the insurers but also representatives of policyholders. Discussions relating to that question are expected to result in some worthwhile improvements. I do not profess to have any knowledge of this at all, but I am advised that some similar procedures involving the Ombudsman in the United Kingdom either have been in use or are about to be in use and that it is possible or even likely that something similar to that may evolve in Australia. Otherwise, I do not propose to delay the passage of the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 April, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In leading for the Opposition tonight on the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1989 I would say at the outset that the Opposition will be supporting this legislation because it basically provides for Qantas to raise some more money. We are very critical about the steps taken by the Government which put Qantas in the position where it has to raise money once more with the guarantees of the taxpayers. I will be moving an amendment to this motion later on. That amendment will be:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add `, but the Senate calls on the Government to recognise the urgent need to provide additional capital resources for Qantas and to overcome the ideological objections to the sale of shares in the airline to its staff and to the Australian public'.

The Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill is to enable the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on behalf of the Commonwealth to guarantee under certain terms and conditions the payment of amounts which Qantas Airways Ltd is liable to pay with respect to money borrowed to assist in financing the purchase of three new Boeing 747-400 series aircraft and related spare parts and equipment. It is proposed that the limit of any borrowing subject to guarantee should be $US385m or its equivalent, which is 85 per cent of the total project cost of these three aircraft. It is proposed that the terms and conditions under which the moneys are borrowed will be subject to the Treasurer's approval.

This is the first Bill we have had this year for loan raisings for Qantas. I spoke on the last Bill that came before the Senate, which was not so many months back, last year, where funds were raised for the purchase of some new Boeing 767 aircraft. We are certainly going to have more Bills in the future because the Qantas fleet expansion is proceeding almost as fast as Boeing can build the aircraft. As I said in my introduction, the purpose of this Bill is to allow Qantas to borrow more money, with a Commonwealth guarantee. Qantas, of course, despite what the Australian Labor Party thinks, is not a statutory authority; it is a public company and all the shares in Qantas are held by the Commonwealth of Australia.

Initially I want to talk about two points. Firstly, I want to talk about the financial position of Qantas and, secondly, I want to go on to make a few general remarks about Qantas itself. The first point I would like to make is a very basic one. Australia is an island tucked away in a corner of the world quite a long way away from all the great centres of population. The other important basic point is that Australia is a great trading nation. Transport to Australia is big business, both by sea and by air, because it is how we move people to and from this country, and it is how we move our exports and bring in our imports. It is very much in our interests to have a very efficient transport system. We have got to be efficient so that we keep the costs of transport down because everything we buy and everything we sell has a transport component in it. The Australian consumer has to pay for that on goods he buys. The Australian exporter has to lose the cost of transport on what he sells in competition with other world markets. So we want to be as efficient as we can in the transport field.

The second point I would make is that we want to keep as much of the money from transport, that inevitable minimal cost, in Australian hands. In the marine environment, in which we move most of our commodities, we do not have much in Australian hands. Most of the passenger trade comes by air, and we have a higher fraction of that. But in 1986-87, which is the latest year for which I can get figures, sea traffic saw 78 per cent by value of all our imported commodities and 86 per cent by value of our exported commodities. A very low proportion of that was carried in Australian ships. I do not have the precise figure but I have the feeling that about 6 per cent of our export and import trade moves in ships that are owned by Australians or Australian companies. Thanks to the restrictive trade practices of the Seamen's Union of Australia and the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia-as the report of the Inter-State Commission which was brought down at the end of last week and debated in the Senate today in an urgency motion showed-the incentive for Australian companies to own and operate ships both on the coastal trade routes and internationally is so poor that no-one wants to get involved in it.

We have done a bit better in the air. Roughly 40 per cent of the passenger trade moves with Qantas into and out of this country. Despite the very strong unionisation that exists in the airline industry with its inherent inflexibility and its featherbedding leading to low productivity rates from employees in the Australian airline industry, we do have a bigger fraction of the trade coming into and out of this country in the passenger field in Australian-owned aircraft that we do in the comparable commodity trade at sea.

Currently Qantas earns a profit. It also earns a great deal of foreign exchange, said to be about $2.5 billion per year. Given the way this country has been driven into such deep indebtedness through the spendthrift policies of this highest taxing and biggest spending government, it is terribly important that that balance of trade be kept up as high as it can be. For Qantas to stay earning that money for us it is important that it earns a profit because if it does not earn a profit there is a limit as to how long it can stay in the marketplace. One of the real problems that Qantas is looking at is that, unless its capitalisation structure is changed, it will not be able to survive into the future. Australia will lose enormously if that happens.

Last year was the most profitable ever in the history of Qantas. The company declared a profit of around $153m. That has not always been so. In 1982 Qantas lost $20m. In 1983 it lost $47m. From 1984 onwards it has progressively shown increasing profitability. Despite what the Australian Labor Party says, it was not a change of government in 1983 that turned the loss situation into a profit situation; it was the explosion in air travel consequent on the boom in international tourism. For the last four or five years virtually every seat that could be sold to people coming into and out of this country has been filled. Let us look at the economics of aircraft like the Boeing 747 operated by Qantas on long, thin routes where it does not have the penalty of multiple landings that shorter haul operators have. The great majority of routes that Qantas operates on-the Sydney-Tokyo, Sydney-London and Sydney-North America routes-are long, thin routes with very, very few landings on them. Consequently costs are minimised. In normal situations, I would think, the break-even load factor on a Boeing 747 must be somewhere around at least 60 per cent, 62 per cent of seats sold. I believe Qantas is now very close to the maximum attainable figure, which might be 90 or 92 per cent of the seats available on every flight. If that is the case, it should be making a profit.

While we welcome very much the fact that Qantas made a profit last year, a record profit of $153m, one must put that against the funds that are involved in the company structure. It is said that Qantas currently has a gross asset position of about $27 billion. A profit of $153m on that sum is a pretty meagre return. If we look at it another way round and look at the turnover Qantas had last year of $38 billion, it has averaged in the last five years a 4 per cent profit on a ratio of sales to profit, which is not a very impressive result. The crucial thing from an economic point of view is just how much of Qantas is owned by Qantas. The answer to that is: very, very little. The assets position of Qantas is dangerously low. For many years this Government, which has been in power now for more than six years, has been told that something has to be done about the under-capitalisation of Qantas.

Running a company is a bit like running a family. A breadwinner, somebody on a good income, can get a mortgage and buy a house or buy a car on hire purchase. In fact, one can take holidays and buy all the things one wants on a credit card. But if that breadwinner gets sick or loses his job, there is a crisis. The Labor Party does not understand the commercial world. It believes that so long as one can borrow one is a good businessman. That is the whole basis of Mr Keating's approach. Every year since he has been running this country as Treasurer he has lost money. He has taken our debt position up to a record level. He started with a figure of about $30 billion. After six years of Keatingism he has blown it out-depending on how one calculates the exchange rate-to between $125 billion and $130 billion. In the six years that he has been Treasurer he has the disastrous record of averaging a loss for Australia of $1 1/4 billion a month. In every month of the Hawke-Keating regime Australia has spent $1,250m more than it has earned. So long as Mr Keating can keep on borrowing he thinks he is the world's best Treasurer. But there is a limit to how long people will lend us money when we are living beyond our means. Just as a family cannot do it, a country cannot do it and no company can do it. There is always a brick wall ahead.

I would like to return to Qantas. In simple terms, Qantas has borrowed far too much money. Times are good; for the last four or five years it has been making a profit. It can afford to pay the interest on the huge borrowings that it has. But all businesses are cyclical. The Labor Party, with its lack of commercial experience, cannot understand this. It does not matter how good a business is, there are always good times and bad times. It is the bad times that sort out the incompetent operators. At the moment, Qantas cannot service its borrowings without resorting to heavy Government support when the inevitable downturn comes. Times have been good because of the expansion in the tourist traffic but those times could change if there is a downturn in world economies. Inevitably that occurs. We might not like it but it is going to happen.

For years Qantas has been telling this Government that its debt to equity ratio is wrong. Qantas believes that a comfortable debt to equity ration for it is 70 : 30-in other words, borrowing 70 per cent against 30 per cent of its money. But the Government has failed to support it on that. It is now looking at debt to equity ratios of up to 75 : 25. This is a really dangerous level. The Chairman, Mr Jim Leslie, has repeatedly told the Government that the debt to equity ratio has to be addressed. The Government has not done anything about it. At present it is almost unmanageable.

If we look ahead we have two matters on the horizon. As a consequence of the ageing Qantas fleet-the average is 9.6 years and honourable senators know that there is an increasing passenger rejection of older aircraft because of the spate of accidents that have occurred on international aircraft-Qantas will be forced to replace those older aircraft just to maintain its public appeal. That is why Australian Airlines had to get rid of its DC9s. The second problem that faces Qantas is the expansion to stay viable in the market. It must expand. We are now in a world of mega airlines. While I am not sure that it has to be one of the mammoth groupings in the world to survive, Qantas certainly has to be larger than it is at present; otherwise it will become a very minor regional carrier in the South Pacific. Qantas knows very well it has to expand. Its target is to go to about a 50-aircraft fleet, roughly double the size it was five or six years ago. That is one of the reasons why it bought into Air New Zealand Ltd. Doubling the size of the airline means greatly increased borrowings. One cannot do that on the minuscule equity basis that the company has at present.

Even Senator Gareth Evans, the former Minister for Transport and Communications, who was not one of the great financial gurus of the firmament, understood this some years ago. At a Labor Party conference he made the very telling point that just to maintain the equity base- not to pay for the expansion of the company, but to maintain the equity ratio of 70 : 30-Qantas would need an injection of $600m. He asked where it would come from. If Qantas did not expand because it did not have the money, his figures were that, from a position of carrying 44 per cent of the passengers that came into Australia, Qantas would decline to a figure of 28 per cent of the market share in the foreseeable future. A drop of that magnitude will cost Australia a very great deal of money. A 5 per cent drop in that passenger traffic is estimated to cost at least $100m in foreign earnings. From a foreign earnings point of view it is terribly important that Qantas maintain its market share.

Senator Evans, when he was the Minister for Transport and Communications, went on to say that in the foreseeable future Qantas had purchases of new aircraft which would amount to somewhere between $4 billion and $6 billion as well as the infrastructure cost on the ground to support those aircraft. He went on, in reference to the $600m that they would need to put into the Qantas equity pool to support the borrowings for those $4 billion to $6 billion, to say that there was no way that this Government would put that money in and that the only alternative was to privatise the airline; to sell it off.

Unfortunately the Labor Party has few people in it with the insight to understand what is happening. The great majority of the members of the Labor Party run around saying, `Why should we sell a profitable enterprise? It earned $150m plus. We are not going to sell anything that is making that sort of money'. They lack the ability to understand what is ahead in the market. They do not understand that the only way we can raise the money to keep Qantas a successful Australian enterprise is to go into private enterprise. They do not understand that if we are to go into the market and sell Qantas, the time to do it is when Qantas is making its maximum profits. If it is in the red, if it is losing $40m, $50m or $100m a year, no-one, but no-one, will buy it. The time is right now, particularly as the company is set up as a public company, to move into the marketplace and sell it.

Every time I go overseas and check my bags in at a Qantas counter the employees behind the counter invariably say to me, `When are we going to get the chance to buy this airline?'. This happens absolutely without exception. When one talks to pilots or cabin crews, they say, `When can we buy this airline?'. The employees of Qantas want to buy it. They should be able to buy it. So should the Australian public have the chance to buy this airline. The only prohibition that the airline employees at the counter put on it is, `Don't let Hawke sell it to Abeles'. They want to be able to take up their share of the equity and they want to see the Australian public join them. That is the realistic way to go. The Government can maintain, through the golden share principle, Australian control of the airline. The xenophobic horror stories of seeing it sold out to the Arabs, the Japanese, the Germans and all the other people that the Labor Party carries on about, are not realistic. The airline can be sold to the Australian public. Australian control can be maintained. Unless it is sold we will not have the capital base to expand Qantas in the next five years, which we must do if we are to keep it as a viable international carrier.

Apart from capitalisation, Qantas has some other problems. I want to touch on those very briefly. I want to look at it first of all as a traveller. I have been travelling as a passenger with Qantas for well over 25 years. I guess that is longer than some of the board members of Qantas have been travelling on the airline. Now that I am thinking of the board members, I believe that one of the problems Qantas faces is that literally one-third of the board members are Labor Party stooges, people with no commercial or aviation experience, people who have been put on the board of the airline in one of the most ruthlessly competitive international games. They are people whose only claim to fame is the fact that they carry Labor Party membership or are Labor Party sycophants. We simply cannot afford passengers in such a competitive industry.

Last year I went overseas and travelled by Qantas, because I always fly Qantas wherever I can. Unfortunately, on all but one sector the standard of travel offered to passengers was, in my judgment, the worst I have ever seen, so I made a speech in the Senate about it. Certainly I ruffled a few feelings in Qantas, as some of my friends have subsequently informed me. But it needed to be done and I would have been doing less than my duty if I had not drawn attention to the shortcomings-and in my judgment they were gross shortcomings-in the airline last year. This January I went to a conference in North America and afterwards went on to Europe. I can report that the standard has improved a little. The cabin service is up, the aircraft are a little cleaner, and the ground organisation is a little better. But it is not as good as it was five years ago and, most importantly, it is not as good as the competition.

Many other airlines are now giving a better standard of service than Qantas is. Some of the board members of Qantas would be well advised to take some of their travel entitlement and travel on the competition, particularly in tourist or economy and in business class. They should compare what is offering in Qantas with that is on offer among their competitors. Most of them would get a shock. The impression I get when travelling Qantas these days is that the morale of the employees is very poor. There is a real need for a bit of leadership there to boost morale and to motivate them. This was once a great airline and it could be again. When one talks to the staff they are depressed because they do not know where the airline is going; they do not know where the money is coming from.

For all this the Government must take its share of the blame. We have had six years of Labor government and it has failed to address anything in the aviation field. It has failed to address the capitalisation of Qantas, about which I spoke a while ago. It has also failed to address the education market-and education, strangely, has quite an impact on Qantas. This Government has been very keen to throw money at the soft options-the basket makers of Balmain and so on-but we have seen a great collapse in the hard scientific disciplines, the hard intellectual disciplines through the educational program. The teaching of science and maths is at the lowest level it has been for 40 or 50 years in this country. One has only to look at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), whose funds have been cut progressively. I hear today that another 500 employees of CSIRO are programmed to be fired.

Because education is so poor we have a shortage of pilots, a shortage of technicians such as electronics technicians, skilled metal workers and the people needed to run an airline. The only decent training going on in these skills, the hard scientific and technical skills, in the country today is in the Services-in the Air Force for pilot training, radio technicians and airframe fitters, and to a lesser degree in the Army and Navy. The Services are being stripped of these people by the airlines because the Government is not meeting its responsibility to train people for Australian commerce. Although they are excellently trained, in one sense they are inefficiently trained because the requirements of the Services are different and sometimes more advanced than is required for civil use.

The second problem with the Government's handling of Qantas is its inability to realise that it is not part of the Public Service. It has to have the flexibility it needs to get into the marketplace, to offer the wages and conditions to attract the people it needs. The shortage of staff has led Qantas now, for the first time in its life, to have to farm out its aircraft for maintenance. There are six overseas airlines-Air New Zealand, Singapore Airlines, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, United Airlines, Air France and Aer Lingus-all doing maintenance work this year for Qantas, at a cost of at least $10m. Qantas is in the position where not only does it not have enough skilled workers but it also has an average attrition rate of 18 per cent. Its experience level has been pretty well halved in the last few years.

I mention that not only is investment in aircraft required but also a major investment in infrastructure, the building of hangars and workshops and test facilities for the company is needed. In the next few years that will involve the company in expenditure of well over $1 billion, and again that must be financed. In 1982 I suggested that Qantas should start to move out of Sydney. Sydney has become overpopulated and it is too constricted, quite apart from the paralysis of this Government in coping with the runways. Sydney now is built up and it is virtually impossible to build new facilities there. Quite regularly since 1982 I have been putting the case in public that Qantas should move to Brisbane with its maintenance facilities. It is also the logical point of entry into Australia because we find now that nearly 40 per cent of tourists into Australia want to come to Queensland. That percentage will rise, and it will rise above 50 per cent. Brisbane is closer to the sources from which these tourists come than is Sydney or Melbourne, and there is an economic advantage in taking tourists into Brisbane.

Sadly, we have had no support for this proposition from the Queensland Government, and only in the last month or so has it started to talk about Qantas coming there. But had I had the support of the Queensland Government and the Brisbane City Council, I think there would have been a good chance that Qantas would have considered more seriously the movement to Queensland. Not only is the space available in Brisbane on which to develop and build, but it is also a curfew-free airport and, most importantly, there is a work force there. It is very hard now for any line of commercial activity to get people to move to Sydney because of the huge cost of housing and the great travelling imposition of them.

In summary, we now have an airline that is grossly overstretched; its management skills are at full tilt; and it is critically and dangerously short of capital. It is essential that the Government recognise the mess in which it has put the company and the inherent dangers of the situation. Unless the Government resorts to the taxpayer when the inevitable downturn comes, the company cannot service its debt position. The Government does not seem to understand this. It is clinging to an outmoded ideology. The Government believes that somehow or other Qantas is owned by all Australians and that if it is sold it will not be owned by all Australians. The truth is that it is owned by the Australian Government on behalf of Australians at present, and by selling it to Australian citizens and Australian companies it will still maintain the same equity which will guarantee its survival into the future. After all, Qantas started as a private company in my own State of Queensland and survived until the Chifley Government nationalised it in the mid-1940s. I formally move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate calls on the Government to recognize the urgent need to provide additional capital resources for Qantas and to overcome the ideological objections to the sale of shares in the airline to its staff and to the Australian public''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with much that Senator MacGibbon has said, but not his final conclusion. I do not feel there is any need to privatise Qantas Airways Ltd. If it were privatised the fears expressed by those employees who have been talking to him about Sir Peter Abeles taking over would be realised. I am sure Sir Peter Abeles would be in like a shot. He knows a profitable organisation when he sees one. The operation of Qantas is a very useful bit of activity for the Government and the people of Australia to be engaged in. Qantas, as we all know, has high standards. It serves the country. It brings in foreign exchange.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon has listed a number of these things. He also touched on an area of concern which I would like briefly to reiterate, and that is the lack of maintenance personnel at Qantas. That is probably more due to the low pay regime than the lack of educational opportunities. Qantas simply does not seem to pay enough to keep people in the company. Of course, this comes at a time when the 747 aircraft is under increasing scrutiny because of a lack of safety evident in some aircraft in recent times. The 747s were considered to be completely indestructible, and up until now they have been pretty good. But cracks are starting to show. Most recently people at Boeing, including Mr Ulf Goranson, the manager of structural technology, have stated that the design life of the 747 is 20,000 flights, 60,000 hours or 20 years. Some 68 aircraft have exceeded these limits. One that we need to be concerned about is VH-EBA, which is a Qantas aircraft. It has done 19,000 flights and 59,000 hours, so it is almost up to the limit. It has to be inspected and watched closely.

Unfortunately Qantas, as Senator MacGibbon has said, does not have the personnel to do all the maintenance work, and some of it is being farmed out. I am told by Qantas pilots as I go overseas that sometimes they are forced to fly the aircraft with unworkable systems. This is not necessarily dangerous because the 747, like all modern aircraft, has a redundant system capability. There is generally at least two of everything, and if one system is not operable the aircraft can still be flown safely. However, this aircraft was designed to have the redundant systems and they should be operable. The industry estimates that Qantas is presently short of 150 personnel in the maintenance area. This is something that should be looked at, but I do not think that selling the airline to Sir Peter Abeles will solve that problem.

The Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill is to enable Qantas to obtain some new Boeing 747-400 aircraft. Unfortunately, these aircraft are not being delivered as rapidly as Qantas or other operators would like because of difficulties in their electronic systems. They are very sophisticated, as noted in the second reading speech. They have a `new technology cockpit' which enables them to be crewed by two pilots. Unfortunately this cockpit is also subject to electronic interference. The pilots found when flying one of these aircraft over a very powerful transmitter in Europe that the electronics went on the blink and they were not quite sure whether they could control the aircraft. Many of these aircraft are still sitting on the ramp at Boeing and will remain there until a suppression mechanism can be installed to shield the electronics from radiation. So it may be a while before we get them.

The Boeing 747 itself is a wonderful aircraft. I often think, however, being an old-time pilot, that it would be better if we stopped this love affair with electronics and went back to basic pilot skills, with hydraulics and even wire and cable systems, for that matter, and used electronics as indicating devices, letting the pilots fly the aircraft. But I may be a voice in the wilderness and showing my age. I do not know whether Senator MacGibbon would agree with my analysis or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would want big muscles for that.

—I think a pilot probably would, for a 747. The Blohm and Voss, the great big German aircraft, was flown by a woman and was controlled entirely by cables. It is possible, if an aircraft is designed with a balanced control system, to fly it that way. I have digressed mightily, and I will not take the time of the Senate any further. I agree with many of Senator MacGibbon's comments. I hope that the Government can see its way clear to allow Qantas to hire the maintenance staff it needs, and I hope that it is able to keep an eye on some of the older aircraft. I frequently fly on Qantas and I will note the aircraft designations. But I have confidence that I will always arrive at my destination safely. I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support for the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill. Inevitably the debate, particularly Senator MacGibbon's contribution, turned into an extended recitation of the problems of Qantas's capitalisation. It is certainly a familiar theme for me, as Senator MacGibbon well appreciated when he quoted me, I gather, quite extensively during the course of his contribution. The Government acknowledges that Qantas is playing an extremely significant role in Australia's balance of trade. We want that role to continue in the future. We acknowledge that it is possible for that to occur only in an expanding aviation market and an environment where Qantas has the capacity itself to expand its fleet. We acknowledge the commercial reality that that will involve some improvement in its capital base. The question at issue, as Senator MacGibbon well knows-I certainly well know because I lived with this issue for a year or more as Minister-is just how that can best be achieved. There is no question of our burying our heads in the sand and refusing to acknowledge the nature and extent of the problem. I think we all acknowledge it. Qantas is an issue about which emotions run wide and deep in segments of the community. As a result it is important for us to address the issues carefully and to make sure that we get it right.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor governments have certainly in the past not been reluctant to respond quickly to the perceived needs of government owned airlines. Since Qantas was purchased by the Chifley Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government from the British Government and Australian private interests in 1947, the company has received a total of $148.4m in capital injections. Qantas received $66.2m in 10 years of Labor governments and $82.2m from Liberal-National Party, or Country Party, governments over a period of 31 years. I do not think our record has been in any way at fault by comparison with that of the other side. On regaining government in 1983 we moved quickly to address the under-capitalisation problem faced by Qantas. We injected $60m, raising paid up capital from $89.4m to $149.4m-an increase of 67 per cent. We moved with our public sector micro-economic reform package last year to improve the commercial operation of the company. The particular question of capital needs is being addressed by an ALP committee established by the National Conference which is examining the whole range of investment needs and funding options for both Australian Airlines and Qantas. We are also looking at the application of some remaining broad controls, such as the Australian Loan Council, to the fully commercial Commonwealth owned enterprises operating in a competitive environment, of which Qantas is obviously a major example. I am quite happy, as I have been in the past, to engage in an extended debate on these matters at an appropriate time and place. But with an uncontroversial piece of legislation of the kind presently before us and in an environment where the committee to which I referred is still doing its work, I do not think it is helpful for me to wax any more lyrical than I have been on this subject. I think it is inappropriate for that committee's work to be pre-empted at this stage.

We all know that Qantas has been carrying record numbers of passengers into and out of Australia and that its profit position has improved dramatically as a result, no doubt riding, as it has done, on the wave of massively increased aviation business over the last few years. I simply repeat for the record that we are determined to ensure that Qantas keeps pace with the game. Questions about effective maintenance and so on are ones that both the airline and the Government are wrestling with. We would love to be able to snap our fingers and get on board the extra numbers of maintenance staff that are needed to keep ahead of the game in that respect. But as Senator MacGibbon, Senator Sanders and others should well appreciate, this is an extremely difficult thing to achieve without causing breaches in that dyke of the wage system which we are trying very hard to avoid.

So it is a matter of being conscious of the whole range of problems that the airline is being confronted with. This particular piece of legislation is, of course, a response initially to current capital raising problems. There need to be some longer term solutions but the time to talk about those in more detail is not now. I commend the legislation to the Senate and thank the chamber for its support, making clear as I do, of course, that we cannot accept, for the reasons that I have already indicated, the Opposition amendment that was moved by Senator MacGibbon.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 March, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1989 provides for an increase in salaries for Ministers from a total of $745,000 to $820,000. While the total sum might sound quite substantial, in fact I do not believe that it is. The increase that we are approving this evening is some $75,000. If we divide that by 30, which I think is the current number of Ministers, each Minister would receive an increase of $2,750. This is not a particularly substantial amount when tax is taken out. The increases are required to be approved by the Parliament, as the Ministers of State Act requires legislative amendment to increase ministerial salaries. This increase has resulted from two reviews conducted by the Remuneration Tribunal in 1987 and 1988. The Opposition does not intend to oppose this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: There are one or two matters, though, that ought to be looked at. It is always difficult to deal with parliamentary salaries. Somehow this subject always generates a very emotional response in sections of the community and sections of the media, frequently from those members of the media who get far more substantial salaries than do any of us in this place. Let me put into perspective some of the salaries that are the subject of this legislation. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has a base salary of $55,000 and an additional $56,931, which gives him a total salary of $111,931. At the same time, the head of his Department gets $100,402. I think a very good case can be made out for saying that while we are not in any way putting down the position or role of head of his Department, the Prime Minister's salary is sufficiently near that salary as to be not reasonable.

But the story gets far worse. The basic salary and allowances of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) bring his total salary to $86,016. But the Secretary to the Treasury receives a salary of $100,402. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) receives a total salary of $80,747; the Secretary to the Department of Social Security receives $92,343. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) receives a total salary of $80,747; the Secretary to his Department gets $92,343. So of the four I have mentioned-the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, the Minister for Social Security and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs-three receive less than the heads of their own departments.

I have not mentioned these figures to suggest in any way that the heads of their departments are being paid more than they ought to be. The number of recent resignations by secretaries to departments and senior public servants would indicate that they are able to obtain more substantial salaries in the private sector. I suggest that one does not need to read many newspapers to find out that in fact men of that ability are able to earn and do earn more in the private sector. What is not adequate, of course, are the salaries of the Ministers to whom I have referred. Their salaries are a sample of what is being paid.

I am somewhat bothered that if we continue to do what has in fact been done on a number of occasions over the last 10 years, we will finish up with parliamentary salaries being so low that we will have done a great disservice to the democratic process and the institution of parliament. I believe that all of us here should accept the responsibility and have the fortitude to recognise what we need to do. We need to pass on to our children and grandchildren a parliamentary system which works. On a number of occasions since the Remuneration Tribunal was established in 1973, the Parliament has decreased the salaries which have been recommended. In fact, by doing so, we have held salaries down. If this continues, we run the risk that the only people who will be members of parliament will be those under patronage or those who are sufficiently wealthy in their own right to be here. We will significantly change the process that has been developed since this Parliament was established in 1901.

I know that it is fashionable to criticise politicians and criticise their salaries. But sooner or later, if those in the Parliament do not have the courage to stand up and say what needs to be said, we will be sorry and we will be subject to criticism by those who come after us.

I briefly want to refer to a book called Fair Enough which came into my hands just recently.This book, which is written by Roger Holdich, deals with possible changes in the way in which salaries and allowances for Australian parliamentarians are set and administered. It is a summary of Roger Holdich's discussions and investigations while he was overseas on a senior executive fellowship which was completed in mid-1988. He compares salaries and allowances and the manner of fixing and determining them in the United States of America, Canada, the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, France, Italy and the European Parliament. He deals with the questions of both salaries and allowances and how they should be set and how they should be administered. He points out:

The upshot has been a substantial slippage in politicians' salaries. Six years ago a backbencher received roughly the same salary as a Senior Executive Service level two public servant. At the end of 1988, the latter received $57,775, or 17% more than the backbencher.
He suggests some changes and says:

If wage justice is to be achieved and maintained, parliamentary salaries should be linked to those of a less contentious group, such as the public service; or the Government should accept that the power to decide levels of salaries of parliamentarians resides with the Remuneration Tribunal, and that there should be no questioning by government or Parliament of the umpire's decision.

I recommend this book to anyone who is interested in the topic. He goes on to list a number of other characteristics and matters that should be taken into account when assessing these matters. In referring to other countries, he mentions those that have attached their parliamentary salaries to less controversial groups.

Frequently it is said that one politician may be worth more than another and that that makes it difficult to decide what the salary should be. Since I have been in the Senate I have met few who have not been energetic and hardworking. We do not find the same criteria taken into account in assessing other's salaries. When we are assessing teachers' salaries, for example, we do not decide the amount which will be paid to the whole group based on whether they are particularly diligent or not. I know of no other group in the community in respect of which that is taken into account in the same way as some would suggest it ought to be when assessing politicians' salaries. Mr Holdich says:

I would strongly support linkage with an appropriate level of the Senior Executive Service of the Australian Public Service. Alternatively, the Government should accept that the power to decide salaries of parliamentarians resides with the Remuneration Tribunal, and should accept the determinations of that body. In this way the salaries are more likely to rise as a result of an assessment of what is equitable rather than what is politically expedient.

It is necessary to see that senior public servants-in fact, all public servants, judges and others who are serving the community-are remunerated properly; and it is time that we put our heads together and worked out a system that ensures that our democratic process will continue. This book has extracts, details and information about the salary setting in all of the countries that I have referred to. As I said, I recommend it to anyone who is interested in this topic. The increase in salary relates to ministerial salaries only and it is not opposed by the Opposition. In fact, it is not a particularly substantial amount. But I believe that there are far more significant issues that the Parliament needs to look at on the question of parliamentary salaries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ministers of State Amendment Bill 1989 relates to the increases that are necessary and must be passed by this form of legislation to allow the Ministers of State the salary rises and allowance rises that flowed through to members through the Remuneration Tribunal's determination of last year. The last time I spoke on this piece of legislation I pointed out that Ministers of State, as a group, could be seen as the group worst off, with regard to salaries and allowances, of all members of the Federal Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for that are many and varied; but, if one looks at the structure of Ministers' pay, one finds not only the salary of a Minister as a member of parliament and the electoral allowance component that is also available to all members of parliament, but also a salary of office component and a ministerial allowance component. The last two are such that, when one looks at the total taxation of the package that arose through legislation passed by this Parliament with regard to the fringe benefits arrangements, undoubtedly most Ministers now would find it extremely difficult to be able to detail, under the taxation law, any deductions with regard to the ministerial allowances.

Ministers of State, under any government and any political party, will be working extremely long hours and in extremely onerous jobs. It is obvious that anybody who retains a ministry in any government, against the types of pressures that come from the back bench, must be performing and must be seen to be performing. So, there are a number of pressures that keep Ministers in there working, not least of which presumably is their desire to stay as Ministers and the desire of many people that they might move on.

On top of that there are the demands of this place. We have seen in recent days one Minister make an explanation with regard to the changing of the Hansard record. When we look at that item in isolation, as we were required to, the justification for the Senate passing a censure motion is obvious, and I voted for that. But, when we look at it in the totality of all the other things, we can well see how an item such as that may slip by. But that is no excuse and cannot be offered as an excuse in this place. In other words, on top of the normal workload there is that additional demand of ministerial responsibility under the Westminster system.

On top of that there are the normal types of pressures that are put on anybody operating in a job with that type of responsibility, the normal stresses and strains, the normal departmental problems which have to be solved and which may flow through to the Minister, and the normal activities of the Minister of receiving delegations of overseas visitors. Added to those is the necessity for the Ministers to attend conferences, to speak at conferences, to visit various parts of the Commonwealth with regard to their own portfolio and to receive delegations of interest groups and individuals from the community.

When we start adding these items together, it does not take long to see that the task of a Minister is not a simple and easy one, and it is one that the Commonwealth and of the people of Australia certainly all wish to have done well. I think that under those circumstances the remuneration that is offered is not commensurate with the job that we demand to be done. In fact I remember sitting with the Minister at the table tonight, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), at a table at a conference in a hotel in this city a couple of years ago, when this particular item came up. The other people at the table were directors and managing directors of companies in Australia. The Minister was giving the keynote address, and I think he was receiving the second lowest salary of anybody at the table. The person who was getting a lower one was, of course, me.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about relative worth, not salary.

—Yes, but the Minister was the person who was ultimately responsible for the policy decisions that were going to flow through and affect all of those people who were there from the companies. To me, that was an example of the absurdities that can come about when there is not a market link to the job that is required.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid pointed to a particular document that has been generated in recent times. It certainly is an interesting document, and I join with her in recommending that people go through it. However, I remember a previous document circulated in the British Parliament which made the unerring discovery that seats in the House of Commons could be filled for no salary whatsoever. That is true as well; for a long time they were. In other words, it is notoriously difficult to find for a backbencher an adequate linkage in the market arrangement. I am not at all sure that that is the case with Ministers of State. It is fairly obvious that there are corporations within Australia and overseas of the size of our departments. In fact, some corporations are easily the size of the nation.

When one looks at the salary packages that are provided to some of those people, one gets an idea of the enormous remuneration packages available. I understand that the highest remuneration package provided to an Australian chief executive is of the order of $800,000. That is an extraordinary amount of money in anybody's terms. When one goes down the line and looks at some of our public servants one sees that our Prime Minister is paid less than quite a number of our public servants, who admittedly are running large corporations under the public umbrella. Nevertheless they are public corporations, and the Prime Minister is the one who is held ultimately responsible for the health of the general economy and the social economy of the country.

It is a fair and reasonable proposition, although it is always unpopular, that the salaries of Ministers of State need to be put on a much more market oriented scale. At some stage it will have to occur; at some stage it will undoubtedly happen. There will probably be belly-aches from the editors of the major newspapers, all of whom get two or three times what Ministers currently get. That has to be worn. But at the end of the day, to do anything less is to sell the job short because our society wishes to provide remuneration on the basis of the job that is done. It is not as though the Ministers, in the jobs they do, are somehow immune from accountability. As I have already pointed out, there is a large range of ways in which Ministers are held accountable-by their colleagues, by the normal arrangements of their departments, by the Parliament, and by the people.

The general proposition that everybody ought to be able to accept is that a Minister of State should not be paid less than the secretary to the department he administers. That is not the case at the moment. Ministers of State should be paid more than the secretaries to their departments and their remuneration package should be more than that of the secretaries to their departments. How much more will be a matter which will be determined some years hence, when some sanity comes into this area. At present we ought to say that that is the basis upon which the salaries should be determined. I have been looking at these matters in recent times, and it seems to me that one fair way of doing it would be to have the salary package of the secretary to the department plus 15 per cent, that 15 per cent to be delivered as a ministerial package, as it were, so that the Minister as the senior person receives the highest salary in a departmental structure.

I do not expect that these matters will ever be discussed with sanity-certainly not for some time, although I must admit that last time round I was quite surprised by some journalists' comments on this matter. It struck me that at last somebody was starting to look and listen and calculate the context in a more reasonable and rational way rather than take the easy line, which is to knock the type of work any politician has to do. I have never subscribed to the notion that if we raise the salaries we will necessarily get better people. That is an argument which really has no bearing on the matter.

What one is looking for is the job to be competently done and to be paid appropriately, because the pay and allowances within our society indicate the worth we wish to put on the job. I would have thought that the worth we wish to put on the jobs done by Ministers and by the Prime Minister is such that we would want them to be paid amongst the top salaries in our society. Certainly we believe they should be paid the same types of salaries as executives of top public corporations. Certainly a Minister should be paid more than the person who is heading up the department the Minister has to bear the brunt of and for which he bears the responsibility. As I said, at some stage that will occur, but it is probably some years off. Hopefully it will come about.

On that basis we support the Bill before the Senate. We regret that we have not yet managed to get over the normal political hiccups that occur in this matter. Presumably at some stage sanity will strike and we will be able to deal with this subject on a saner basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for the support of this measure, and I say that with rather more feeling than I normally bring to bear on second reading replies. In fact, I think I have to say that the contributions made to tonight's debate by Senator Reid and Senator Macklin represent the finest, most sensitive, and far-sighted statesmanlike contributions that I have ever heard either of them make in this place. I have often speculated on just what it is that motivates people to embark upon this profession of politics.
—Don't try to tell us now.

—No. I have concluded that there are just two motivations that are relevant: one is megalomania and the other is idealism. Those two factors are always there. The proportions, of course, vary from individual to individual. Whatever it is, it is certainly not money. Manifestly, the Ministers of State Amendment Bill, which does nothing much more than make it possible to adjust ministerial salaries for the national wage case, will not make much difference on the monetary front.
—Speaking from an idealist's perspective.

—Indeed. It is bad enough, with the sorts of comparisons one can draw in terms of hours worked and executive responsibility, to compare Ministers' positions with people in the private sector or in equivalent or comparable professions, but I should also say for the record, in an equivalent feat of statesmanship, that it is not only Ministers whose salaries do not reflect their real effort and responsibilities, I think that is very clear also in the case of backbenchers.
—And shadow Ministers.

—All of us. I think it is important that some sanity, some fairness of an elementary kind, should ultimately prevail in this respect. One lives in hope that it will happen. Tonight's Bill is clearly not the occasion for this being achieved. Nonetheless, we are grateful for small mercies. I am certainly grateful on behalf of the body of Ministers for the support the Senate has rendered to this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.
SPEECH.PARA: Mr President--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not going to speak, are you?

—I will not keep the Senate more than a couple of minutes. I will excuse the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) if he feels that he has had enough for the day. I rise to make mention of a speech which I think is important and should become part of the national record. It was one given by Sir Llew Edwards on 19 September last year. Sir Llew was Chairman of World Expo 88. In that speech he spoke beyond Expo and gave to all of us who have had an opportunity to read the speech a real message worthy of further note.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Llew looked at Expo in light of the extent of the challenge that was ahead of him, in particular, the fact that there had not been an exposition in the Southern Hemisphere in 100 years, the problems of isolation, particularly perceived as such by the Europeans, and an uninterested and cynical media. His approach was that those involved should roll up their sleeves, plan, work towards success and develop to ensure success. He made mention in this speech that there was no Commonwealth money involved, and yet the organisers were able to put together a budget of $620m. He said the Expo would make a profit, and it did. He noted that not one hour was lost in industrial dispute and that they were able to negotiate to operate without penalty rates or overtime. Everything was finished on schedule and on target. The reasons were that they believed in the project, they had a vision and they worked and fought to achieve it. As we all know, it was a wonderful success.

Sir Llew puts it in the form of four principles which would apply to anything that is done in this country if success is the real objective: firstly, the need for a belief in the project; secondly, the need to strive after excellence; thirdly, anything can be achieved if there is involved sufficient generation of national pride; and finally, it can be achieved if those who are in a decision making capacity respect and value the dignity of people. He put it in terms that he, in his own position as Chairman, had no greater importance in the project than the cleaners. He said:
This spirit of Australia is the hope of the future and we must not lose the opportunity or abuse the privilege.
I believe that this is a message that Australians should take note of, and therefore I seek leave to table the speech.
Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
